Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you were rather frightened? A. Yes: not so much when I saw them run as when I saw the man bleeding: it is rather a lonely place - my husband had told me he had taken two of the men before I went to the watch-house.

Q. How long was it after you saw the prosecutor till you saw him bleeding? A. It might be five minutes - I cannot exactly say; it appeared so to me waiting: I dare say the men staid a minute under the window - it was all done in a very short time; I told the Magistrate I could recognise them by their faces - I am almost positive I mentioned their faces; they had hats on - I do not believe that either of them had a cap on under the window; they wore hats, to the best of my recollection; I cannot be certain whether one might not have a cap, but the rest of their dress I particularly noticed; I believe they wore hats - I only guess the distance of the lamp.

JAMES HORNE. I am a watchman. I was applied to by Raim, and took up the two male prisoners; they said nothing to me - Turner's trousers were both wet and dirty at the knees, as if he had been down in the dirt on his knees; I took them to the watch-house; I did not know either of them before - I had not seen either of them that night.

ANDREW FISHER
. I am a watchman, of Great North-street and Grove-road. On the evening of the 6th of May, a little before eleven o'clock. I was standing at the corner of Great North-street, Marylebone, about ten minutes toeleven o'clock; I observed five men come in a direction from St. John's-wood; I have seen the whole five ofter before - I could tell the names of two of those who are absent, and am certain the prisoners are two of those five -I have frequently seen them passing up and down the grove of a night, but did not know their names; I am certain they are two of the five, for I followed them down North-street to observe what they were about: I know where Raim lived in Great North-street; they were going in a direction towards his house, but they turned off towards Little North-street; the extent of my beat is at the end of Great North-street - I did not follow them further; they were then seventy-two paces from where the robbery was done; I have measured it: though I stated it to the Magistrate to be about one hundred and fifty yards, I measured it, and it is seventy-two paces of my own steps.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you measure the distance of the nearest lamp to Raim's house? A. It is about fifty paces; I call one of my paces a yard - her window is a height that I think a person might be identified from.

NATHANIEL BIRNIE
. I am one of the serjeants of Mary-lebone watch. About twenty-five minutes past eleven o'clock, I was coming along Church-street, Lisson-grove, and saw some of the watchmen's lights in an open place; I ran across, and saw the two male prisoners in custody; Davis came up, and said, in their presence, "That is the man who held my mouth;" (pointing to Turner) Turner heard that - they made no reply in my hearing; Davis identified them both - he said he believed them both to be the men who held him down, and held his mouth; and he said if it was so, the knees of their trousers must be dirty- I turned a watchman's lantern towards Turner, and both the knees of his trousers were dirty and wet; I examined Crowther - there were no marks on his knees - I examined their shoes; they were dirty - I took them to the watch-house, and next morning I went to the spot where the robbery was committed, and saw a quantity of blood there, and footmarks, as if a struggle had taken place, and the impressions of shoes - it is a yellow brick clay soil; I went with Webster, the officer, to the watch-house, about half-past five o'clock that morning; Webster took off Turner's shoes, and Crowther pulled his off himself - I tried one pair at the place, and Webster the other; we compared them with the marks, and they exactly fitted, even the nails, and every thing - I am perfectly certain that those shoes had made the marks on that ground - that is my judgment; there were more marks than had been made by these two pairs of shoes - the tip of the heel of one pair had been worn off; this is it, and there were marks fitting it, and other marks of the very same number of nails in - the tips of both pairs fitted some of the marks.

Q.Was there any thing out of the common way in the shoe, did you find marks that exactly fitted it? A. I did; here are Crowther's shoes - they were also very plain to be seen; these nails in the too were very plain; I have no doubt these shoes must have been on the feet of the individuals who were on the spot.

Cross-examined. Q. Did they not appear to be the marks of persons who had been struggling about? A. No; there did not appear to have been struggling where the footmarks were - they are ordinary shoes; Davis did not express a doubt about the men in my hearing - he was quite certain of them; he believed them both to be the men.

Q. Did he not say the two men had knelt over him? A. No, not exactly; he said Turner was the man who knelt over him, and he believed the other to be the man who held his mouth - he did not say I should find the knees of both of them dirty, but I examined both; I found no large carving-knife - I found three knives; Davis said some person in a blue coat held a carving-knive over his breast - it had not rained in the night.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I belong to the Police-office, of Marylebone. I went with Birnie to the watch-house, and took the shoes off the prisoners - I accompanied him to the spot where the robbery was committed, and compared the shoes with the footmarks very carefully, and am convinced these shoes had been there before; I was perfectly satisfied as to Turner's shoes by the length, the width, and the tip to the heel, and the nails in the heel, all correspond with the marks - we measured them; I have no doubt whatever of Turner's shoes having been there before, also by the colour of the clay on them - I compared Crowther's shoes with some marks, and was not so satisfied in my own mind as to his as Turner's; I apprehended the female prisoner from the description that was given of her, and knowing she was acquainted with Turner - I went down to the New Prison thinking she would be bringing him refreshment; I saw her there, took her, and told her it was on suspicion of having been with Davis that night - she denied it.

Cross-examined. Q. She knew Turner was in prison? A. Yes, because she went there to him - Crowther took off his shoes, picked them up, looked at them, and said, "You cannot match mine," I have not satisfied myself about his.
CROWTHER'S Defence. I and Turner went to Kilburn, and came across the place twice where the robbery was - and I went to case myself upon that very place where the shoemarks were.

THOMAS WORLEY
. I have known Crowther about seven years, and Turner one - they bore good characters; they came to me when I was at work at Mr. Watkin's brickfield, Portland-town, to ask if I could tell them of a job of work - there is loose clay and earth in that field; they wheeled up some dirt - it was on Wednesday the 6th of May.
Four witnesses gave Turner and Crowther good characters.

CROWTHER -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.

TURNER -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the prosecutor on account of the respectability of their friends.

STEPHENS -
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury - before Mr. Recorder.

1205.
BRYAN KENNEDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Horatio Charles Anthony Hardy
, from his person .

CHARLES HORATIO ANTHONY HARDY
. I live at Stoke Newington. On the 25th of April, about two o'clock in the afternoon, I was walking from Cornhill
to the East India-house
, and near Angel's, the pastry-cook's shop, I perceived my handkerchief was gone, on feeling for it; I am certain it was safe when I was in the Jerusalem coffee-house; on my return from the India-house, where I hadstaid a very short time - I met Gordon who informed me he had taken up a boy; I found the prisoner in custody at the Mansion-house with my handkerchief, which had my name in full length on it.

JAMES BLAKE
GORDON. I am a cooper and shipowner. I saw Mr. Hardy on his return from the India-house - about twenty minutes before that, I had seen the prisoner and given charge of him to an officer in Cornhill, for taking a handkerchief from a pocket; I took the handkerchief from the prisoner's hand myself, and saw the prosecutor's name on it - I knew him on seeing him; I asked if it was his - the prisoner was in custody with two others; I saw him take the handkerchief from a pocket, but did not know it was the prosecutor then; the other two went away immediately as I laid hold of the prisoner - one of them was older than him.

THOMAS HERDSFIELD
. I am an officer. On the 25th of April Mr. Gordon delivered this handkerchief to me; he brought the prisoner into the Mansion-house, and charged him with stealing it - he said something about another boy having given it him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it on the ground in Rosemary-lane and took it up.
MR. GORDON. I am sure I saw him take it out of a gentleman's pocket - he was before the other two.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Life .

1206.
MARGARET LLOYD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 1 watch, value 38s.; 1 chain, value 1s., and 2 keys, value 1s., the goods of
William Wooding
, from his person .

WILLIAM WOODING
. I am ostler at the Ship inn, Fulham. On the 12th of March I was in London; I was at the Ship public-house, in Ivy-lane
, early in the morning; I treated the watchman with a glass of gin, and had one myself - I was quite sober; I saw the prisoner in the taproom, and sat in the same box with her, on the same side of the table - I did not enter into coversation with her; I remained in that box with her from half-past five till half-past seven o'clock, and then she was gone; she asked me to treat her with gin - I refused: it was about an hour before she left - she left about half-past seven o'clock; before that she was very pressing for me to accompany her as a woman of the town; she wanted me to go out with her - I refused: I got up to go away about ten minutes after she was gone - I was going to see what time it was, and my watch was gone; one more woman had been in the same box, one on my right side, and the other on my left: the prisoner left first - the other stopped till after the officer came: she seemed the same description of woman - she was searched, but nothing found on her; she was taken to Guildhall, and then discharged; I have not found my watch - there were several persons in the tap-room at first, but for the last half hour there were only these two women in the same box; I sat down as soon as I got in - the prisoner came and sat by me: I moved to the other side, and she came and sat by me again - I felt my watch safe about half-past six o'clock, and looked at it, and am certain nobody was near me after that, except the prisoner and the other woman; nobody sat opposite to me - the taproom was partly full when I first went in; neither of them left the box till the prisoner went away - they had not stirred.
Prisoner. Q. Do you mean to say I was there at seven o'clock? A. Yes.

JOSEPH BATES
. I am an officer. I was sent for to the Ship about twenty minutes to eight o'clock - the prisoner was not there; I had seen her there about half-past six o'clock, endeavouring to scrape company with the prosecutor - another girl was there, and five or six men in the house: I stopped about five minutes, looking at the prosecutor - he shunned her, and shifted his seat; I went there again about half-past seven o'clock - she was then sitting very near him, in the same box; the other girl was fast asleep - directly I went in, the prisoner got up and left the tap-room, and in about twenty minutes he missed his watch- I went after her, but did not see her again for a month afterwards; I am sure she was there at half-past seven o'clock.

HEZEKIAH WILMER. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner, and found nothing on her - she said, "I know what you want me for - it is about the watch;" I was at the Ship at half-past seven o'clock, and saw her leave the house - the prosecutor missed his watch within ten minutes.
Prisoner's Defence. I was there, and asked him for drink, having come a long journey, but I was at home before seven o'clock.

ANN HANDS
. I am the prisoner's sister - she lived with me in Angel-alley, Bishopsgate-street, and works at the umbrella trade - I heard of this watch being stolen, and that it was said she was in the prosecutor's company; she had come in between six and seven o'clock on the morning of the robbery, and had not a farthing.
NOT GUILTY .

1207.
JOHN WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of June , 95lbs. of lead, value 10s., the goods of
James Chadwick
and others, and fixed to a certain building of his .

WILLIAM HUNT
. I am in the employ of Mr. James Chadwick - the premises in question were not in his possession on the 3d of June, but he was proprietor of the fixtures, which remained there to be taken by the next tenant- his right to the fixtures was gone; he had no right to the occupation of the house at that time: Mrs. E. Ballard was the proprietor.
NOT GUILTY .

1208.
THOMAS RANGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Abraham George Favenc
, from his person .

ABRAHAM GEORGE
FAVENC. I am a warehouseman , and live in Cheapside. On Tuesday, the 2d of June, I was by the Bank
, returning home, and had used my handkerchief in Bishopsgate-street; it was about a quarter to ten o'clock at night - I observed the prisoner, with two more, by the Royal Exchange - I crossed over from them by the Bank, and near the end of the Bank I missed my handkerchief; on turning round I observed the prisoner about three yards from me - when I went towards him the other two persons passed me; I went towards the prisoner and saw him throw my handkerchief away - he attempted to run: I caught hold of him, and accused him of stealing my handkerchief - the others ran away; Garton came up,and took charge of him - I picked up the handkerchief: he begged of me to forgive him, and promised if I would let him go he would not do so again.

JOHN GARTON
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner following the prosecutor; the other two were about ten yards behind him - I knew them by sight: I did not see the handkerchief taken; the prisoner went right under the Piazza - the others dodged about, and met at the other end- he spoke to them, and went on towards the Bank, and just before they came down to princes-street, I saw the prisoner turn round; the prosecutor turned round immediately, and I saw the prisoner throw the handkerchief on the railing of the Bank; the other two went on, and took not the least notice.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .

1209.
CHARLES CALLAN
was indicted for
embezzling the sum of 13l. 7s. 10d., which he had received on account of
Henry Taylor
, his master , he having been before convicted of felony.

HENRY TAYLOR
. I am a Custom-house agent . The prisoner had been my clerk for about seven months - I entrusted him to receive money on my account and to pay it; Mrs. Thacker owed me 13l. 7s. 10d. - I never sent him for that money; it had been due to me about two months; she lived in Hertfordshire; I never inquired of the prisoner respecting it; I wrote to Mrs. Thacker for the amount - the prisoner had left my employ about a fortnight before that; he never said any thing to me about this money - I settled all accounts with him at the time he left me.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You of course paid him all you owed him, and there was a balance struck? A. He owes me something now; he left a cage and two birds at my counting-house, and wished me to buy them for 12s., but I refused; I had a dispute with him, and discharged him, but he said he was in distress, and should feel obliged if I would give him a few days employ, and I sent him on messages; I cannot swear how long I kept him; at the time he brought the cage a captain was there who had paid him money which he had not handed to me, and I told him to leave the counting-house and never come again; I do not think he remained with me a single day after that - a gentleman once gave him an old sofa for his attention to him at the docks; I cannot now recollect whether that ever came into my possession, so many things pass in the course of a twelvemonth - if I did, I gave it to one of the men, at the docks - but it is a trifling circumstance, and I cannot say whether I had it or not; I only say, if it was given to the prisoner, it was given away again to some of the men, and I must have given him a compensation for it; I have had many such things in my possession; I do recollect something about one, but what it was I do not know; it was not worth 5s. - it was an Indian couch, they are sold at 10s. new; I remember one was given to him, but whether I ever had it I cannot say; I did not authorise him to receive money generally, but I have sent him for money, and if any was brought to the counting-house he received it; I cannot say whether I told the Magistrate he was not authorised; he did receive small sums such as 1l. or 2l.; I know Captain Liddel , he was not on board the Wellington; I have a hundred small accounts, and cannot recollect them all; I have no recollection of desiring him to borrow money on my account for dock charges - but it is common with us, if we want to ship goods in a hurry, to borrow money till the morning to pay the dock charges.
COURT. Q. Did the prisoner ever demand any thing as due by you to him? A.Never; I made this charge about a week or a fortnight after he left.

MARY ANN
WEBBER. I live at No. 48, Chiswell-street, Finsbury. I carried a letter, containing money, to the prisoner; the letter appeared to me to contain money - I felt money in it: I staid while it was opened; it was from Mrs. Thacker, directed to Mr. Taylor - I took it to the East India Chambers, Leadenhall-street, which was Mr. Taylor's counting-house; I delivered the letter to the prisoner, and was in the counting-house when it was opened: I did not positively see him open it- I said I had brought that letter for Mr. Taylor, and I was to take a receipt back for it; he said Mr. Taylor was not there, but my paying it to him would be quite right, the same as if I paid it to Mr. Taylor - he gave me a stamped receipt; I brought it home, and gave it to the lady who gave me the letter - she was in town then; it was Mrs. Thacker's mother; I never read it myself; I did not know what the sum was - I am sure I gave Mrs. Thacker's mother the same paper I received from the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. He might have passed off as Mr. Taylor to you, if he had chosen? A. yes; I felt something like money in the letter and heard it jink - I knew it was money; I am sure he is the person to whom I gave it, and who gave me the receipt.

JANE MANSON. I am Mrs. Thacker's mother. I myself brought the money down to my daughter to put into the letter; I do not know whether I saw her put it in -I was in the room when she wrote the letter; I brought it to London, delivered it to Webber, and told her to take it to the East India chambers, Leadenhall-street -I know it contained money; Webber took it out, returned, and gave me a paper, which Mr. Taylor has got(looking at it); this is the man's receipt for it - I am certain it is the paper Webber brought me (read).
August 1, 1828. Received of Mrs. Thacker the sum of 13l. 7s. 10d. amount of bill delivered for H. Taylor.
CHARLES CALLAN.
MR. TAYLOR. The whole of this receipt is the prisoner's hand-writing; he never accounted to me for this sum - I never knew it had been in his possession till this was discovered.

GORDON CLARK
. I am a watchman of St. James' parish. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Shelton's office - I know the prisoner; he is the person described therein (reads) - I was present when he pleaded guilty to the charge, and am sure he is the person.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that his salary was 1l. a week, but he at times received but 5s. which was an inducement to commit crime; that he had been in possession of the prosecutor's monies for a considerable time, but always accounted for them when called upon to do so; that he had not taken money with the intention of embezzlement, for a sum wasdue to him as salary, and that the prosecutor had offered to drop the prosecution for 35l.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Fourteen years .

1210.
JAMES SWEENEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 1 poker drawing, in a frame, value 21s. , the goods of
Charles Sweet
and another.

CHARLES SWEET
. I lived at No. 38, Chancery-lane
- I have one partner, and am a looking-glass manufacturer . This poker drawing was in my window; I was not up when it was taken - my house is in the City.

JOHN LEACH. I am in the employ of Mr. Sweet. On the 8th of May, in the morning, this drawing was in the window, which was closed; the shop door was open; I was opening the shop, and just as I took the shutter in I saw the prisoner come in and take the picture; he went out with it; I went after him directly - I lost sight of him and overtook him in Fetter-lane with it, under his arm - I met a gentleman, and got him to lay hold of him, which he did; I took the picture; he said nothing.
THOMAS LIGHFTOOT. I am a constable. I received him in charge about eight o'clock in the morning.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. A lad came up, and asked me to carry it; he ran away when the gentleman came up.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .
NEW COURT, Fifth Day.
First Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1211.
THOMAS PAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 61 handkerchiefs, value 8l. , the goods of
William Venables
and
Thomas Venables
, his masters.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1212.
JOHN ROBERTSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 saw, value 3s. , the goods of
James Predex
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 37.
Confined Three Months .

1213.
WILLIAM MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 cart spring, value 15s. the goods of
Thomas Trevillion
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 44.
Confined Two Months .

1214.
JOHN KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of November , 7 pewter pots, value 6s. ,the goods of
John Edward Clare
.

No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1215.
THOMAS COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , 1 gown, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Pink
.

MARY PINK. I am the wife of Thomas Pink; we live in Queen-street, Edgware-road
. On the 24th of April I fastened my shop door, and went down stairs for a few minutes: I heard a noise, and when I went up I found the door open, and this dress gone - I went to the door, saw a crowd, and in a few minutes it was brought back.

JAMES FRANES
. I was standing at my door, between five and six o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoner and two other boys come into the street - the prisoner went into the prosecutor's shop, and walked about; a little boy then went and took the dress, and gave it to another, who ran off with it - I went up to the shop, and secured the prisoner coming out at the door.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

1216.
FLORENCE CRAWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , 3 shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
John Howard
.

WILLIAM VANDEVELDE
. I am in the employ of John Howard, shoemaker , of St. Martin's-court
. On the 14th of May the prisoner came in, and stole three shoes; I was in the shop, saw him take them from inside the door, and run away - I pursued, and brought him back with them in his hand.
WILLIAM RAYNER. I am an officer, and have the shoes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I wish it had been his life I had taken.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Judgment Respited .

1217.
ANN DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of March , 1 shawl, value 10s., the goods of
Mary Ann Connolly
, and 1 sovereign , the money of
Charlotte Bennett
.

MARY ANN CONNOLLY
. I am single , and live in Broad-court, Bow-street
; my landlady's sister hired the prisoner as a servant . I had been out one evening in March, and left my shawl on the sofa, when I went to tea, between six and seven o'clock; I afterwards missed that, and some other things - this is the shawl.

MARY ANN INGRAV
. I live at No. 13, West-street - the prisoner came to lodge there just before Good Friday. On Good Friday my sister came and asked me to go and help her wash; the prisoner was present, and began crying; I asked what she was crying for; she made no answer - I asked her if she would go with me; she said Yes, if I would lend her my shawl, and take hers, which I did; we went on to Drury-lane, and met a witness, who came up, and wanted to take the shawl off my shoulders, but I would not let her: she asked if I would go with her; I said Yes: and when I got there, I found the prisoner in the kitchen, accused of the robbery - she did not say any thing.

CHARLOTTE BENNETT
. I live in Broad-court. I remember the evening when the shawl was lost; I missed a sovereign the next morning, which had been in the same room as the shawl - it was locked in a work-box, but the key was in it; I had seen it the night before the prisoner left.

SAMUEL STEVENS
. I took the prisoner. I asked her what she had done with some other things which were missed; she said she had pawned them, but could not recollect where; this shawl was given me in the house - she said she bad spent the sovereign, but did not say how she got it.

ANN HINSLEY
. I am the wife of
George Hinsley
- my sister is landlady of the house in Broad-court. I know this shawl; Mrs. Connolly gave my sister 1l. 15s. for it - on Good Friday morning I met the prisoner, and took her home, and soon after I met Ingray, with the shawl on her back; the prisoner said, "For God's sake don't take me home" - she said she bought victuals with the sovereign.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1218.
GEORE FENSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 11 pieces of printed cotton, containing 100 yards, value 3l. , the goods of
Henry Benjamin
and another.

HENRY BENJAMIN
. I am a linen-draper , and live in Edgware-road
- I carry on business with my father. On the 10th of June a person called me from up stairs, and said that a parcel was gone from the door; I went down and missed it - I followed the prisoner, who was then out of sight; I came up with him at the distance of two or three streets; he had turned some corners, and had thrown the cotton down - a person gave it me; I had seen it safe a few minutes before.

JOSEPH DRAKE
. I am a glazier, and live in the Edgware-road. On the 10the of June I saw my next door neighbour run to the prosecutor's door; I saw the prisoner running down Chapel-street with a bundle - I pursued him, he turned two corners, and was near two hundred yards from the prosecutor's when he dropped the bundle, I pursued him into a court and took him - I am certain he is the person I saw carrying the bundle - it was not taken up till I brought him back to the place where it had been dropped, and I took it up - he had been running very fast.

JACOB STEVENS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry the bundle - he put it into my hand; I went on to the end of the street, and heard the cry of stop thief! I threw it down and ran - the man was then gone.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1219.
WILLIAM TOMKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 handkerchief, value, 3s., the goods of
Charles Caswall
, from his person .

CHARLES CASWALL
. On the 13th of June I was in Holborn
, between twelve and one o'clock in the day; I felt somebody at my pocket, turned, and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand.

ANDREW NELSON
RUDDUCK. I was walking with Caswall; I saw the handkerchief in the prisoner's hand.

THOMAS MITCHELL
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner. I found nothing on him; I have inquired, and believe he is only a cat's paw in other people's hands.
Prisoner. It is the first time I was ever in such a situation - I hope you will take it into consideration.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1220.
WILLIAM GORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of May , 1 plane, value 1s., and 1 spoke-shave, value 1s. , the goods of
James Mclntosh
.

JAMES MCINTOSH. I am a carpenter . I had been working with these tools the day before they were missed; I had gone out at four o'clock to look for a better job - I know this plane and spoke-shave to be mine.

JOHN WHITE
. I am a watchman. On the 9th of May, about a quarter before five o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner on my beat nearly a mile from the prosecutor's - I saw something bulky in his bosom, and asked what he had got; he refused to tell me - I opened his waistcoat, and found this bag and tools; he tried to get away, but I took him to the watch-house.
Prisoner. I told him where I got the tools from. Witness. No; he told the watch-house-keeper that he got them from Mr. McIntosh to grind.

JAMES MCINTOSH. I did not send him - he had lodged in my house before, but not then; I never gave him leave to take them; he came to me, and said he had no money to pay for a lodging, and I told him to go and lie down in the kitchen, but not to come to me any more.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1221.
SAMUEL HILL
and
WILLIAM WISE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 4 pewter-pots, value 8s. , the goods of
Edward Thomas Jury
.

EDWARD THOMAS
JURY. I am a publican , and live in High-street, Wapping. About eleven o'clock in the morning, on the 1st of June, I was at the workhouse - I was sent for home, and told that four pots had been found in a dust cart, and I found the two prisoners with a dust cart; I asked where they got the pots - they said they would show me, and took me up to a dust-hole on the first floor of a house which I supply with beer; I took their shoved, and turned the dust over in the dust-hole, but I found no pots there; I had sent beer to the house, and could not get the pots returned.

CHARLES COX
. I have been a publican. I saw the prisoners with the dust cart on the first of June; I had information that there were some pots in the cart - I thought they might he some of mine; I got into the cart, and insisted upon their turning the dust over; I found these four pint posts altogether in one corner under the dust - they did not say any thing.
HILL'S Defence. We found the pots in the dust-hole; it was dark, and we could hardly see what there was; when I was called down I came and found the pots in the cart.
WISE'S Defence. I brought down the dust, but did not see any thing in it.

HILL -
GUILTY . Aged 53.

WISE -
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined Two Months .

1222.
THOMAS HOLLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 8 pairs of stockings, value 8s. , the goods of
Benjamin Bate
.

SARAH SMART
. I am Mr.
Benjamin Bate
's niece. I was on a visit there on the day this happened; I did not see the stockings taken, but I was called to the door and saw them, and know them to be my uncle's - they had been in the window that afternoon; I had only turned my back about ten minutes and they were gone - they were tied with a string.

WILLIAM BILES
. I am a salesman, and live nearlyopposite to the prosecutor. I saw the prisoner go to the door and then go away again - soon afterwards I saw him go and put his arm round the door-post and take the stockings; I took him immediately, without losing sight of him; two or three persons took hold of him - he tried to escape.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1223.
THOMAS JEFFERYS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , 24lbs. weight of beef, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Mendy
.

THOMAS MENDY
. I am a butcher , and live in Brick-lane
. On the 24th of April I saw the prisoner take this beef from my counter, as I was in the adjoining room to my shop - he threw a handkerchief over it, and ran away with it; I pursued and overtook him - when he saw me, he threw it down and ran away.

JOSEPH DYSON
. I stopped the prisoner about threehundred yards from the spot; a young man came up and said he had stolen a piece of beef - I took him back to Mr. Mendy.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character, and one of them engaged to employ him.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1224.
PETER JORDAN
and
CHARLES BESSANT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 carpet bag, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Lane
and
Allen Billing
.

GEORGE JUDGE. On the 1st of June, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was standing near Waterloo-bridge - I saw the two prisoners follow a gentleman, and then they passed on, and went to the prosecutors' shop; Jordan made an attempt to take a trunk, which he could not do - they then turned back and went to the shop again; I lost sight of them for about two minutes - we then crossed the way and went on to Somerset-house, looked down a turning, and saw them tying up something in a handkerchief; they came up, and I took Jordan, who had this bag under his left arm - Bessant ran off, and Fogg took him.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not see them take the bag? A. No; I saw them attempting a gentleman's pocket before - they then went and tried another gentleman's pocket; I was on the other-side of the way.

THOMAS FOGG. I was with Judge in the Strand. I saw the prisoners together for about an hour; I know the prosecutors' shop - I saw Jordan stand against it, and Bessant was opposite; I then saw them going towards the Strand - Jordan had something under his arm; they went down a turning which leads to the Adelphi - we came up to them, and Judge took this bag from Bessant.

JOHN BRODERICK
. I am shopman to Thomas Lane and
Allen Billing
, trunk-makers. This is their bag; I did not miss it till the next morning - I had seen it safe at eight o'clock in the evening; I left at nine o'clock - the officer came after I was gone; we had only one of this pattern.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there a private mark on it? A. No; I know it by hanging it up so often - it is not an uncommon pattern; the workmanship makes me positive it is the same - they are made by women; the handle of this is worn away by hanging it up so many times - I was thinking I should clean it up; it is what we call a halfyard bag, the next size would be a half-ell - our shop is very long.

JORDAN'S Defence. I was passing the Strand on the 1st of June, and met a person I knew, who had this bundle - we went and had a pint of beer; he asked me to hold the bundle while he went on one side, and the officer came and took me; I never saw this prisoner before.

JORDAN -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

BESSANT -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

1225,
ROBERT MURRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
Richard Richardson
.

RICHARD RICHARDSON. On the 7th of May I lost a handkerchief, as I was at the back of the Islington stage; it had been in my inside coat pocket - I did not miss it till I got home; I know I had it when I was at the Royal Exchange, at four o'clock - I afterwards saw it in the possession of the officer.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE ANTHONY
. On the afternoon of the 7th of May, I saw the Islington stage go by - the prisoner was behind it; he put his hand into the gentleman's pocket and took out this handkerchief - I went and took it from him and gave it to Mr. Powell, who put it into his pocket, and went to get the officer; I know this to be the handkerchief.

THOMAS COPE
. I took the prisoner. This handkerchief was given me by Mr. Powell - the prisoner told me he had been drawing the handkerchief, and this other handkerchief was bound round his arm; he said it was a hard case that he should be taken alone, for Charley Purley was with him - and as we were going along the fields he said" There's
Charley Purley
;" I went and took him, but he was discharge.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1226.
CORNELIUS MAHONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of May , 4 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 8 sixpences , the monies of
Luke Brunton
.

LUKE BRUNTON. I am a shoemaker , and live in York-street, Saffron-hill
. On the morning of the 11th of May I went to settle with the prisoner and another of my men - there was only 1s. coming to him - I then went to my clothes in my box, and went away leaving the prisoner in the room - I had left my money in the box on the Saturday night, and when I went out that day, I left the key of the box on the bed - before I returned, word was sent after me that the money was gone; I came home and missed four half-crowns, some shillings, and sixpences - the prisoner had seen the box - it was where I kept my clothes - I was advised to go to Mr. Spooner, who told me to go in quest of the prisoner - I found him in a public-house intoxicated: I sent for an officer, who took him - I then went to Mr. Phillips, and then to a baker's where he had left part of the money - he had left his own old hat at Mr. Phillips; this is it.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. How any people had you in your employ? A. Only two. The box was not in a private room, it is where I work, and where the prisoner slept - he had a wife, but she had not lived with him for three weeks.

PATRICK BURK. I lodge at the prosecutor's. On the 11th of May, I was going up to my bed-room, and saw his door open, about eleven o'clock, and the prisoner with his keys in his hand, locking or unlocking the box.
Cross- examined. Q. Did you say before the Magistrate that he had the keys in his hand? A. Yes; I did not see him take any thing out.

JOHN SPOONER. I keep a chandler's-shop on Saffronhill. On the 11th of May, between eleven and twelve o'clock the prisoner came and asked me to give him a sovereign for a sovereign's worth of silver - he had three or four half-crowns in his hand - I said I had not any gold.

ALEXANDER PHILLIPS
. I sell hats on Saffron-hill. On the 11th of May, the prisoner came about twelve in the morning, and purchased a hat for 3s. 6d. - he paid for it with a half-crown and a shilling - he pulled out a bit of paper, and I saw a sovereign in it - he said he had been going to throw it away to light his pipe with - I advised him, as he was in liquor, to get it changed into silver. as then, if he lost part of it, he might not lose it all - I gave him eight half-crowns for it - he went away, and left his old hat, which the prosecutor had the next day.

ANN MARIA
BAYLIS. I am a baker on Saffron-hill. On the 11th of May, about four o'clock, the prisoner came into my shop, and asked for a pennyworth of bread, and then asked me for change for a sovereign, which I gave him - he left me 15s. to keep for him till he called - I had seen him two or three times - he did not appear very tipsy.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I took the prisoner, and received this money.

LUKE BRUNTON
. This is the prisoner's old hat - there were no sovereigns in my box - there were four half-crowns and the rest in small silver - there was 1l. 10s. or 1l. 18s. in all.
JURY. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of putting money into your box for you to keep for him? A. No; I forgot the keys that day.
GUILTY . Aged 51.
Confined One Month .

1227.
BRYAN MALONY
was indicted for
stealing, in the 14th of May , 1 plane, value 2s., and 1 jacket, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Stevens
; 1 axe, value 1s. 6d.; 1 hammer, value 6d., and 1 apron, value 6d., the goods of
George Healman
; and 1 plane, value 2s. , the goods of
William Waugh White
.

WILLIAM STEVENS
. I am a carpenter . I was working in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square
; I left my tools there on the evening of the 14th of May, and when I went next morning I missed a plane and a jacket.

GEORGE HEALMAN
. I was working at the same place. I missed an axe, a hammer, and an apron; I know nothing of the prisoner.
WILLIAM WAUGH WHITE. I missed a jack-plane from the same place.

THOMAS WALLACE
. I am an officer. At half-past seven o'clock on the evening of the 14th of May, I saw the prisoner and two other men in Rathbone-place; the prisoner went on to Charlotte-street - I saw two of the workmen come out of No. 1; he followed them some distance, then returned, went into the house, and came out again with these tools - I took him, and asked if they were his own; he said they were; I then asked if he worked there- he said he should answer no more questions.

Prisoner's Defence. I met two men, who asked if I would go over the way and get some tools; I asked if there was any danger of my getting into trouble - they said No, but they had been having some words with their master, and did not like to go; I said I was going to take them to those two young men - the officer saw them, but he did not take them.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined One Month .

1228.
CATHERINE RAGEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 4 pairs of trousers, value 48s.; 20 pairs of shoes, value 35s., and 2 brooches, value 30s. , the goods of
William Newby
.

WILLIAM WILCOX. I am in the employ of William Newby, a pawnbroker , of Drury-lane
. On the 11th of April these things were safe, between nine and ten o'clock- I did not miss them till the next morning, when I received information; the prisoner has been a customer.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.You did not see her there that day? A. No - she has a family.

FREDERICK PRIEST
. I am in the employ of Mr. Bassett. I have a pair of trousers, pawned by the prisoner, on the 11th of April, for 8s.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know her? A. Yes - she did not tell me they were not her own.
CHARLES MAYO. I took charge of the prisoner; her husband came and gave the shoes into my hand, and insisted upon my going to his room, and taking charge of her.
Cross-examined. Q. Is her husband here? A. Not that I know of - he laid all the blame on her.

DANIEL HALL
. I received two gold brooches from the prisoner's husband; I found this duplicate of the trousers where the prisoner had been standing, in the watch-house.

WILLIAM WILCOX
. This is one of our pairs of trousers.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see her husband? A. I have seen him twice.

COURT. Q. Did you see him on the 11th of April? A. No, the following morning; I saw the prisoner on the 11th of April, just as I was leaving the shop at night - these things were all taken between nine and twelve o'clock- we lost twenty-five pairs of shoes at least; they all laid in one corner of the window - the bar was taken down.

Cross-examined. Q. Were not the shoes separate? A. Yes; they might have been taken at different times, or a person might have swept them off altogether - I saw her come into the shop after eleven o'clock.

CHARLES MAYO. I saw the prisoner's husband last night, and told him the trial would come on, and very likely he would be wanted; I believe they had a little quarrel - he is much given to drinking, and had beendrinking that night: the prisoner has one child at the breast, and has two more.
GUILTY of stealing the trousers . Aged 24.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1229.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 hat, value 10s. , the goods of
Marshall Hall
.

BENJAMIN SAGE
. I am in the service of Dr. Marshall Hall, of Keppell-street, Russell-square
. On the 26th of May I saw this hat safe on the table in the hall, about eight o'clock in the morning, and it was gone in about half an hour - I know nothing of the prisoner.

JAMES WHITE
. I saw the prisoner take the hat from Dr. Hall's; he went in without one, and came out with a hat in his hand, in about three minutes - I told the cook, and in half an hour I saw an officer, and told him.

WILLIAM CORDWELL
. I am a pawnbroker. This hat was pawned at my house by the prisoner, on the 26th of May - I gave this duplicate for it.
ALPHONSO DALLERY. I am an officer. I received information, and took the prisoner in the skittle-ground of the Brittania public-house, Battle-bridge; I found this duplicate in his fob pocket.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1230.
ELIZABETH WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of May , 1 tea-caddy, value 8s., and 16 spoons, value 6s. 6d. , the goods of
John Perkins
.

JOHN PERKINS
. I am a baker , and live in Chequer-alley, Bunhill-row
. On the 2d of May, about five o'clock, I lost a tea-caddy from my bed-room, and six spoons; I had seen them safe about three o'clock; I did not see the prisoner - this is my caddy and spoons.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know a woman named Smith, who came to your house to see some one? A. Yes; I have made inquiries about the prisoner, and I have heard a very good character of her, and that her state of mind is such as to render her a very easy dupe to any person.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES
. I am shopman to Mr. Clark, a pawnbroker. On Saturday evening, the 2d of May, the prisoner pawned this caddy, and then the spoons.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you observe any woman outside? A. No; she came with the caddy first, and asked 8s. - then brought the spoons, and asked for as much as I could give her, as she wanted to make up her rent; she gave her name and address - I knew her before.

JOHN CLARK
. I took the prisoner up, and found this duplicate on her.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to Mr. Cotterell's, at the top of that house, for an umbrella - I stopped some time with him, and when I came down I saw a woman in the passage; she followed me out, and asked if I lodged at Mr. Burton's - I said No: she asked me to go and get 20s. for these spoons - I went and asked them, and they said they would chop them up before my face - she then asked me to go to another shop, and I went to Mr. Clark's, where I was known; I pawned the caddy first, and then the spoons.
JOHN CLARK. Mr. Brooks told me that a woman had been there to pawn some spoons, on which she asked 20s., and she would be there again to take something out.
NOT GUILTY .

1231.
WILLIAM PAGE
and
JOHN PAGE
were indicted for
that they, on the 8th of June , 49 handkerchiefs, value 5l., the goods of
William Venables
and
Thomas Venables
, feloniously did receive, of a certain evil-disposed person, which had been lately before stolen, they well knowing the same; against the Statute, &c.

RICHARD VENABLES
. I am brother to William and Thomas Venables, who are in partnership; Thomas Page, the prisoners' brother, was in their service - he pleaded guilty this morning to stealing these things. On the morning he was committed, I applied to Sir George Farrant for a warrant to search the prisoners' house, No. 2, Windsorplace, and in a hat-box, which
John Page
acknowledged to be his. I found twenty-six silk handkerchiefs, and seventeen in William Page's box; John said they had been given to him by Thomas, to keep and to sell - William was out at the time; when he came home we took him: he said he had bought them of his brother Thomas; he had given 1s. a piece for some, 1s. 6d. for others, and 2s. was the utmost price he had given; he said he had been in the silk business, and he considered he had given the utmost price - they have our marks on them.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. For ought you know, Thomas may have brought them there for them to sell? A.Certainly; I got all the handkerchiefs I could find.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. I went to the prisoners' residence, and found John at home; I found the handkerchiefs in the boxes; some of them John said had been given to them to sell, and some they had bought: when William came home he said he gave 1s. 6d. or 2s. a piece for them - they live in Hoxton; Messrs. Venables' shop is in Oxford-street; William keeps a butcher's-shop, and I believe John is his servant.

WILLIAM PAGE
'S Defence. My brother brought the handkerchiefs to me, and said he bought them of Mr. Venables - that they were selling off a bankrupt's stock at one third of its value; he said he would bring a few more if I wished it: I said I had no objection, and he brought some more.

RICHARD VENABLES
. We were selling off cheap, but not at the price he speaks of.

WILLIAM PAGE -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

JOHN PAGE
-
NOT GUILTY

1232.
WILLIAM LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 1 iron pot, value 5s. , the goods of
James Anderson
.

JAMES ANDERSON
. I am a furnishing ironmonger , and live in Wardour-street
. I lost an iron pot on the 1st of May, from inside my shop; the prisoner was brought in with it.

CHARLES WILLIAM GREEN
. I saw the prisoner walking about the prosecutor's premises; I went into my own house, and soon after saw him coming up the street with this pot - I stopped him, and took it from him; he said it was his own - he had another person with him.
Prisoner. Q. Did I say it was my own? A. Yes; after I locked you up, you said the other young man told you to hold it - you had it covered with this apron.
Prisoner's Defence. It was not my apron; I was walking down the street, and a young man told me to hold it while he went into St. Anne's-court.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined Four Months .

1233.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 2 live tame fowls, price 8s. , the property of
William Cresshull
.

WILLIAM CRESSHULL
. I live at Stepney
, and keep fowls : I had five hens and a cock on the 6th of June; I saw them all alive and well that night - the next morning I got up at half-past five o'clock, and saw a number of feathers on the ground, near an old pig-stye, which we use as a hen-roost; I found the cock dead, and all the hens were missing - I found one hen had run into a dogkennel with its wing cut; a neighbour said he had taken the man to the watch-house - I went there, and saw two fowls, which I knew to be mine.

THOMAS CALLOWAY
. I am a watchman of Whitechapel. I was on duty on Sunday morning, at a quarter-past two o'clock, in Bath-street; I saw the prisoner with something in his apron; I asked what he had there - he shammed intoxication; he said he had two fowls which he bought last night for 1s. 6d., that he had been drinking with some of his shopmates, and had staid till that time; I took him to the watch-house, and Mr. Cresshull identified the fowls - he produced the cock before the Magistrate, which matched the hens; they are a black Spanish breed - he described them before he saw them.

Prisoner's Defence. The watchman asked what I had got there; I said,"Two fowls;" he said,"Did you nail them?" (that is steal them) I said,"No, I bought them in Ratcliff-highway for 1sd;" he said "If you will give me 5s., I will let you go:" I said No, 5s. was not to he parted with in that way, for I had bought them at the Eight Bells public-house.

THOMAS CALLOWAY
. I never said any thing of the kind.

WILLIAM CRESSHULL
. When they read the deposition he confessed that he did the robbery for want; he said they would not do anything for him in Whitechapel workhouse.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1234.
WILLIAM KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 5 yards of printed cotton, value 12s. , the goods of
David Lawrie
and another.

DAVID LAWRIE
. I am in partnership with Mr. Williamson; we are linen-drapers , and live at Albion-terrace, Old Brentford
; I have seen the prisoner before: our shop was entered on the evening of the 8th of June, about six o'clock - I was out at the time, and no person was there; I lost five yards of red printed cotton, which has not been found - I had seen it that morning.
Prisoner. He had been to London that day to summons me for a hat, and my wife nonsuited him. Witness. I was too late to answer to my name.

ANN JACKSON
. I go out to needle-work. On the 8th of June I was near the shop at Old Brentford; I saw the prisoner go to the shop - the door was shut; he opened it, and went in - he came out in about three minutes, with a piece of red print locked under his coat; he had nothing when he went in - he went straight up the lane, as if to go home; I told Mrs. Lawrie of it, and she sent the washerwoman, who watched him home; I could not see the pattern of the print, but it was red.
Prisoner. I had business there; I went and knocked at the door, to see if it was settled about the hat. Witness. No, he did not knock; I was opposite, with the baby in my arms.

Prisoner. I never stepped my foot in; I had this bundle under my arm which I have now, with some old shoes in it. Witness. I am quite certain he had nothing when he went in, and what he brought out was not this bundle - it was quite a flat bundle.

THOMAS REYNOLDS
. On the evening of the 8th of June, I saw the prisoner come down as I stood at the end of the lane, which is only one house from the shop; he went towards the prosecutor's shop - I took no further notice till about three or four minutes, when he returned with something tucked under the flap of his coat - it was of a red colour, but I did not see what it was; I think it was a larger bundle than the one he has now - it looked like a piece of print.

Prisoner's Defence. No one answered me at the door, and I went home; I had bought these shoes for a pint of beer, and I was ashamed of them as they were very bad -Mr. Lawrie came and said, "I have another summons for you, you shall not get off so;" I am as innocent as the Angels in Heaven.

DAVID LAWRIE
. This young woman's mother came and told me I had lost something; I went, and missed the print- the handkerchief he has that bundle in, was not the one he showed before the Magistrate; that was a yellow one,
ANN JACKSON. He shewed a different handkerchief before the Magistrate - that was a small light handkerchief, with pink flowers on it.

THOMAS REYNOLDS
. It was a different handkerchief he produced before the Magistrate; he said "This is the handkerchief the old shoes were tied up in," and he was ashamed to carry them along the street.

DAVID LAWRIE
. I went to his house, but did not find the cotton.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

1235.
MARY HARNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 2 pewter pots, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Williamson
; and 1 pewter pot, value 1s. the goods of
Joseph Tomsey
.

WILLIAM WILLIAMSON
. I am a publican
, and have lost a great many pots. I saw two of my post at High-street office on the 7th of June.
JOSEPH TOMSEY. I am a publican. I found one of my pots at the office.

THOMAS BLAKE
. I live in Westmoreland-street. On the 7th of June, at half-past eight o'clock, a person came and told my mistress the prisoner had taken some pots from the doors in the street - I followed her, and in Little Mary-lebone-street I asked her if she had taken a pot off therailing; she said she had not been in the street - I followed her on to Bulstrode-street; she there called another woman - I saw she had something in her apron before she spoke to that woman.

ISAAC HILL
. I was going along Welbeck-street, and this lad called me to follow the prisoner down to Old Cavendish-street, and on to Shepperd-street - I then went and asked what she had got; she gave me one pot of Mr. Tomsey's and said, "Let me go" - the boy said she had some more, and I found a quart and a pint pot of Mr. Williamson's in her apron.

Prisoner. I told you to stop the woman in the red cloak; she gave me them to hold. Witness. There was a woman in a red cloak who spoke to the prisoner, but I did not know where she was gone - I did not see the prisoner and the woman meet, but they were speaking together.
GUILTY . Aged 69.
Transported for Seven Years .

1236.
JOHN GLENNON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 1 pair of of breeches, value 5s. , the goods of
Martha Jones
, widow .

MARTHA BANCE COLLETT
. I went and got these breeches from the prisoner, on Thursday the 7th of May, at half-past nine o'clock in the morning: they were under a short jacket which he wore - I had heard of Mrs. Jones' loss.

SAMUEL CHERRY
. I am in the employ of Mr. Sexton, of Brentford; we live opposite to Mrs. Jones, who keeps a clothes-shop - I saw the prisoner take these breeches off her window, put them under his jacket, and go off.

JOHN JONES
. I am the son of
Martha Jones
; she is a widow . I placed these breeches on her window: they are her property.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1237.
JAMES GERRARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 blanket, value 4s. , the goods of
Francis Barton Hunter
.

MARY
ANN HUNTER
. I am the wife of
Francis Barton
Hunter. On the 1st of June, early in the morning, I missed a blanket from a spare bed at our house in Wapping
; the prisoner had lodged there the night before, and was the only lodger there - he was gone on board of a ship; I took this blanket out of his clothes-bag, which he takes to sea with him - it was in another room.

THOMAS JUDD
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was apprehended, and somebody took 2s. 2 1/2d. from my pocket

MARY ANN
HUNTER. I told him of it; he said if I would forgive him he would never do the like again - I found the stairs muddy on the 6th of June, as I was going up; I found some other blankets in his bag.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1238.
FRANCIS CURRY
,
ROBERT TILEY
,
ELIZA HILL
, and
ELIZABETH JOHNSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , certain fixtures, to wit; 1 kitchen range, value 7s., and 1 grate, value 10s., the goods of
Daniel Wooley
, then and there fixed to a certain building: against the Statute, &c.

DANIEL WOOLEY
. I live in Great George-street, Bethnal-green
. I lost my grate and range - I found the grate, but the range is gone; the grate had been fixed in the room up stairs.

HANNAH CLARKE
. I live next door to the prosecutor's house, which has been empty for some time. About half-past five o'clock in the morning of the 15th of April, I was awoke by a great noise in that house, like the breaking down of the stones of the fire-place - I heard the stove drawn out, and some persons go down stairs very heavy, and put something down in the passage; I looked out of the window, saw Curry open the door and come out, stand on the step, and look in my face; I said, "What do you want there, you thief, you shall not have the stove?" he said nothing, but kept looking at me; I said to my husband, "Father, come and look at him, that thief is looking me in the face:" Curry then left the step, turned, and made a trot round the corner of the Three Sugar Loaves public-house, and went away - I cried Stop thief! my husband went and found nobody in the house; he then pursued - I am sure Curry is the man.
Prisoner CURRY. What she states is very true; I put my foot on the step of the door to tie my shoe; I was not in the house. Witness. I saw him open the door, and come out.
THOMAS CLARKE. I heard the door open, looked out, and saw Curry - I did not see any of the others.

JOHN SMITH
. I am a weaver. I heard a cry of Stop thief! when I was in my own house; I opened the window, saw Curry run by, and Clarke running after him, about one hundred and fifty or two hundred yards from the prosecutor's house; a few minutes after six o'clock I saw Curry come home, and go into his own house; soon afterwards I saw Tiley go into the same house - shortly afterwards I saw Curry, Tiley, and Eliza Hill come out together, and go round the corner; I saw Johnson come out with something covered over with a cloth, and as she brought it along, the cloth flew aside, and I saw it was a flowered range.

THOMAS CLARKE
re-examined. Q.Where did you lose sight of Curry? A. In Fleet-street, about two hundred yards from the door he was first at.

MARY MARTIN
. I live at No. 1, Fleet-street. I was getting up, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I said to my husband, "I think I know the voice;" I went out, and met Mrs. Clarke, who told me a house had been broken open, and a range was gone; I afterwards saw Johnson bringing something out of that house; the cloth fell off, I saw it was a flowered range, a bar, and a trivet; she took it round the corner by the public-house - I saw Hill, Tiley and Curry, come out of the house - they put the range on Tiley's shoulder, and went away.

JOHN ARNOLD
. I am a corn-dealer. On the morning in question these two female witnesses came to my house, and said there had been a robbery; I went to Mr. Glibbery; we went down, waited about the street, and watched the two female prisoners enter a house in George-street, where they lived - in a few minutes they came out, and we stopped them near Spicer-street; on Johnson I found a glazier's diamond, on Hill a crow-bar, a packof cards, and some other things; in a little while we saw Tiley coming up the street to the same house; I received information, and took him to the watch-house - I went again, saw Curry passing, and took him to the watch-house.
JAMES GLIRBERY. I am an officer. I found on Curry a little tinder-box and matches.
HANNAH CLARKE. I had the care of this house; it was a small flowered kitchen range, with a drop bar, and one trivet to it.
CURRY'S Defence. The women know nothing about it.
TILEV'S Defence. I was going to this man's house; the officers came and laid hold of me - I know nothing about it.
HILL'S Defence. I went out to seek for work; not succeeding, I called at this house; I heard Johnson say she was going to sell that range, and she took it out.
JOHNSON'S Defence. I know nothing about it.
HANNAH CLARKE. The stove had been left in the passage, but the range has been carried away.

CURRY -
GUILTY . Aged 46.

TILEY -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

HILL -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .

1239.
MARY HEWITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 2 boxes, value 6s.; 3 pin-cushions, value 2s. 6d., and 1 memorandum-book, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Mary Goetze
.

MARY GOETZE
. I am single , and have a counter at the Royal Bazaar
. I lost the articles stated, from there about half-past three o'clock, on the 29th of May, when the fire broke out; when my other articles were brought home, I missed these.

MARY ANN
WATKINS. When the fire broke out, I went to assist in saving some of the property - I took some to my father's house, and left them there in the care of the prisoner, who lodged there; my father's is No. 52, Castle-street, East-street, Oxford-market; when my father came home, she gave up all but these into his possession - these articles were found at the pawnbroker's.

THOMAS DANDERS
PERRY. I am a pawnbroker. These articles were brought by the prisoner the day after the fire, about eleven o'clock in the morning - I had some suspicion, and stopped her till I sent for an officer.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. I took up the prsoner; she said she had them put into her possession for a little while, and she had taken them to make a little money of, through distress.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined One Month .

1240.
MICHAEL CONNOLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of April , 1 coat, value 20s. , the goods of
Lake Brunton
.

LUKE BRUNTON
. I lost a great coat on Easter Monday; I went out with a friend, and did not miss it till the Tuesday morning, when I went to put my clothes in the box - I had left it on my bed; the prisoner had been a lodger - I went in quest of him.
Prisoner. He took me out to drink with him, and we drank till one o'clock in the day. Witness. Yes, a friend took us out, and treated us both.

WILLIAM SMITH. I am a pawnbroker. On the 20th of April, about one o'clock, this coat was pawned with me by the prisoner; I asked if it was his own; he said Yes, that his name was John Mooney, and he lived in Cow-cross- I asked him how he came to Islington to pawn it; he said he worked in the Pied Bull fields.
WILLIAM CLARK. I took the prisoner. He was in liquor - he said he had pawned the coat.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Seven Days .

1241.
SARAH REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , 12 dozen of buttons, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Wyld
.

JOHN WYLD
. I am a haberdasher, and live in Rathbone-place
. The prisoner came to my shop on the 15th of April, to purchase some buttons - I showed her a drawer - there were four cards on the top - she bought four dozen, and gave me half a sovereign to change - I put away the drawer, and missed one card of buttons -I then said "You must come back, you have taken a gross of buttons" - I took her back - she denied it - I sent my boy for an officer - she then gave me these buttons and said she was very sorry.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1242.
WILLIAM PENDRICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of November , 1 male ass, price 10s. , the property of
John Herridge
.

JOHN HERRIDGE. had a male ass which I turned out in Mr. William Hammond's meadow - it was taken from there the latter end of November, or the beginning of December - I never saw it again till May, when I saw it tied to some palings at the prisoner's place, in Fulhamfields - I said it was mine, and asked him for it - he said it was not mine; I went and got a constable - I allowed the prisoner to keep it that Saturday, and then he was to give it up.
WILLIAM HAMMOND. The donkey was in my field - I cannot say when it was missed; the prisoner lived in our neighbourhood.
CHARLOTTE HAMMOND, I know the ass by its being into our meadow, and by its colour.

WILLIAM GUMM
. I saw the ass at Hamersmith, in November last, with its ears fresh cut, in the possession of John Harris, between seven and nine o'clock in the evening - it was offered for sale at 25s.
JOHN HERRIDGE. Its ears were cut after it was stolen from me - the prisoner lives at Hillingdon - he said he bought it.
NOT GUILTY .

1243.
ANN HALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April , 2 gowns, value 1s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 6d.; 2 caps, value 6d.; 1 blanket, value 6d., and 1 sheet, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Cowen
.

THOMAS COWEN
. I am a tailor , and live in Museum-street
. I went into my kitchen on the night of the 17th of April - I found the prisoner there almost naked in the act of putting some clothes on - I got a light, and asked what she wanted there, and whether she had been employed by Mrs. Smith - she said Yes - I was going to leave, thinking it might be so; but I returned and asked if she had been washing; she said Yes; I went and asked Mrs. Smith to come down with me, and they both came down - Mr. Smith asked, what she wanted there - she said a man brought her there - I asked her how she came to be undressed; she said he made her undress - I saw two bed-gowns, a handkerchief, and a cap, on the table; I said "We must make search for this man" - she said,"You need not look, he is not here" - I still looked; she then said, "There has been no man here" - the things were lying together on the table.
JOHN RIERDON. I went to the house and took the prisoner - she told me she took these things from Mr. Cowen's room, and she was in the habit of taking such things when she was drunk.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

1244.
JOHN GOMEZ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 2 sheets, value 3s. , the goods of
John Goss
.

ANN GOSS. I am the wife of John Goss. On the 1st of May, we lost a pair of sheets from the room which the prisoner occupied - I had let it him on the Friday - he told me on the Sunday, that his wife had run away - I asked, what made her run away; he said he did not know -I said, "Let me see if my property is all right, and you had better go too." I took down the bed, and the sheets were gone - he said the bed had never been lain on.

WILLIAM ALEXANDER
. I took the prisoner, and he gave up this duplicate.

JOHN BUTTON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Battlebridge. I have two sheets; one I received myself from the prisoner, on the 2d of May; the other I did not take in.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I have only been four months in this country - I only received 10s. a fortnight from the Society for the Support of the Spanish Refugees; it was not quite sufficient, and I pawned these sheets from distress, intending to get them out again - the landlady missed them - I told her if she was not satisfied, I would leave her a coat or something not to make a disturbance - she kept a house of ill-fame, and would listen to no reason - my character may be heard from Mr. Freshfield, the Secretary to the Spanish Refugees.
GUILTY . Aged 25.

1245.
WILLIAM CLANCEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of May , 1 fender, value 7s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Brooke
.

THEODORE BROOKE
. I am the son of
Elizabeth Brooke
, of High Holborn
: she keeps an iron and tin-plate warehouse . I saw the fender about the middle of the day.

JOHN LEWIS
. I saw the prisoner take the fender on the 19th of May - he ran away; I gave an alarm, he dropped it, and I took it up; I saw him again in about five minutes, and am certain he is the person - I knew nothing of him before.
GEORGE FORDYCE. I heard Stop thief! called, and saw the prisoner running, at twenty minutes before ten o'clock in the evening, and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was ill with the typhus fever, and was forced to go into the infirmary, and then my father, mother, and sister all caught it - I was not able to go to work; I beg for mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1246.
MARY ANN BISHOP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , 1 shawl, value 6s., the goods of
Frances Conner
, from her person .

FRANCES CONNER. I am a widow . On the 6th of May I was in Goswell-street
; I met a young man very much intoxicated, and I stopped to pursuade him to go home, because I knew he had money in his pocket; he knocked me down, and while I was down the shawl was dragged from under me - it was about eleven o'clock at night - I do not know who took it - I did not see the prisoner till I got to the watch-house; she then appeared to be in liquor.

CAROLINE JOHNSON. I saw the witness with a young man; I did not see him strike her, but I saw her on the ground - the prisoner came to me and asked me to hold her shawl while she put on the witness' shawl; I did not take it, but it fell down before me - she then took up her own shawl and put it on, and then put on the prosecutrix's shawl over her own.

Prisoner. She is an unfortunate girl like myself; she said "There is a row;" I went and found this woman on the ground; she took off her shawl and gave it me. Witness. No; I know nothing of her since she lived in service where I did.

DANIEL PAINTER. I am a watchman. I did not see what passed, but Johnson gave me some information, and I took this shawl from the prisoner in Golden-lane - I saw the prosecutrix the same night; she appeared quite sober.

THOMAS TOOL
. I was putting up the shutters, five or six doors from the place - I saw the row and went up; I saw the prisoner take the shawl when the lady was on the ground - I met Painter, and told him of it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1247.
WILLIAM KEEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 necklace, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Hollingsworth
, from the person of
Mary Ann Hollingsworth
.

THOMAS HOBBS. I am a carpenter. On the 26th of May I saw Mary Sheriff in the street, with a child in her arms - I saw the prisoner go up to the child, and then snap the beads; he drew them off the child's neck, and put them in the waistband of his trousers - I went over, clasped his two arms, and shook them out of the legs of his trousers; there was another person with him about his own size, but he went away.

MARY SHERIFF. I was in the street, with Mr.
Thomas Hollingsworth
's little girl, named Mary
Ann Hollingsworth
- she had a necklace on; I did not see the witness till he told me he had the necklace - he shewed me the necklace at the watch-house; I looked, and it was gone from the child's neck.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked them up in Goswell-street, and put them in my trousers; I had no pocket.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

1248.
WILLIAM JONES
and
TIMOTHY MORAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
William More
, from his person .

WILLIAM MORE. On the 28th of April, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, I was coming down St. Giles'
, Rierdon told me my handkerchief was gone - I saw it again in McGregor's hand; I had not seen the prisoner before.

DANIEL RIERDON. I was coming from our office - I saw the prisoner and three others standing on the curb - the prosecutor came by, and one of them, not now in custody, took up his coat, took out his handkerchief, and gave it to Jones, who ran off, and I took him; Moran was with them, and was close to the prosecutor at the time he was taken - he ran away likewise.
Prisoner JONES. The boy threw down the handkerchief at my feet; I did not run. Witness. Yes he did, to the end of Monmouth-street.

WILLIAM MCGREGOR
. I saw Moran in company with Jones and three others - I did not see Moran do any thing, but he ran to try to take up the handkerchief; I took him and the handkerchief - the prosecutor had got some distance before we could overtake him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
JONES' Defence. I had nothing to do with the handkerchief.

MORAN'S Defence. I was coming from my master's and met this boy, who was a school-fellow - we saw three boys take the handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and then the officer took hold of one person, and let him go, he then laid hold of me.
Jones received a good character.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

MORAN -
NOT GUILTY .

1249.
THOMAS WRIGHT
&
RICHARD FARRELL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Morris
, from his person .

JOSEPH CARROLL
. I was with Robert Morris on the 7th of June, about half-past twelve o'clock at night - the two prisoners were passing by; Wright took the handkerchief from Morris' pocket - Morris gave a jump, and said,"My handkerchief is gone;" I ran after them to the corner of Compton-street - I saw no watchman; they then turned, and run down a street - I and a friend ran after them - they crossed Frith-street; I saw three watchmen coming up with a charge - I spoke to them, and one of them came and took the prisoners to the watch-house; the handkerchief has not been found; I am sure I saw Wright take it, and run it into his trousers pocket; Mr. Morris and I were afraid to take them, we were afraid we should be knocked down; Mr. Morris is not here; Farrell was close to Wright at the time it was taken.
CHARLES O'NEAL. I am a watchman. I took the two prisoners at the corner of Compton-street - they denied all knowledge of it.

FARRELL'S Defence. I went to a man who owed me a few shillings - I then met this young man, we were walking on; this gentleman crossed the road, and said we had been picking a pocket; I know no more of it than I do of my dying hour.

WRIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

FARRELL -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1250.
WILLIAM SLATER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Russell
, from his person .

THOMAS RUSSELL. On the 28th of April I was going down St. Martin's-lane
, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I felt something touch my hip - I put my hand to my pocket and missed my handkerchief; I turned, and the prisoner passed me; I looked at a man who was behind me, a stouter man than myself - he looked and smiled; I looked after the prisoner, and saw him take off his cap and put something into it; a boy said, "Excuse me, Sir, but a boy has picked your pocket;" I said, "I thought so;" I then went after the prisoner but lost sight of him; I came back and met the other boy, who told me where the prisoner was gone; I went to the ruins and saw a number of boys, who said, "Here comes the man with the white hat."

STEWART MACDONALD. I was coming down St. Martin's-lane, and saw the prisoner lift up the tail of Mr. Russell's coat; Mr. Russell stopped, and then he let the coat go, and went on the lamp post; the prosecutor then went as far as the watch-house, and then the prisoner took the handkerchief out of his pocket - I am sure he is the boy.

WILLIAM BODY
. I am thirteen years of age. I was going to play, and picked up this handkerchief in the passage of our house, down a turning in Chandos-street - I gave it to my mother.

MARY BODY
. My son brought this handkerchief to me one Monday evening; I kept it till Mr. Russell and the officer came.

JOHN GROOM. On the 5th of May I received this handkerchief from Body, in Round-court-passage, Chandos-street; I took the prisoner; when he saw the witness and me together he ran away - but McDonald said he took the handkerchief and he was taken.(Property produced and sworn to.)
MR. RUSSELL. I do not know what he put into his cap, but he went between the church and the new buildings.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about it.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1251.
SUSANNAH ROGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , 1 shawl, value 8s., the goods of
Prudence Day
, widow , from her person .

PRUDENCE DAY
. I am a widow. I was in Whitecross-street
on the night of the 21st of April, at ten minutes before twelve o'clock; the prisoner took my shawl off my shoulders and threw it to another person; I caught the prisoner, but I never got my shawl again; I am certain she is the person who took it - I gave her to the watchman.

GEORGE HOOPER
. The prisoner and another person passed me about a quarter before twelve o'clock - I passed on down Chequer-alley, and saw the prosecutrix with the prisoner in custody, charging her with stealing the shawl; she denied knowing any thing about it.

WILLIAM HORNSBY. I am a watchman. The prosecutrix passed me with a large shawl on; I assisted in taking the prisoner; the prosecutrix had no shawl on then - she said the prisoner had taken it; the prisoner denied it, and kept laughing; the prosecutrix appeared quite sober, though flurried.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I was going home, through Whitecross-street, when two or three persons ran with great violence against me, which nearly knocked me down, and before I could get over the shock, the prosecutrix took hold of me, and accused me of stealing her shawl. Knowing my innocence, I did not attempt to get away, which (in consequence of the state of intoxication the prosecutrix was in) I might easily have done.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1252.
JOHN NORTH
and
WILLIAM CRAWLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of May , 1 watch, value 5l., and 2 watch-keys, value 1l., the goods of
John Clarkson
, from his person .

JOHN CLARKSON. On the 11th of May I had been dining out, and walked from Stoke Newington
to Kingsland
