- it was then three or four o'clock in the morning; I was not perfectly sober, but I was sensible; I had a dog with me, and I missed him for a few moments; I then saw him near the door of a house; I went in and found the dog without his collar; North took the watch from my pocket and threw it behind; I have seen one key since, but not the watch.

Prisoner CRAWLEY. Q. Did you not have your watch again? A. Yes; I took it up and put it into my pocket again, in the same house where I went in for my dog; there were one or two persons there, and I went in and treated them with drink - I was rather drowsy; there was a blue ribbon to my watch - I lost it afterwards.
Prisoner NORTH. Q.Did you not let me have the watch to look at? A. No.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS. I was fetched to the King's Arms public-house to lock up a disorderly man - I saw the prosecutor, a woman, and the two prisoners; I took the woman out at five o'clock in the morning to the watch-house; I then went in sight of the house on duty, it being market morning; I saw the prosecutor came out in about three-quarters of an hour; I saw his watch-ribbon; he then went into the house again; after that he came out again, and said he had been robbed: I went and told two other officers because I could not go in myself; the prisoners were gone from the house, but they were taken afterwards.

JOHN GATES. I am landlord of the King's Arms. I saw the prosecutor come in soon after four o'clock, with a female and a dog; the two prisoners came in afterwards - the woman was very noisy, and was taken away; the watch was afterwards found on the ground, and was picked up again - after that the prosecutor and the two prisoners had some beer; there was a deal of conversation about the watch: about half-past five o'clock they all went and sat down on a seat in front of the bar - the prosecutor went to sleep, and North appeared to be asleep too; Crawley stood up with a pint pot in his hand - I went into a small room where there was a glass over the fireplace - I heard a rushing, and looked into the glass; I saw Crawley running out of the house - North rolled over the prosecutor, and went out; I went to the prosecutor, shook him, and asked what he had lost - he said his watch; there was no other person there at that time but a female, who had come from the country.

RICHARD MILLAN
. I am a constable. Phillips informed me a gentleman had been robbed, and that Crawley and North were suspected - I went and found them at another public-house together; North appeared in liquor I found these two keys on Crawley.

JAMES TERRY
. I went with Millan to the Coach and Horses public-house, and took Crawley; he said he had some property of his friend's - it was this watch.

JOHN CLARKSON
. These are my keys.

CRAWLEY'S Defence. North told me he bought these two keys as he came from the country, and he said he must have made an exchange, as he had lost his own keys; the prosecutor went to sleep in the public-house, and for safety I took his watch from him.

NORTH -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

CRAWLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .

1253.
HARRIET DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 half-sovereign, and 1 half-crown , the monies of
Thomas Wright
.

THOMAS WRIGHT
. On the 16th of May I met the prisoner at the corner of James-street, and gave her something to drink at the White Lion public-house; I then came out, and went to Mrs. Porters, No. 3, Legg-alley
- I was quite sober; it was about half-past eleven o'clock - I gave her 2s. for the bed, and went to bed; at two the next morning the prisoner got up, and went away unknown to me - I had had half a sovereign and half a crown in my trousers, which I put under my head; Mrs. Porter came up and asked if I had not been robbed - I said Yes, and told her to go for the watchman; in going to the watch-house half a sovereign fell from the prisoner - she took it up, and put it into her mouth; she had said she had not a farthing, but at the watch-house they found half a crown in the heel of each of her stockings - one of the half-crowns I had given her; she swallowed the half-sovereign.

Prisoner. Q. Were you not tipsy? A. No, not at all- I was not sick; I had not had any oysters - I gave you a shilling, and you went and got bread and cheese and raddishes for supper; I did not bolt the door.

JOHN SHIELDS. I was night-constable. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house - the prosecutor said she had robbed him of half a sovereign and half a crown; I saw a piece of gold in her mouth, and tried to get it, but she swallowed it - I found a shilling in her purse, half acrown in her bosom, and half a crown in each of her stockings.
Prisoner. Did you not put your finger into my mouth? A. Yes, but I took it out again pretty soon, for I know you of old.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor in Longacre; he asked me to get him something to drink - I had 6s.; I took the prosecutor to the White Lion, and had a glass of wine - he asked if I had a room; I said I had not, but took him to No. 3, Legg-alley - he gave me half a crown to stop with him; I scrupled to take it - he then gave me a shilling to get some bread and cheese and raddishes, and he took my bonnet lest I should go away; he shut the door, and bolted it - the landlady went up and knocked at the door, and then he opened it and said"It is all right;" he then said he had lost his money - he had been sick on the bed; I gave him back the half-crown, and said I would not stay with him.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1254.
JOSEPH PERMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 1 iron screw, value 3., and 1 iron collar, value 1s. , the goods of
William Lee
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined Two Months .

1255.
JOHN MASHFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 basket, value 2s., and 9 loaves of bread, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Blake
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

1256.
SAMUEL HIGGINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
William Wilson
, from his person .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1257.
WILLIAM FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 coat, value 4l., and 1 pair of trousers, value 30s. , the goods of
Emery Moore
, his master.
MR. DOWLING conducted the prosecution.

EMERY MOORE
. I am a tailor , and live in Oxford-street. The prisoner was in my employ - I gave him a coat and trousers, on the 26th of May, to take to a customer, at No. 7 Barlow-street, High-street, Marylebone; he never returned.

ANGELIOS BETRAUN. I am a constable. I was employed to go to the prisoner's lodgings - he was in bed; I made him no promise or threat - I asked what he had done with the clothes; he said he had pawned them at Mr. Sowerby's, in Long-acre, and had been robbed of the duplicate and part of the money.

JOHN ANDREW
SIMPSON. I am an assistant to Mr. Sowerby, a pawnbroker, in Long-acre. On the 26th of May the prisoner pawned these articles at our shop for 50s.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met two persons, who asked me to have something to drink - I got intoxicated, and they persuaded me to pawn the things to raise a spree.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1258.
JOHN RYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , 3 files, value 5s.; 2 screw-drivers, value 9s., and 1 chisel, value 1s. , the goods of
Alexander Galloway
, his master.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

JAMES TERRY
. I am an officer of St. Sepulchre's. On Saturday, the 25th of April, I saw the prisoner in Cow-cross; he went into a marine-store shop - he came out again, and I asked what he had got there; he said an old file, which belonged to Mr. Meggs, of Soho, whom he worked for - I found a paper in his possession, by which I found he belonged to Mr. Galloway; he said Meggs had sent him to make what he could of it for a drop of beer, not being able to pay him wages that night - I went with the officer to the prisoner's lodging on Saffron-hill.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not say it was an old file or rubber? A. Yes - this is nearly worn out.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
. I am an officer. I went to the prisoner's lodging on the 27th of April, and found two screw drivers, two files, and an iron chisel.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the man's wife there? A. Yes - she gave us every facility to search the place.

MR. RICHARD HODGSON GALLOWAY. My father's name is Alexander - he is an engineer, and lives in West Smithfield; he has many hands. On the 25th of April we had about one hundred workmen; the prisoner was a labourer there - he had 24s. a week; he was rather a superior hand - they are entrusted with tools like these, but are not at liberty to take any away; this rubber is my father's property, and these other tools - one of them has my father's name at full length; I have laid the value of them at 14s.

Cross-examined. Q.What is that large article? A. A rubber we call it, but it is in fact a file - comparatively these things are worth nothing; my father is a very particular man, and always makes out the men's wages himself - the prisoner has been five or six years in our service; we should not have kept him had he not been honest.

Prisoner's Defence. For the last seven years back labourers have lodged with me - both single men, and married men and their wives, have lodged with me; they used frequently to bring files, hammers and screw-drivers when they went to breakfast - they threw their tools down on the floor, and then took them back to the factory; if any of them have been left till night I have taken them to the gate, and the time-keeper has said, "Take them back, and bring them in the morning," and now at last they came and found these things in my house; the officer said,"Tell me the truth" - I said, "I am not ashamed, I live on Saffron-hill; tell my wife to come here" - she came, and I told her to go to Mr. Galloway's, to tell him I was in custody; she did, and he said, "It is more than I expected, but if it is my property I shall know it."
NOT GUILTY .

1259.
REBECCA BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Timothy Neil
, from his person .

TIMOTHY NEIL
. I am a cooper , and live in Hinton-street, Bethnal-green - I am married . I met the prisoner in Whitechapel, on the evening of the 28th of May - she asked for something to drink, which I did not object to; there was another female with her - I offered to go to a house in Whitechapel; they said there was better liquor up a turning - we went up; they sent for the liquor, and the prisoner took two half-crowns, two shillings, and two sixpences from me - they pressed me to go to bed, but I would not; I took off my jacket, and they tried to get out - I said I would not let them go out; I seized the prisoner, and she threw down sixpence on the floor - they then said if I did not go out they would get two men to put me out - they got me out and threw stones and bricks at me; I cried Watch! but the watchman did not come- I cried Murder! and then Mr. Lee came by, and took them.

JAMES LEE
. I am an officer. I was passing Georgeyard, between nine and ten o'clock - I heard a cry of Murder! went up and saw the prisoner and three others throwing stones at the prosecutor; I took the prisoner, and the others went away - I found two half-crowns in her bosom at the watch-house.

The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she was passing and stopped to look at the prosecutor, who was very much intoxicated, and quarrelling with some girls, and that he turned suddenly round and charged her with robbing him, but she had not been with him.

JURY to
JAMES LEE
. Q.Was the prosecutor tipsy? A. He had been drinking, but was quite sensible.

TIMOTHY NEIL
. I had had but two pints of beer when I met the prisoner - I walked with Mr. Lee to the watch-house.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Life .

1260.
JAMES O'CONNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , certain fixtures, to wit, 2 sashes, value 6s., and 3 doors, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Morris
, and fixed to a certain building of his: against the Statute , &c.

CHRISTIANA MORRIS
. I am the wife of Thomas Morris; this building belonged to him - the prisoner took the house; it is No. 31 Cow-cross
- it was a verbal letting; I think he took it on the 7th of March - he entered it at that time, and was to hold by the year; we had another house empty next door, No. 30 - I let him that, which he entered on the 23d of March; the property was taken from both these houses but not at the same time - for the first house he was to pay 50l. a year, and lay out a 100l. on it; for the second he was to pay 40l., but not to lay out any thing - after he had been there but a short time, I heard that every thing in the house was being pulled to pieces; I went to the house No. 31, I think about a fortnight after he was there; I did not miss any thing then - he left on the 27th, and I discovered the loss; on the Friday before he had told me, he found the place did not answer, and he would come to my house and settle about the rent - I said I wished to go over the house; he said I should not - a lodger told me that on the Sunday there had been two men pulling down every thing; I went and found the cupboard doors, the sashes and the water-butt gone, the water was cut off, every thing taken away and destroyed, and he gone off -I think he was there from the 7th to the 27th of April; he took them both by the year - a great many articles were gone; one shop sash was gone from No. 30, the sashes from No. 31, and all the stoves in the house were gone - the prisoner was taken in Camden-town on the same day; I found the carter on the Monday - he went early in the morning; the sashes and doors were fixed to the house - I knew nothing of him before.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not let me the house for 50l. a year, on an agreement for fourteen years? A. You were to have an agreement, if you laid out 100l., but were not to have it till you did that; I have no security for the rent whatever - I sent to the person, he referred to, but they have not come forward; I am sorry to say a respectable tradesman has deceived me; he has not fitted up either of the houses, he has destroyed every thing, and took every thing away - every thing was in proper order when he took the houses.

JOHN CARTER
. I am an assistant to Mr. Underhill, a glass-cutter; he purchases a great many old materials, having a great many houses - I went to No. 31, Cow-cross the beginning of April; I think it was for four doors, which my master had purchased - I saw the prisoner; I said, I had come for the four cupboard doors - I went afterwards, and brought away a glass front and two sashes; the prisoner delivered them to me, and I gave him the money - I gave 24s. for the front; I had seen him when he came to ask my master if he wanted to purchase some old things from a house he was repairing, and which he had got the lease of; my master did not buy any lead of him, that I know of - the rooms were not repaired; there was no front to the shop - it was a tripe-shop apparently; I believe that front came from came from one of the shops - it was brought into the passage, and not replaced with another; some of the doors are here, this is the best of them - I do not know what it is worth, it may be worth 4s.

JAMES TERRY
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner at Somers'-town, the day he absconded from the shop; I think it was the latter part of April - I found him in a little back room, and coming along I asked him what he had done with the fixtures of the two houses; he said the shop front he had sent to Vauxhall to be glazed, and the doors he had never seen.

MRS. MORRIS. These are my doors and sashes; he said he was going to keep a tripe-shop - he was to make a shed and other things; it will coat me more than 100l. to replace the articles that are gone - he was to live in one of the houses; there were no repairs going on.

RICHARD MILLIN
. I am a constable. I found this shop front at Mr. Underhill's - he is not a painter and glazier.
Prisoner's Defence. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court - I removed into one of the houses, and was fitting it up for my own trade.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .

1261.
WILLIAM WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 600 bricks, value 7s. 6d. , the goods of
Charles Thornton
.
MR. DOWLING conducted the prosecution.

CHARLES THORNTON. I am a market-gardener , and live at Walham-green. My father had a number of bricks in a field - I went there on the 17th of March, and missed from six to seven hundred; there were a heap of bats on the other side.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.What is your father's name? A. Charles; these bricks were in a field which he had bought some time before - there was a private road across the field, not a regular thoroughfare for carriages; there were from twenty to thirty thousand bricks in that clump - they had been left regular, and I found the clump not regular.

JOSEPH LOWE. I am a shoemaker, and live at the back of Hale's-place, where the prosecutor's bricks are, I know the prisoner, and on the 14th I saw him taking away some bricks, between nine and ten o'clock, from the heap on the left hand side - I saw him take one barrow full.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they brick-bats? A. Yes; some of them were very good ones.

MR. DOWLING. Q.Was this at near ten o'clock in the evening? A. Yes; I followed him, and saw him wheel the bricks down the place where he lives - some of them were whole bricks; Mr. Vale is dead - he was examined one Thursday, and died on the Thursday following.

AMBROSE SADLER
. I am a gardener, and live at Northend, Fulham - I work at Mr. Lee's nursery. On Sunday morning, the 15th of March, I saw the prisoner take two barrow loads of bricks from Mr. Thoruton's ground; some of them were whole bricks.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you state this before the Magistrate? A. Yes; I did not say I saw "Some man" - I said it was the prisoner.

ROBERT FIELD
. I am a carpenter, and live at Northend. On Sunday, the 15th of March, I saw the prisoner take a barrow of bats from Mr. Thornton's ground, at the back of Hale's-place - I knew him before.
Prisoner to JOSEPH LOWE. Q. Did you see me on the 14th take any bricks or bats away? A. Yes, and many times before - I was crossing the road to get some strings for some shoes I had to take home.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is the reason you did not tell the prosecutor of it? A.Because I did not like to make mischief.

WILLIAM MARTIN. I am a shoemaker, and live at No. 26, Wood-street. I have known the prisoner nineteen years- I was at Queen-square, and heard Mr. Sadler say that I was the man who took the bricks; Mr. Gregorie told him to look round and see if he knew the man - he saw me in the corner and said, "That is the man," meaning me - he then turned round and saw the prisoner, and pointed to him.
MR. SADLER re-examined. Q. Is that the fact? A. No.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Upon your solemn oath were you not told to turn round, and then pointed to him? A. No; I pointed my hand backwards without looking at the man, as I knew he had been there before - the prisoner was the only man in the bar; Mr. Gregorie asked me twice -I did not mean to allude to this man; I pointed behind me.
MR. THORNTON. That is true; he kept his eyes on Mr. Gregorie, and pointed behind him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did you make any sign to him? A. No.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1262.
WILLIAM PALLASIER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 2 live tame ducks, price 9s. , the property of
John Patten
.

JOHN PATTEN
. I live in Three Colt-lane, Bethnal green
. I lost two ducks from my door between five and seven o'clock on Sunday, the 10th of April; when I came out I saw two men at my door - I cannot say whether the prisoner was one.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.How soon after did you see these ducks? A. Not for a week or ten days.

THOMAS SHELSWELL. I received information on the the 18th of April that the prisoner had some stolen property in his house - I stopped him in Prince-street, Mile end New-town, went to his house, and found ten ducks; two of them the prosecutor identified.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you brought them here? A. No; they were given up to him.
JOHN PATTEN. They were my ducks - they were white ones; one has a long neck, and the other a short one.
NOT GUILTY .

1263.
WILLIAM PALLASIER
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , 1 iron stove, value 6s. , the goods of
Benjamin Willomatt
.

BENJAMIN WILLOMATT
. I am a general dealer . I lost a stove from my door in Bethnal-green-road
, about the 3d or 4th of April - I found it again on the 15th.
NOT GUILTY .

1264.
SARAH WILLIAMS , alias
EMMA ARMSTRONG
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of April , 1 pelisse, value 5s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Callam
; and that she was at the delivery of the King's gaol of Newgate, holden at Justice-Hall in the Old Bailey, on the 26th of October, convicted of felony.

MARY ANN CALLAM
. I am single . I never saw the prisoner till the 27th of April, when I lost my pelisse out of the first floor, at No. 10, Circus-street
, where I lodge - I saw her come out of the house, as I was in the front parlour - she had got the pelisse; my landlady followed her, and the officer found the pelisse.

THOMAS PERRING
. I was sent for, and found the pelisse, where a little girl had placed it behind a watertub, No. 10, John-street, Edgware-road.

ANN BEST
. I live at No. 10, John-street, Edgeware-road. On the 27th of April, I was going down stairs with a pitcher of water; and I saw the prisoner with the pelisse - I said, "Whose is that?" - she said, "Where shall I hide it?" - I said, "I did not care" - she said,"You take and hide it;" and she hid it behind the water-butt - this is it.

MARY ANN CALLAN
. The prisoner walked into the house where Best lives.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, denying that she had entered the house, or seen the property.
PHILIP WEBSTER. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - I got it at Mr. Shelton'soffice - I was present at the trial, and know her to be the person (read.)
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Life .

1265.
MARY ANN SUMMERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of June , 19 yards of ribbon, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Savage
.

WILLIAM RUSSOR
. I am in the employ of
John Savage
, haberdasher , of Crawford-street
. The prisoner came there on the 8th of June; there was a drawer of ribbons standing before her - I was waiting on another lady - I saw the prisoner take a piece of ribbon, and put it under her shawl - I then saw her take two more pieces, and put under her shawl on the other side - I went to her, and she said, "What is the price of this?" - I said,"Three-halfpence" - she bought one yard of it; when she had gone out I fetched her back - she opened her shawl, and a young man saw her throw down the ribbon which she had taken.

WILLIAM ROE. I was in the next shop - the prisoner was brought back into the shop, where I was - I saw her throw this piece of ribbon down in the middle of the shop under the table - I took it up - there are nineteen yards of it - it is worth eighteenpence.
Prisoner. I did not drop any thing. Witness. Yes, you did, and I took it up.

Prisoner. Q. You looked about the shop, and found this ribbon, and then you asked the females there if they had had that ribbon, and they said, No - then you said,"You must have bought it." A. No, I saw you throw it down - I fancied I saw you throwing something.

Prisoner's Defence. I took nothing out of the shop but what I purchased - I said, if you will bring a female, I will strip entirely - this young lad looked about for some time, and then be asked the females if they had had it; they said, "No, not since Saturday" - then he said, "You must have had it."
NOT GUILTY .

1266.
SUSAN MORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 6 shirts, value 10s.; 2 shifts, value 10s.; 4 sprons, value 3s.; 12 collars, value 6s.; 9 pairs of stockings, value 9s.; 2 collars, value 4s.; 4 night-caps, value 2s.; 2 night-gowns, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 3 dresses, value 1l.; 4 petticoats, value 10s.; 2 habit-shirts value 3s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 10s.; 3 table-cloths, value 8s.; 3 napkins, value 3s.; 2 kitchen-cloths, value 1s.; 6 towels, value 4s.; 2 curtains, value 1s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s,; and 2 waistcoats, value 5s. the goods of
John Todd
.

PHOEBE GREEN. I live with Mr. John Todd, No. 18, Pavement, Moorfields
. Jane Morris washes for the family - the prisoner is her grand-daughter. On the 22d of April, the prisoner came and asked me for the dirty linen, and said she came from Mrs. Morris - I had not seen her before - I had but just come into the family - I went and told my mistress, who desired me to give her the linen - I gave her the articles stated to be washed by her grandmother.
JANE MORRIS. I wash for Mr. Todd - the prisoner is my grand-daughter - I did not send her on the 22d of April, nor know of her going - I had not seen her for eight weeks before.

WILLIAM HALE
. I am an officer. On Monday, the 27th of April, I received information from
George Morris
- I went with him to the Salmon and Ball public-house, in Bunhill-row, up stairs to the dancing-room, and took the prisoner, with part of the prosecutor's property on - I took her to the watch-house - I found a key on her, which unlocked a box, where the remainder of the property was, at a house in Rose-lane, Spitalfields.
JANE MORRIS. I knew nothing of this - the prisoner had been missing from the family eight weeks - when I went for the linen, they said she had had it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.

1267.
SUSAN MORRIS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 1 counterpane, value 8s.; 1 sheet, value 6s.; two table-cloths, value 10s.; 4 towels, value 2s.; 3 waistcoats, vlaue 1s. 6d.; 1 cap, value 3d.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 3s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
George Appold
.

MARY PATMAN
. I am servant to Mr. George Appold; of Finsbury-square
- Morris washes for us. On the 27th of April the prisoner came and asked for the dirty linen for Jane Morris - I gave her the articles stated.

JANE MORRIS
. I wash for Mr.
George Appold
; I did not send the prisoner there on the 27th of April, and never received any part of the property.
WILLIAM HALE. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; I found this part of the property in Rose-lane, on Tuesday, the 28th of April - I got it from the box, the key of which I took from the prisoner.

MARY PATMAN
. This is part of the property, the rest has not been found.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence .

1268.
CATHERINE JOYCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 silver milk-pot, value 15s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Nuttall
, widow .
ELIZABETH NOTTALL. I am a widow, and live in Perry-street, Somers-town; I have known the prisoner these five years - I lost a milk pot; I used to employ her three or four days in a week.

THOMAS HUNT
. I live in Tottenham-court-road. On the 9th of June the prisoner came to my shop and presented a silver milk-pot to sell; she said she lived with a lady in Oxford-street, and during her absence the children had got the milk pot and battered it up, and her mistress sent her to see what I would give for that, and what a new one would cost; I said the old one was worth about 15s., and a new one would be about 2l.; she cried and made a great piece of work - she said she would leave it with me, but it was a very hard case that she should have to pay for what was done by the children.
FREDERICK HILES. I am an officer. Here is the milkpot, all bent up.
ELIZABETH NUTTALL. This is my property, but it was not in this state.

Prisoner's Defence. I had to clean the parlour, and I had to move a trunk from one side of the parlour to another; I did not see the milk-pot, and I put it upon it;I knew my mistress was very severe, and I know the property is not hers - it belongs to a man she lives with, who has a wife - I wanted to know what I could get one for, as I knew she would make me pay for it; I asked what he would charge for a milk pot the size of that, he said 2l. but he said," You can sell this for old silver, and it will come to 15s. or 16s." - I said it was a good deal of money to pay, but I would go and ask my mistress to come.
MR. HUNT. This is broken purposely.

MRS. NUTTALL, re-examined. Q. Did you make her pay for any thing before? A. Yes; for a baking-dish which I lent her - she was very insolent, and I did keep 2s., and told her when she replaced the baking-dish I would give it her back again; I am a little hasty sometimes.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Confined Three Months .

1269.
CHARLES HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
George Weston
, from his person .

JOSEPH DAWS
. I saw the prisoner take a yellow silk handkerchief out of Mr. Weston's pocket; I have seen Mr. Weston before several times, and heard him called Weston - I do not know what he is; he was before the Magistrate at Bow-street - I only know that his name is George, by hearing him called so by several gentlemen who have been with him; this happened on the 6th of June, about six o'clock in the morning, at Mr. Belshaw's wine-vaults, at the corner of the Piazza, Covent-garden
; I went in there to get a glass of liquor, and I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from Mr. Weston's pocket; I took it out of his hand immediately as he drew it from the pocket - I gave the handkerchief to Mr. Weston.
JOHN EAMES. I am a constable. I have had the handkerchief ever since Mr. Weston gave it me; he is not here.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to get a glass of something to drink - I was very much intoxicated, and knew nothing of the transaction.
NOT GUILTY .

1270.
GEORGE HICKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 2 gowns, value 10s.; 2 aprons, value 1s.; 2 window curtains, value 1s.; 1 pinafore, value 3d.; 2 child's flannels, value 3s; 3 caps, value 1s.; 5 shirts, value 1s.; 3 children's rollers, value 6d; 4 bed-gowns, value 3s.; 1 frock, value 1s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 1s.; 1 bed curtain, value 1s., and 1 box, value 6d. , the goods of
Mary Griffiths
.

MARY GRIFFITHS. I am a widow , and live at No. 4, White-horse-court. On the 4th of May I was moving from No. 9, Twister's-alley
, from one house to another; the property was there between five and six o'clock in the morning - I missed it about twelve; I found it at the pawnbroker's

THOMAS BROOK
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce two gowns, three aprons, and two curtains, pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of May, in the name of
George Hicks
.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have known him some time? A. Yes; he gave his own name and address - I had been told the prosecutrix had asked 2l.,
and I asked how she could ask that for them, as they were not worth so much.
MARY GRIFFITHS. I lost more property than this.

Cross-examined. Q.Where is Mr. Griffiths? A. He has been dead these three years; I am not married now; I do not live in the house with the prisoner - I know Hawksby, but I never asked through him for 2l., of the prisoner; I never said, that if the prisoner would give 2l. I would drop the business - I had no conversation with him about these things; I know the prisoner by sight, but I do not think I ever spoke to him.
DAVID MCCRAY. I took up the prisoner in his father's house - he gave himself up to me; he said two young men came and asked him to pawn the parcel for them, and they would recompence him.
MR. PHILLIPS called -

- KING. I am a butcher. I was talking to the prisoner, and two young men came up and called him away; I went home, and did not see him for an hour or an hour and a half afterwards - I did not notice that they had any bundle; I do not remember what day it was - I was at the corner of Adam and Eve-court, and he was called over to Playhouse-yard.

WILLIAM HAWKSBY
. I am a cheesemonger, and live in Whitecross-street; I have known - the prisoner from an infant - the prosecutrix said, in my presence, that 2l. would satisfy her for these things - I am quite sure of that.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Confined Fourteen Days .
OLD COURT.
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, JUNE 17.
Third Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1271.
JOHN TISLEY alias
JOSEPH HARRIS
was indicted for that, at the general delivery of the King's Gaol of Newgate, holden for the County of Middlesex at Justice Hall, in the Old Bailey, on Wednesday the 11th of January, in the 55th year of the reign of George the 3d, he, by the name of
John Tisley
, late of the parish of Chirstchurch, in the County of Middlesex, labourer, was in due form of law tried and convicted on a certain indictment against him, for that he, on the 2d of January, in the 55th year aforesaid, about eight o'clock in the night of the same day, with force of arms, at the parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, the dwelling-house of
Samuel Loader
, there situate, feloniously and burglariously did break and enter, with intent the goods and chattels in the same dwelling-house, then and there feloniously and burglariously to steal, take, and carry away; and 3 pairs of shoes, value 3s.; 1 lookingglass, value 3s.; 24 yards of fancy trimming, value 2s., and 1 silk handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of the said Samuel Loader, in the same dwelling-house, then and there being found, then and there feloniously and burglariously did steal, take, and carry away; against the peace, &c.; and was thereupon ordered to be hanged by the neck until he should be dead, but His Royal Highness the Prince Regent, in the name of His Majesty, having been graciously pleased to extend the Royal mercy to him, upon condition of his being transported toNew South Wales, or some one or other of the islands adjacent there to, for the term of his natural life, which being in due manner signified, he was ordered to be transported accordingly; and that he afterwards, on the 27th of May , in the 10th year of the reign of George the Fourth, at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green,
feloniously was at large, without any lawful cause, within His Majesty's dominions, to wit, at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green
, before the expiration of the said term for which he was so ordered to be transported; against the Statute , &c.

SECOND COUNT, that at the delivery of the King's Gaol of Newgate, holden for the County of Middlesex, at Justice Hall, in the Old Bailey, on Wednesday, the 11th of January, in the 55th year of the reign of our late Lord the King, he was ordered to be transported to the coast of New South Wales, or some one or other of the islands adjacent, for his natural life, pursuant to the Statute, &c.; and that he afterwards, on the 27th of May, in the 10th year of the reign of our Lord the King. feloniously was at large, within his Majesty's dominions, that is to say, at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green, without lawful cause, before the expiration of the said term for which he was ordered to be transported; against the Statute.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction for burglary; I saw it signed by Mr. Shelton, the clerk of arraigns - (read, see indictment.)

BARNARD GLEED
. I have belonged to two police-offices, and have since retired on a pension. I was in this Court when the prisoner was tried for the burglary named in this certificate, in 1815, and am positive he is the man; I gave evidence against him - Armstrong was with me.

JOSHUA ARMSTRONG
. I believe the prisoner to be the man who was tried on this charge, in 1815 - I have no doubt of him.

JOHN VANN
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner in Bethnal-green, Middlesex, on the 26th of May.
Prisoner's Defence (written.) I know myself innocent, and humbly beg your Lordship to call the following witnesses on my behalf (naming them.)

SAMUEL LOADER
. I now live in Swan-lane, Upper Thames-street: I am not a housekeeper. I prosecuted
John Tisley
, in 1815, for breaking open my house - I gave evidence on that trial - the prisoner is not that man: I am quite satisfied he is not the man, or else I do not know the man when I see him - I consider him not the man - I believe him not to be the man; I am satisfied of it.
Q. Do you mean to say you are sure he is not the man? A. I mean to say I have my doubts about it; I conceive he is not the man - he is not the man; I have no doubt of it.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Are you sure the prisoner at the bar is not the man? A. I really believe him not to be the man - I think I can swear I am sure he is not: but fifteen years is a long time, and may much alter a person, but I believe him not to be the man; I will swear he is not the man - I have not seen the man since.
Q. Have you seen the prisoner since? A. Yes; Mr. Wontner gave me leave to see him in Newgate.

Q. How came you to hear he was in Newgate? A. His friends, no doubt, wished me to come and identify him; I am a fellowship-porter, and work at Billingsgate - I was suspended, but the suspension was taken off last hall-day, the second Wednesday in this month - it was for six months on suspicion of doing wrong, taking two Dutch-plaice - they were in a boat where I was measuring them, I brought them up, and they suspected I took them improperly.

Q. Have you kept any place of public entertainment lately? A. I have been to many such places; I kept a bear and badger bait, in St. Luke's, for three or four years- it is more than ten years ago; I got a reward for Tisley's conviction, and a Tyburn ticket.

COURT. Q. When was it you were found out to be brought here? A. About a week or ten days ago, I think; I do not know who sent for me - I do not think it was the prisoner; he might occasion it - it was from some of his friends no doubt; any man might find me at Billingsgate - I never saw the prisoner at my house; a gentlemanly sort of man asked me to come here - he said a man was taken up, named
John Tisley
, and he understood I was the prosecutor, fifteen years ago; I did not ask who he came from, for he naturally told me he came on behalf of this man.

Q. Then what made you say you believed he came from his friends? A. I cannot understand these equivocations - he told me what he came upon; I should be sorry to swear he is the man, when I do not think he is; I did send the prisoner a bit of fish into Newgate a few days ago as I felt for him - I did not know him.

RICHARD JACKSON. I knew John Tisley about sixteen years ago; I am a silk-weaver, and now work for Mr. Archibald, of Mitre-court; Tisley was convicted of burglary about sixteen years ago - I knew him very well- he was not an acquaintance; he was older than me a good deal, but he lived next door to me; I did not associate with him - the prisoner is not that man.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Tisley was your next door neighbour, perhaps you attended here and give him a character? A. No; I was but eleven or twelve years old, and lived with my father and mother; I have not seen him since - he was about the prisoner's height, but much stouter; he had dark chesnut hair and dark eyes.

Q. How do you know he was convicted here? A. I recollect Armstrong's father coming and apprehending my brother in the room of him, but he let him go again -I think it was sixteen years ago, but cannot be sure; I recollect him by a certain mark he had on his hair; he had some marks of white hair - he was not very intimate with our family, only his mother kept a mangle, and we took our things there.

Q. When did you first see this prisoner? A. I have known him about eighteen months: he lived in the neighbourhood, but not next door; he goes by the name of
Joseph Harris
- I knew him by no other; I knew him before he came to live in our neighbourhood - he said he had just come from sea; he never mentioned New South Wales to me - I did not ask what ship he belonged to; I have not seen him in Newgate - I knew he was in custody, as my wife was at home when he was apprehended; she did not know that I knew Tisley.

COURT. Q. You knew Tisley very well, and know thisman very well? A. I knew him by being a neighbour; he works at silk-weaving, not at the same loom as me - he told me about eighteen months ago that he had just come from sea - he is not at all like Tisley; I should not conceive any body could make a mistake - they are certainly very much unlike each other; Tisley might have been about thirty-seven or thirty-eight years old, I suppose - I knew the prisoner by his working next door to me; I never asked what ship he belonged to.

LYDIA FOULKES
. My husband is a fellowship-porter, at Billingsgate; Mr. Loader brought me here to-day to give the prisoner a character. I have come to say I know he is not John Tisley - Loader and his wife came for me; Tisley is a man I was acquainted with; Loader's wife did not come for me - it was Loader and the prisoner's wife; they said it would be kind of me to come, as I knew the prisoner so well; he is not at all like Tisley - he is the man whom I have come to say is not Tisley.

Q. Who have you come to give a character to? A. They told me it was Tisley that was here - I was not in Court when he was tried; I was a neighbour of his, and lived close to him - I do not know the prisoner now at the bar - I never saw him before.
Q. Who have you come to give a character to? A. That man - I never saw him before; his wife asked me to come to look to see if he was Tisley or not; Loader asked me to come as well.
Q. What character can you give him? A. People tell me he is a very hard working honest man - I know no more than that.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. The man at the bar is quite unlike the man who was tried here? A. Quite so - he is not at all like him; he was stouter than this man, and had dark eyes- the prisoner has not got dark eyes; his hair was lighter than the prisoner's; it was a kind of sandy colour, inclning to carrotty red hair; he was about the prisoner's size - I knew him well; I never saw the prisoner before to-day.

SARAH TISLEY
. I am not related to the prisoner - I am the mother of the man who was transported - I do not know the prisoner; I never saw him before to-day - I am quite sure he is not my son; I knew nothing about him till I was found out - they at first said it was my son, till I was brought up: my son was transported for life - I do not know what has become of him - I have not seen him from that day to this; I never saw the prisoner in my life- I went to Loader, and desired him to come and say it was not my son; there is not a bit of likeness between the prisoner and my son: I have had but one letter from him; that was ten yearsago - I live at No. 7, Turvey-street: I know Jackson; we live pretty near each other; not far off - that is not in the same street; I never saw the prisoner with Jackson; I am sure I never saw him before - I first heard of this about three weeks ago, and went to Loader -I have not been to Newgate since my son was there, nor sent any of my family there.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long have you known Jackson? A. I did not know him till he came and told me to come here - my husband is still living; Jackson did not live next door to me - I keep a mangle.

Q. Did Jackson ever bring things to you to mangle? A. Why I forget; he knew my son - I do not think his father and mother ever lived next door to me, but the young man says he lived in the same neighbourhood - I lived in Winson-street, Spitalfields, at the time of my son's misfortune - I never heard of Jackson before this.
COURT. Q. Then you did not know Jackson when he was a boy, eleven years old? A. No.

SARAH BURY
. I am married, and live at Bethnalgreen; my husband is a painter. I am sister to Tisley, who was transported - I am older than him; it was seventeen years ago; or it may be not quite so much; I have only heard of him once since; I know nothing of the prisoner -I never saw him before; I have lived at Bethnal-green all my life - I do not see any likeness of my brother in him; he is very unlike him: I never saw the prisoner till this morning - I am sure he is not my brother, nor is he the man who was transported: I do not know Jackson; I lived with my brother before he was transported - my mother keeps a mangle; I came here with Jackson this morning - Loader did not come with us: the first time I saw Jackson was on Saturday; I do not remember his coming to my mother's about the time my brother was transported - I am now about thirty-seven years old; I and my brother lived with my mother: I have known Lydia Foulkes these eighteen years; I never saw Loader till Saturday; I never saw the prisoner in Newgate, and know nothing about fish being sent him there; I went to see my brother in prison about seventeen years ago - I have not been to see the prisoner there.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Look at the Jury - was your brother taller or shorter than the prisoner? A. I think he was much of the same height; rather stouter, and rather darker hair.
Q. Not carrotty, or inclined to be sandy? A. Yes it was, but it was darker.
Q. Now look at that man, and tell me, on your solemn oath, is not that your brother? A. No, he is not; I never saw him with my eyes before.
COURT. Q.Jackson did not live next door to you when your brother was tried? A. Not to my knowledge - I never saw him before Saturday.

Q. If it has been sworn that at the time your brother was convicted Jackson lived next door, and used to take clothes to be mangled by your mother, that is false, is it? A. I do not know; he might have done that - I cannot say; I lived with my mother then; Loader did not ask me to come here.

MARTHA LOADER. I am the wife of the Samuel Loader. I am come to say the prisoner is not the man - I was only merely coming by this morning, and as I was in the yard they called me in. I gave evidence on Tisley's trial - the prisoner has not a feature like the man; I cannot say about his size, it is so long ago; the prisoner is an entire stranger to me - he is not acquainted with my husband in the least: no present has been sent to him in prison by me or any of my family.
WILLIAM VANDERSTEEN. I am a silk manufacturer.
The prisoner has worked for me for the last twelve months he is a man I much depended on for his work; I have not known him longer than twelve months; I do not know where he came from.

THOMAS ELLIDGE
. I am a bricklayer, and have known the prisoner for the last nine months; he rented a house of me, and was considered a steady man - I knew nothing ofhim before; I made no inquiry about him when I let him the house.

DANIEL NORFOLK
. I keep the Duke of York public-house, and have known the prisoner for the last six months- he bore an undeniable character; I knew nothing of him before - I know Loader, but never saw him in my house; I do not know Mrs. Tisley - I know Jackson.

GEORGE GLOVER
. I am a weaver, and have known the prisoner for twelve months, not longer; he is a weaver and bore a good character.
SARAH BURY here, at the request of the Jury, took off her bonnet.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 38.
Before Mr. Baron Hullock.

1271.
EDWIN MARTIN VAN BUTCHELL
was indicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
William Archer
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

EMMERSON ARCHER. I am a silk manufacturer, and the brother of
William Archer
; he had no complaint for months before the 10th of May, that I know of; we were always together, and I should have known if he had - his last severe illness was last Christmas twelve months; he at times said his inside was a little out of order: for a week before the 10th of May he stated himself to be better in strength and spirits than he had been for months - I lived next door to him: he came to me on the 10th of May, about five minutes before he went out, and asked the way to Golden-square - I told him; I went out for about three hours, and when I returned he was at home, lying on the sofa, so unwell; he could not rise without assistance - this was between one and two o'clock: I persuaded him to get up and come down to dinner, in order to rally him, but he hardly took any thing; he appeared in great pain, and great agitation - towards five o'clock he got so extremely ill that I persuaded him to go to bed, and helped him up stairs - he got gradually worse; I got Dr. Lloyd about eight o'clock that evening; he died on the Saturday morning following - from the time he took to his bed he was certain he should not live, and arranged his affairs; he said he should never recover - he said nothing more than that, as to the certainty of his death.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. Had Mr. Lloyd been attending your brother for any length of time? A. Not for two months; he then paid Mr. Lloyd two or three visits; he had a depression of spirits in consequence of the death of his wife - there was nothing the matter with him at this time; his inside had been out of order - that was set right by a little medicine: I believe Mr. Lloyd wrote for him - his wife died of a complication of diseases- I have heard she had some stoppage in her inside, what it was I cannot say, and there was a tumor also. I attended the Coroner's Inquest; Mr. Van Butchell was not there - the verdict was returned without his being there: no proposal was made to delay it till he could he sent for; an attorney came from Mr. Van Butchell, and requested to see my brother's body, on Friday, when it was too late - he came about three hours before the funeral: the friends were all assembled, and the body fastened down; Mr. Van Butchell was taken into custody on the day of the Inquest(Wednesday); we refused to grant a view of the body, as it was fastened down, and not in a fit state to be opened - I saw Mr. Lloyd after the Inquest; I know of no application being made for a surgeon to see the body till the Friday I mention; if any body had come to see it on behalf of Mr. Van Butchell in proper time, he should have seen it; I did not say if I had the Coroner's authority they might see it - a paper was brought with a request from the Coroner, the day after the funeral.
COURT. Q. Do you know whether your brother had walked from Golden-square? A. He walked to the first coach-stand, and rode the rest of the way.

MR.
EUSIBUS ARTHUR LLOYD
. I live in Frederick's -place, Old Jewry, and am a surgeon. I called on the deceased about the 8th or 10th of May, and found him in a state of great depression of mind and body, apparently suffering great uneasiness; he complained of great uneasiness in the abdomen, and greater pain in the lower part, towards the left side - he said, "I am aware I have received such an injury in my bowels as I shall not recover;" my opinion from an examination of him, and from his report of an operation he had undergone, was that his bowels were seriously injured: I stated that I considered his life in a very uncertain state, but that at that moment it was impossible for me to say what injury he had sustained: independent of the injury he had received, there were not those symptoms to lead me to suppose he must necessarily die; I had several conversations with him - I endeavoured to encourage him, but his expression always was, he believed he should not recover. On the evening of his decease I examined his body, and found the whole of the abdomen very much extended, and on cutting it I found it arose from gas; the contents of the abdomen altogether exhibited appearances of inflammation: the general appearance of the covering of the viscera was that of recent inflammation - the parts were gathered together by a sort of lymph and serum, mixed with flakes of lymph in the cavity of the abdomen: the appearances of inflammation were greater in the lower part of the abdomen, and on endeavouring to examine the upper part of the rectum, I found such inflammation had gone on to that part, that another portion of the intestine was adhering to it - I was anxious to examine that part particularly, and as some injury might be occasioned by removing the parts at once from the body, I examined them in their natural situation; for that purpose it was necessary to separate a portion of the intestines, which was adhering to it - I did so, and at once perceived the rectum had been perforated, so that its cavity, and that of the abdomen were injured - I proceeded to remove the injured part from the body, and the portion of the intestines that adherred to it; I was then enabled to examine them more particularly, and was then confirmed in my opinion, that it was occasioned by violence, and not by disease; I have subsequently examined them again and again, and am the more fully confirmed in my opinion; any uneven instrument being introduced would have produced this injury, whether sharp or blunt - I have here a straight clyster-pipe, six inches long, by which a similar accident was occasioned.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q.Who occasioned that accident? A. A nurse in the hospital - the patient died: on pressing the lower part of the deceased's abdomen he complained of pain - I found the peritonoeum considerably inflamed; his feeling a tenderness there, was not a decisive criterion of a peritonoeal inflammation - I was convinced he was not suffering from peritonoeal inflammation to any extent when I first saw him - it came on afterwards; he was bled two successive days - I generally prescribe only, but I did bleed him on the Tuesday; he had a dozen leeches on the Sunday - they usually take about half an ounce each, but the quantity is uncertain; leeches were again applied on Monday, and I think twice that day - I bled him in the arm on Tuesday, till he was faint, which is the only good rule to bleed by in such cases; I should think I took sixteen ounces or eighteen ounces, but will not undertake to say positively - I bled him again next day in the arm; on examination after death, I found the upper part of the rectum adhering to some of the smaller guts - I had used a cutting instrument to open the body; I took the part out, partly with my hand, and partly with a cutting instrument; I found the adhesion before that - I separated the smaller intestines from the large, with my hand - the rectum, in my opinion, varies in different individuals from seven to eight inches - in my opinion, decidedly not ten inches; it is a continuation of the large gut.

Q. Is the distance from the anus to the part where the adhesion was, seven or eight inches? A. Not in a straight line, it would be little more than four inches to the upper part of the rectum; the gut lays round in a curved situation - if the rectum was taken out of the cavity, in which it lays, it is much longer, but a straight instrument, could only go in a straight direction; I did not take away any part of the gut in separating them; where the inflammation is of recent duration, it could not be done - I separated them gently with my hand; I doubt the possibility of doing it, if the inflammation had been of long standing; it was almost impossible.

Q. If you wanted to examine the rectum, and parts adjacent, would not the right course have been, to have taken them out, and infuse water into them, to see where the injury was? A. I never adopted that course - if I could not discover it, it would be necessary to use other means, but here it was quite obvious, generally speaking - from two inches and a half to three inches of the intestine is in contact with the bladder: when distended the bladder is much higher up, it depends on the size of the bladder - when it is distended, it extends quite above the rectum; the injury was about four inches from the anus, in a straight line - if an instrument had gone in a backward direction, it would have gone against the back-bone or bladder, but in a front direction it would not; a cellular membrane fills up the space between the bladder and rectum - in my judgment it would not be safe to pass a straight gauge, six inches long, if made of uneven materials; it is not within my knowledge that any regular surgeons introduce such an instrument as an uneven gauge - there are flexible metallic gauges; I never saw an uneven one, six inches long, introduced - I have seen a pliable one used; I have for years paid particular attention to the disease of the rectum.

Q. I should like to know how many patients you may have had under your care in those cases? A. I have been in large practice for many years, and cannot tell you within one or two hundred; I include strictures and those sort of complaints - I cannot tell how many cases of stricture of the rectum I have had; I never saw Mr.
Van Butchell
before to-day - I attended the inquest, but left when I had given my evidence; I did not suggest to the Coroner the propriety of sending for the person who performed the operation - I had nothing to do with it; Mr. Salmon called, and told me he was going to examine the body - I replied,

"I have the parts here that are injured, and you can see them," and it was no use his going to see the body, as I had the parts; I had taken them out on the evening of the day he died - it was by day-light, between seven and eight o'clock, I think; we were a good while about it, and as the part, in its natural situation, lay in a cavity, I had a candle to put into that cavity, that I might better examine them - in my opinion the rectum is not ordinarily ten inches long, decidedly not; parts of the body vary according to the height of an individual, but in the average number of cases it is not ten - it possibly may be so in some individuals; the cavity of the rectum is usually strong and thick compared to the smaller intestines.

Q.From the anus for the first four inches is it not natuturally straight? A. I should say not; the principal curve is that of the lower part of the back bone - the intestines in their natural state may be dilated very much, but when inflamed they cannot.

Q.Suppose the patient was on his knees, and his head down to the floor, would not the rectum be straighter than if in another position? A. I should think it possible, the lower part might be, but the other part would be still more curved; I have put a patient in that position merely to examine the state of the prostrate glands, and to examine if their was a stricture in the rectum, but not commonly - the cerum in the cavity would arise from inflammation, which would cause the smaller part of the gut to adhere; inflammation of some standing, at times, produces ulceration - I do not think I had seen the deceased for more than three months before; he then consulted me for the piles, which is a disease in the lower part of the rectum - operations fail at times, when performed by the most regular surgeons: I remember the case of Mary Kent, at the hospital - I removed her breast when she was in a state of pregnancy; she died soon afterwards - it was a tumor I removed.

Q. As you have had more experience since that, do you consider you acted right? A. I still consider it doubtful, for I have heard it discussed in medical societies, and heard different opinions; many think it was wrong, but allow me to say she died of a disease she had had several times before, and whether it arose from the operation it is impossible to say - she did not die from the operation clearly; I found the deceased's liver slightly diseased. I am a member of the College of Surgeons; Mr. Smith, who assisted me in the examination, is not so.

Q.Supposing the rectum had been perforated, would not the consequence have been very acute pain, and an inability to walk or stir? A. With such an operation as this I should say not immediately - it would cause great pain and faintness, but I consider the pain would not be longer than the faintness; he would be able to walk, for I saw a person who walked from Islington in a worse situation, with part of his bowels hanging out - that was not with a hole in the rectum.

Q. If the cellular membrane had been perforated as well as the rectum, would not blood flow? A. I think very little; I am unable to say whether any would have appeared externally, if the operation be performed by a blunt instrument - if the bladder was perforated it is uncertain whether there would have been blood: I think it more probable that there would not - if blood had flown, I think it most probably would have gone to the intestines; it depends entirely on where the vessel was wounded - there was evidence of active inflammation having gone on about the parts; I did not use any injection when there was a difficulty in getting the bowels to act - I said the proper thing to be done was a clyster, but as I believed the bowels were perforated, if an injection was thrown up, it would destroy the patient at once.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You have the injured parts here? A. I have; I attribute the death to the inflammation arising from the injury of the rectum. The case of Mrs. Kent occurred within the last twelve months - will you, as an observation made will tend to insinuate I did not treat the patient right, permit me to say the reason bleeding was not had recourse to at first, was his being in such a state of great bodily and mental depression, that it would have caused instant death.
COURT. Q. You adopted the best means in your judgment? A. I did.
NOT GUILTY .

1272.
EDWARD MARTELLY
and
HENRY JUBILEE CONWAY
were indicted for that they, on the 4th of April , at St. Paul, Covent-garden,
feloniously did falsely make, forge, and counterfeit, and did cause and procure to be falsely made, forged, and counterfeited, and did willingly act and assist in the false making, forging, and counterfeiting a certain order for payment of money , which is as follows:
No. London, 4 April, 1829, Messrs. Drummonds, Pay to Messrs. Wood and Co., or bearer, One Hundred Pounds.

with intent to defraud
Andrew Berkeley Drummond
and others; against the Statute.

2d COUNT, that they, on the same day, at the same parish, feloniously did offer, dispose of, and put away a certain false, forged, and counterfeited order for payment of money, well knowing the same to be false, forged, and counterfeited, as follows: - (setting it out as before), with intent to defraud the said
Andrew Berkeley
Drummond and others; against the Statute.
3d COUNT like the second, only calling the instrument a warrant, instead of an order, for payment of money.
MESSRS. BRODERICK and LAW conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE COOMBS. I come from the prison in custody: I know the prisoners at the bar - I became acquainted with Conway about three years ago, he at that time lived in the Temple with a Mr. Bale; I was living as clerk to Mr. Busby, a barrister - our acquaintance was broken off, and resumed about four months since, when I saw him in the Temple: I was still living with Mr. Bushy; I told him where I was living - he stated that he was living with Mr. Hinrich, in the Adelphi; I had taken him to Mr. Busby's chambers, and this conversation was there; he asked me if I would call any evening, after six o'clock, at Mr. Hinrich's house to see him - I agreed to do so; Mr. Hinrich lived at No. 9, John-street, Adelphi - he is a solicitor; we saw each other frequently after that; we sometimes met at Mr. Hinrich's house, and sometimes at the Brunswick coffee-house, in Pickett-street, Temple-bar, kept by Jonathan Busby; I recollect Conway saying to me that he was very much in want of money - that he had unfortunately seduced a young girl who lived at Mr. Hinrich's house, and he wished to marry her; he said if he did so, he feared he had not sufficient from his employment to keep her, and the only thing he could do, was to ask Mr. Hinrich to advance him 10l.; the next evening when I met him there, he said Mr. Hinrich had declined to do so - this was about the beginning of March; a few evenings after that I went there, and he said Mr. Hinrich had refused to advance him the money, and he knew how he could obtain some money if I could obtain him a blank cheque; I said I did not know how to obtain one, and if I did I should not like to do it; the conversation dropped then, and I appointed to meet him next evening at the coffee-house in Pickett-street; I did so - while we were in there reading the newspaper over, Martelly was there, and got into conversation with us - I only knew him before by seeing him at this coffee-shop; Martelly said he had been out of work a long time, and asked if we knew of any situation we could tell him of; I said I knew of none - Conway answered the same; Martelly said he had been out of a situation since last September and no one could assist him, and he was almost starving - I think he said if he did not soon obtain employment he must do something; Conway answered, and asked him if he could obtain a blank cheque, and I recollect Conway saying he knew of a good go - Martelly said he could obtain one, that his father had been a clerk, and I think he said at a banking-house; Conway then asked me whether I would give my consent to his procuring one; I said I would leave it entirely to him - Conway and myself got up and went out, Martelly followed us, and said if we were afraid to let him get the cheque, he would tell us of a circumstance for which we might have a down upon him: I understood, from what he related afterwards, that we could tell of a circumstance he had committed in case he split upon us; he said, that about two years ago he saw an advertisement in the paper of a young man wanted at a wholesale stationer's in Cornhill, and that security was required; that he endeavoured to get the situation by forging the name of some security, and that he obtained the situation, and was sent round the country to obtain orders; he received money for other orders which had been completed - and that on one occasion when he went out there was a great deal of money owing, that he had contrived to collect as much as 200l., absconded, and went off to New York with it; I believe Williams and Co. of Cornhill, was where he got the situation; Conway said he felt disposed to let him have the cheque - we then parted, and he promised to meet us next day at the coffee-house in Pickett-street, this was about the 12th of March; we met, and Martelly said he had got information from his father how he could obtain cheques, but he knew a clerk living with a solicitor in Old Burlington-street, who kept cash at Drummonds, he said he would rather go there and try to obtain a blank cheque than that he would go from the information of his father - he appointed to meet me on the following morning at ten o'clock.

Q.Before that application did Conway say any thing?A. I do not remember: he was to meet me at the coffee-shop, in Pickett-place, next morning; I met him there, and he asked if I would walk a little way with him - we went to Old Burlington-street: nothing whatever passed about where we were going to; when we got there, he asked me to wait at the corner of the street until he returned - I did so; when he returned, he said he had been to the gentleman he thought he could get the check from, and was sorry to say he had not obtained one, and could not obtain one; he did not mention the clerk's name, but said the solicitor's name was Hoper - we came back again to the coffee-house, and in a short time I left him; in the evening we all three met there - Martelly stated to Conway that he could not obtain the cheque there, and he must go to his father's, and get information how he could obtain it - we were to meet there next morning again; I and Martelly met there next morning - he said he had got information how he was to obtain the cheque-book, by going to Drummond's, and asking for a cheque-book in the name of Mr. Hoper - he said he would see Conway, would tell him of it, and he would go next morning to Drummond's to obtain the cheque-book: he appointed to meet me next morning, at half-past nine o'clock, at the coffee-house in Pickett-place - I went, and Martelly was not there; he came in about half an hour after, and said he had been and obtained the cheque-book; that I was to accompany him to Conway's office - we went together to Mr. Hinrich's office, and I saw Conway; I do not remember what day that was - there were several cheques shown me by Martelly; he had them in his hand when I first saw them; they were filled up, ready to go to the banker's - he showed me several; they had Mr. B. W. Horne's name on them; I believe he belongs to the Golden Cross, Charing-cross: as Conway had shown me a letter which had come from Mr. Horne to Mr. Hinrich, Conway asked me which signature I thought was the best; fetched a letter, with the name of B. W. Horne to it, and asked me to compare it; I said I thought he was better able to tell than myself - Martelly was there - I had seen Conway write the signature" B. W. Horne" from the letter, on a blank piece of paper; he asked Martelly if he would select one - Martelly selected one, which he thought would do: it was put into my hands to present at Drummond's; Martelly said I must go to Drummond's to get the money for it - Conway was by; I took the cheque, but told them I thought I could not present it, for I thought I should betray myself - Martelly said he would go himself.

Q. Was any woman in the office? A. A pot of ale was sent for, which I paid for; there was a woman there; I believe her name is Mead; she brought the ale - we were all together when she brought it; we each partook of some ale: Mrs. Mead left the room; Martelly said he would go and present the cheque, and that I should not have any of the money; I said he might do as he pleased: I do not recollect saying any thing else - the cheque was for 100l.; Conway made answer, and said I should have a share - we then all three went out for the purpose of going to Drummond's with the cheque.

Q. When the cheques were brought, with the name of Horne to them - were they all filled up? A. Yes; Martelly asked if there should not be a signature at the back of the cheque? Conway said he did not think it was necessary, but he could put it if he Martelly pleased, and he put on the back "Wood and Co., Long-acre" - this is the cheque, (looking at it) - I saw him put that name at the back - the cheque appeared as if it had been fresh drawn when I first saw it; nothing else passed - we walked together arm-in-arm to Drummond's, the bankers' door, which I believe is in Parliament-street - it is three or four doors from Spring-gardens; I understand that to be Parliament-street - it is about sixty or seventy yards from the figure on horseback, at Charing-cross: Martelly went into Drummond's - I and Conway were very near the door when he went in; I and Conway walked on in the street towards the Horse-guards, on the same side of the street: we crossed over, and waited at the corner of the street, and looked for Martelly coming out - we stood at the corner of Craig's-court, which is nearly opposite Drummond's; we saw Martelly come out, and cross over in a direction for St. Martin's-lane - we walked fast, and got up to him; Martelly said he had got the money - we went as far as Bedford-street, Covent-garden, and took a coach to Coleman-street, in the City; Martelly gave me in the coach twenty sovereigns, and Conway twenty sovereigns - he counted twenty, being all he had remaining in gold, which he kept for himself; we all three got out of the coach in Coleman-street, and Martelly said he would go into the Bank of England to change the notes with Conway - I remained at the corner of Tokenhouse-yard: they went away together - I remained where I was, and in about twenty minutes I saw them at the corner of the Bank and Bartholomew-lane; they came towards me, and we walked together as far as King-street, Cheapside, took a coach, and went to Lant-street, in the Borough - I and Martelly stopped in a coach, while Conway went into a house to see his young woman; he came out and got, into the coach again, and we went on to No. 7, William-street, Waterloo-road - a person named Johnson kept the house; I went there for the purpose of seeing a young woman named Smith: while we were in the coach going to William-street, Martelly gave me twelve sovereigns and 1l. 6s. 6d. in silver, and the same to Conway; I was acquainted with Smith - I lived with her occasionally; we had a bottle of wine there - Smith was there: we staid there about half an hour - I gave the landlord money to get the wine; I did not pull any out of my pocket - I pulled sufficient to pay for the wine out of my pocket, and gave it to the landlord; I gave the girl Smith two sovereigns - Martelly and Conway went away in about half an hour, but I remained there the whole of the evening; I did not go any where with Smith that evening; I may have pulled ten or twelve sovereigns out when I gave her the two; I cannot safely say there were more than ten.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you not brought into this business altogether against your will? A. I accepted the money - I did enter into this king of life against my will, and continued it all through against my will - it might be going on a fortnight from the time it was first proposed - I was then out of employ; I had been with Mr. Busby, a barrister - before that, I was with a Mr. Martin, a silversmith, of Falcon-court, Fleet-street - that was seven years ago; I was in his employ I think about a year and a half, and should think a year and a half elapsed fromthat time till I went to Mr. Busby - I left that situation in consequence of having ruptured myself by carrying more than I was able; and at the end of a year and a half I went to Mr. Busby - I left Mr. Busby for a short time, then I went to live with Mr. Spearman, No. 11, Paper-buildings; I was only a month with him; Mr. Busby's was the first situation I took after leaving Martin; I left Mr. Busby, and went to live with Spearman, and Mr. Busby took me back again; I swear I was in no person's employ from the time I left Martin till I went to Mr. Busby - I only went to live with Mr. Spearman while his servant was absent through illness.

Q. Why did you leave Mr. Busby? A.Conway had done something wrong at Mr. Bale's chambers; and as he came to see me, I believe, Mr. Busby discharged me; he charged me with nothing up to the time I went to live with Mr. Spearman; it was not for any thing I had done that he discharged me - he did make a charge against me about three months ago; it was for fees I had put to my own use - Mr. Busby, I believe, saw I had no intention of robbing him, as I expected some money by which I could have made the fees up - he knew it was in my power, and had he not discovered it before, it would have been made up - he did not make an accusation of robbery - he charged me with taking nine or ten guineas - I had no salary but the clerk's fees - it was not more than ten guineas that I kept - he did not accuse me of doing this for any length of time for he knew what I should receive - I was absent from the office when he discovered it - I did not fall out with Mr. Spearman - he found no fault with me - he is a barrister or conveyancer, I do not know which - I was only his servant, and never received fees for him - I lived with Mr. Busby, altogether five years and a half - I gave no information about the prisoners till I was in custody - I was sorry for the offence I had committed, when I was in custody - I gave information because the other prisoners, I believe, had offered to give information themselves - I gave information, because I believed they meant to do so, if I did not - that was my reason.

Q. Then it was to save yourself, and from no motive of honesty? A. I thought it my duty to do so from the persuasion of my parents - I submitted to their persuasion; it was not altogether to save myself - I do not know whether I shall escape.

Q. Have you not a hope that you will be saved, if they are convicted? A.From what my parents say I believe I shall - I made the statement by their persuasion - it was not from the pure motive of getting off myself - I do not hope to get off if they are convicted.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Then if that is the case, your disclosure has been voluntary all along, and you come here for the purpose of justice? A. I have acceded to the persuasion of my parents; it is not with the hope of getting off myself that I gave the evidence I have - it is not for the hope of escaping - I do not see that I have been guilty of many more offences -Mr. Busby's ten guineas is one; there are no others, I swear - I know Mr. Hinrich's house; he had no lodger when I first went there - he had one the last time I went there.
Q.Do you happen to know whether that lodger had a box? A.Conway took me up one night into a room to show me a box; when it was opened by Conway there was some china and glass in it.

Q. You were never guilty of any thing but Mr. Busby's ten guineas? A. I said I had not been guilty of many more; Conway took two pieces of glass out of the box, the rest did not remain there certainly; some of the things were in my possession - Conway gave them to me- and I took them to the pawnbroker's - I left the tickets with the keeper of the coffee-shop - I believe that is all the offences I have committed.

Q. Do you include highway-robbery and burglary? A. I believe they have all been enumerated - I know Goodyear, of Holywell-street, Strand - I used to inhabit his house - I was never accused of what happened there- he may have been the owner of beads, and so have I.

Q. Were the beads he owned the same as you became the owner of? A. They were - he did not give them to me - I never before committed a similar offence to that the prisoners are charged with - I cannot say in what month I became acquainted with Martelly; it was certainly this year; I should think about February - my intimacy with Conway had been renewed about a fortnight or three weeks before that - I was not guilty of any offence like this during that time, nor did I know of any - I redeemed Hinrich's lodger's things - I do not know that that was the reason I was not prosecuted - I pawned the glass, took it out, and it was pledged again; I was not threatened by any one with a prosecution about them - I never had any thing to do with them, except through Conway; I had no intimation that any prosecution was going to take place. Martelly had been in custody a month or five weeks when I made this disclosure; I only knew it by seeing it in the newspapers -I do not know whose hand-writing the cheque is, for I did not see it written; I know Martelly's hand-writing; I did not look at them so minutely, as to say whether they were his writing (looking at one): I cannot say whether it is his or not; I do not believe it is; I thought they all appeared in the same hand-writing, from what I saw of them - I have seen a piece of paper with Mr. Horne's name written several times on it - I do not know where it is; it was never in my possession - I had seen that paper before I knew Martelly. but only once - I was apprehended rather more than five weeks ago - I then lived in Newcastle-court with my cousin, not with Smith - I believe the premises were searched after I was taken - I saw in Mr. Gates' hands a pocket-book, which I believe was found there - I left it there - there was no practising of Mr. Horne's writing there - none could be found, for I never had any, and never did practise the writing; I left none at Mr. Busby's.
