Q. Did you send to the prosecutor's, or they come to you, on this information being given? A. I gave the information at Bow-street before I was sent to gaol: but I made out a written statement in Newgate - I had been asked to do it before by my sister, at Bow-street, but declined - I was never directly asked by any body else to do it, nor told there was already enough to convict me, and I might as well do it to save myself, or that every thing was known - I heard somebody else had made a statement - I sent a letter to Salmon, the officer, inMay, before I was in custody, or charged with any thing; I had seen nothing in the newspapers about it except the account of Martelly being in custody - it did not say I was charged as being concerned.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to say you did not know you yourself was charged with it? A. I knew Salmon was seeking for me - I heard so, but in what way I really do not know; I wrote the letter before I was in custody.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Then you were apprehended in consequence of a disclosure? A. Yes, and nothing else - Conway was then in custody; I have stated all the charges which were made against me up to the time this business happened - I was never charged with embezzlement by any body but Mr. Busby; I left Mr. Martin on account of rupturing myself; I did not leave without his knowledge - I gave him regular notice; that is more than six years ago - I know a Mr. Hamlet; I never saw any of his writing - I have seen Conway write; I have seen an imitation of it, but never imitated it myself.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. You wrote to Salmon - was there an accusation against you about something which happened after the business of Drummond's? A. I did not know it - I heard Salmon was after me about a forgery, and I wrote to him; I believe I was wanted about Mr. Hamletts and Mr. Horne's business - Mr. Hamletts happened after this; Conway shewed me an imitation of Mr. Hamletts hand-writing soon after the forgery on Drummond's was committed - it was before Martelly was in custody; I never practised an imitation of Mr. Horne's signature - Conway produced a paper to me with Mr. Horne's name on it, at Mr. Hinrich's - it was not before I was acquainted with Martelly; but he was not present when it was shewn me - Mr. Busby never charged me with embezzlement before a Magistrate.

Q. What do you mean by joining in this transaction against your will? A. It was against my will that I accepted the money - Martelly seemed unwilling that I should have a share, as he said I had done nothing in it, - that I ought to have presented the cheque, and ought to have none of the money; Conway wished me to accept of it, for fear that I should report it to somebody if I had none - I had left Mr. Busby at the time the cheque was offered at Drummond's.

THOMAS ANDREW RUSH. I am a clerk to Messrs. Drummond's, of Charing-cross -
Andrew Berkeley
Drummond is the principal partner; there are others. Benjamin Worthy Horne, of the Golden-cross, Charing-cross, is a customer of ours - he is a coach-proprietor, and is in in the habit of drawing cheques on us. On the 4th of April this cheque was produced at our counter, and paid by me with four 10l. notes; my information is obtained from my books - I have an extract from them; the book is in my own hand-writing - I have looked at the original book this morning to refresh my memory; I made the extract last Friday.

COURT. Q. Did any body examine the extract with you, or did you do it yourself? A. I did it myself - I made the original entry myself; this cheque(looking at it) has been paid - it has my writing on the back.
Q. Have you a distinct recollection of having paid the cheque, independent of the books? A. I have; I paid it, because my mark is on it, by which I cancelled it at the time of payment.
Q. Having refreshed your memory this morning, by looking at your books, how was it paid? A. with four 10l. notes, and 60l. in gold; I cannot say whether it was sovereigns, or half-sovereigns.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Is it the habit of your house to give blank cheque books to any stranger who may come in the name of a customer? A. Yes, it is done so; I am not aware of the circumstance, but we do not always know the servants who come from their masters - we should give cheques to strangers if they asked for them in a customer's name.

JONATHAN BUSBY
. I keep the Brunswick coffeehouse, Pickett-street. I know Coombs, and know the two prisoners; I have seen them at my house together on two or three occasions - the last time I saw them was about six weeks ago.

ISAAC WATTS
. I am a clerk to Mr. Hoper, a solicitor, of No. 13, Old Burlington-street. I know Martelly, not by that name, but by the name of Gage; I remember his coming to Mr. Hoper's about two months ago, but I made no memorandum, and cannot say when positively - he came about eleven or twelve o'clock in the morning, I think; it might be later - he called to ask me if I could recommend him to any situation, as he was out of employ; I asked where he had been, as I had not seen him for a long time - he said in America; I asked what took him there - he said he had been there keeping books; I asked what he was doing in London - he said,

"I am travelling about, trying to get orders for copper-plate engravings, shop bills, and such things; that was principally the whole that passed - another person was in the room, I believe, the whole time; I was engaged in business, and did not pay particular attention to him, but am certain he called.

CATHERINE MEAD
. In April last I was servant to Mr. Hinrich, No. 9, John-street, Adelphi. I know Coombs and Conway; I remember their being at my master's house - I do not exactly recollect whether it was the beginning of April, or the latter end of March; there was a third person in their company, but I do not know who he was - it was on a Saturday, between twelve and one o'clock, as near as I can recollect; I fetched a pot of ale for them - they were in the front office; my master was out at the time, I believe; I cannot tell whether they went away separately or together, for I went up stairs about my business - they drank the ale; I knew Coombes before, by his calling to see Conway sometimes - he generally came in the evening, when it was Conway's time to leave.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.As to the words" Long-acre" you express no opinion? A. I say they hear some slight resemblance to his writing - I do not know his brother.

SAMUEL HERCULES TAUNTON
. I am an officer of Bow-street. On the 7th of May I apprehended Conway at No. 96. Great Suffolk-street, Borough - I searched his person, and found a letter on him; this is it - it was wafered, and had not been opened when I found it; he lived in Great Suffolk-street on the first floor (read).

DEAR GEORGE - I cannot go with you over the water, having work to do, which will detain me all the morning; go to the fakement and obtain the leaf, then it will be my ingenuity that will settle the slum and put the bustle in our clyes. I am, with every feeling of gratitude, your's faithfully, and truly for ever.
B. M. CAREW.
Have pluck; when done bring the leaf to my house - will be at home all the morning. Destroy this. B. W. HORNE.
To George Coombs, care of Miss Smith.

FRANCES SMITH
. I go by the name of Frances Smith, but it is not my right name; I lived at No. 7, William-street, Waterloo-road, for a fortnight, about three weeks ago - I am acquainted with Coombs; I remember his coming to my lodging one afternoon in company with Martelly and Conway - the prisoners are the persons; they came in a coach - they had a bottle of wine there: Coombs gave me some money - he had a few pounds in sovereigns; I do not remember exactly what he gave me - I was in debt for rent at that time; Coombs paid it in Henry-street- I saw him pay it; it was 2l. 16s. - he paid it when I lived in William-street; he paid it on the Monday - he had come with them on the Saturday; he purchased me a dress on the Monday - I do not recollect how much he gave me on the Saturday; it was silver - I do not know who paid for the wine; I cannot recollect how long they remained at my lodging.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You had never seen the persons who were with Coombs before? A. No; I see a great many young men - I have been intimate with Coombs since last Vauxhall season; he was not particularly a sweetheart - he used to come to see me; I live by receiving visits from young men.

BENJAMIN WORTHY HORNE. I act as a coach proprietor, at Charing-cross. I keep an account at Drummond's, and draw cheques on them (looking at the cheque) - the signature to this is not my hand-writing, nor is any part of the body of it.

Q. Here is a letter with " B. W. Horne" on it, is that in your hand-writing? A. Not any part of it; the signature certainly bears a great resemblance to my writing, more particularly the one in the cheque.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is yours a joint account? A. It is a family account; it is the account of my father's executors - I am not an executor, but have the management of the money: it is deposited there in my name alone - I am responsible for it, and draw cheques for it.
T. A. RUSH. Mr. Hoper, of Old Burlington-street, keeps an account at Drummonds' - I do not remember seeing either of the prisoners before I saw them at Bow-street.

JAMES WOOD
. I am a coachmaker, and live in Long-acre. The endorsement on the back of this cheque is not my hand-writing, nor done by any person authorized by me - I never saw it till I was examined at Bow-street.

JOHN WILLIAMS
, I live in Cornhill. The prisoner, Martelly, was in my employ - I knew him by the name of Edward Gage; he came into my employ in October, 1826, as town traveller - in June 1827 I proposed to add him to several country travellers; it was necessary he should produce me security for 200l. - he produced to me this paper, purporting to be a security; he continued in my employ till the following August - his last letter was dated August, 1827: I did not dismiss him - I heard no more of him after he was at Leeds in August, and saw nothing of him from that time to this; part of his duty was to collect money for me, and for that reason the security was given.(The cheque was here read.)
CONWAY'S Defence. I am quite innocent of the charge imputed against me.
One witness gave Martelly a good character.

MARTELLY -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 25.

CONWAY -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.
On the Second Count.
First London Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1273.
JOSEPH WARDE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April
, 1 carcase of mutton, value 1l. 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Collins
; and
GEORGE SANSOM
was indicted for
that he, before the said felony; was done and committed, feloniously and maliciously did cause, hire, procure, and command him to commit the said felony ; and
JOHN SHELSTON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the said carcase, well knowing it to have been stolen .

GEORGE LEE
. I am a salesman, of Newgate-market
. On the 13th of April I sold to Mr. Collins, a butcher , of piccadilly, three carcases of mutton - they were rather of a particular kind, and had been sent to me to slaughter for a gentleman, who feeds and breeds them himself; they are the purest Merino breed in the kingdom; they weighed from 45lbs. to 50lbs. each: I should know them very readily from other carcases. I did not know the prisoners before this - my salesman came out of the shop in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after I had sold them,which was at half-past seven o'clock, and told me he had lost a sheep; he described a young man who he had given it to.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What was it worth? A. Twenty-five shillings; I never said it would not sell for 1l.; Collins had not paid for it - there are a great many carts about at that time.

WILLIAM BURLEY. I am servant to Mr. Lee. The three carcases were sold to Mr. Collins; the prisoner Sansom came and asked Mr. Collins' man, (Matthews,) what he had to weigh - he said three sheep; he asked who they were for: I showed him the three sheep - Sansom said he would lend him a hand to weigh them; I did not know him before: after they were weighed Matthews took one on his shoulder, and Sansom gave him another on his shoulder, to carry down to the cart; he said, "You had better leave the other one till you return, you cannot carry the three;" Matthews went out of the shop with the two sheep - Sansom followed directly after, and then Warde came in and said, "I am come for a sheep, which Mr. Collins' man has left:" I did not know him before; I gave him the sheep, and directly after Matthews came for it himself.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose two are as many as a man can conveniently carry? A. It depends on the size; Sansom was not there when Warde came in - he went out directly after Matthews; I have seen them about the market before, but not to know them - it was a busy morning: the cart was about two hundred yards off - I saw Warde in custody in a quarter of an hour.

WILLIAM MATTHEWS. I am servant to Mr. Collins. I went to fetch the three sheep from Lee's; I saw Sansom there - he was a stranger: he put one sheep on the scale - I carried away two of the carcases, which he helped on my back, and when I came back he was gone, and the third sheep also; I was not gone five minutes - I know nothing of the other prisoners.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not usual for one man to assist another? A. If asked, not without; I did not see Sansom speak to any body - he was alone for any thing I know.

THOMAS ROBINSON
. I work in Newgate-market. I saw Shelston in Finsbury-square, carrying a carcase of mutton, on the 13th of April, about ten minutes or a quarter-past eight o'clock; I noticed him particularly - I knew him to work in the market as well as myself; his duty was only to carry the carcases from the market to the carts, not further; I said nothing to him - I have been eighteen or nineteen years in the market; it was a small carcase of a Merino breed.

Cross-examined. Q. You can tell a Merino sheep when skinned, from any other breed, I suppose? A. Yes - I did not speak to him; my eyes were fixed on him for three or four minutes; I could tell it from a large Welch sheep - it had no head on: I am an occasional porter, and if asked to carry a sheep I should do so.

WILLIAM HOPKINS
. I am servant to Mr. Lee. I was in the shop on the 13th of April, and saw Sansom weighing the sheep with Collins' man, and shortly after it was missing - I have known him two years; he is a porter: I went to look for him - I saw him walk round the market three times, and then Warde came up to him; this was ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after the sheep was missed: he and Warde went into the public-house, and drank - I found Shelston at Chandler's corner in the market, about half-past eight o'clock that morning; Mr. Lee sent me to fetch him - I never saw him before: I afterwards saw Warde and Sansom together in Warwick-lane - I tapped Warde on the shoulder, and told him Mr. Lee wanted to speak to him - he came with me, and spoke to Mr. Lee.

JOHN RICHMOND
. I am a street-keeper of Newgate-street. On the 13th of April I was fetched to Mr. Lee, and took Warde in charge, for stealing a sheep - I met Jackson in Warwick-lane with Shelston, as I returned, and on the road to the Compter he endeavoured to shift a kidney from his pocket; I took it from him in the Compter, and laid it on the window - he attempted to eat part of it, but I took it from him; it was raw.

THOMAS PEAKE
. I am a patrol of Farringdon Ward. On Sunday morning, the 13th of April, I took charge of Sansom at Mr. Lee's shop; I found nothing on him - I saw him and Warde in company that morning, between seven and eight o'clock.

WILLIAM JACKSON
. I am a constable. I was sent for, on the 13th of April, about nine o'clock in the morning, and took Shelston into custody; I found 1l. 4s. 8 1/2d. on him.
HENRY PAGE. Shelston brought a sheep to my brother, in the City-road, on the 13th of April, and he paid him 1l. 4s. for it; he went away directly - it weighed 6 stone 2lbs.; I am a paper-hanger.

GILES SHAW
. I know that Page paid Shelston 24s. for the sheep: I am a butcher - I saw it in the shop; it was a slight sheep, of the Merino breed - a good many Merino sheep are sold in London.
THOMAS COLLINS. I know nothing of Warde. I never authorized him to fetch my sheep - I know nothing of any of the prisoners.
WARDE'S Defence. I know nothing about it. I left home at seven o'clock, and was in company with a person who cannot attend here now.

SANSOM'S Defence. I had been to work for a master butcher, who had bought a rump and loin of beef at the prosecutor's, about half-past seven o'clock that morning; I always work for him - he came to look for me, said he was in a hurry, and told me to go with him, and see the meat weighed; he took me to Lee's, and said, "Who do you follow?" meaning when was it my turn to weigh; Collins' man said, him; and when his meat was weighed, I put mine into the scale, helped his sheep on his shoulder, hung the third one up, and took my beef away: when I got to the corner of the Old Bailey, where the carts stood, I saw Warde and another man, and asked him to let down the tail-board of my cart, which he did -I returned to Lee's for my hat: it wanted five minutes to eight o'clock; I went to see Hibner executed - when that was over, Warde wished his friend good morning: I went down Warwick-lane with him, when Hopkins came up to us. I know nothing whatever of the robbery.

WARDE -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

SANSOM -
NOT GUILTY .

SHELSTON -
NOT GUILTY .

1273.
GEORGE SANSOM
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 9 legs of pork, value 2l. 17s. 6d. , the goods of
Joseph Collins
.

JOSEPH COLLINS. I am a butcher , and live in Watling-street. On the 4th of April I bought nine legs of pork of Mr. Hubbard, but never received one of them: I do not know the prisoner - I never authorised him to receive them.

DANIEL LEE
. I am a servant to Mr. Hubbard, a salesman, of Newgate-market, Mr. Collins purchased nine legs of pork and twenty-seven pieces of meat; two of his men took the meat away; they left the legs of pork in my care, and in five minutes the prisoner came and asked for them for Mr. Collins, of Watling-street; I immediately delivered them to him, supposing he was his servant.
Prisoner. Q. How came you to let me have them? A. Because you came with a tray across your arm, and asked for them - I had seen you on the Friday, but never before.
WILLIAM HUBBARD. I am a salesman. I sold Mr. Collins nine legs of pork, among other meat; I never authorised the prisoner to go and fetch them - I never saw him before.
The prisoner, in a long address to the Court, positively denied ever having had the property.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1274.
HENRY WILKINSON
,
JOHN BROWN
, and
JOHN PERRY , alias
GEORGE SHEEN
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 3 loaves of bread, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
Henry John Baber
.

ANN FRITH
BABER. I am the wife of
Henry John Baber
, baker , of London-wall
. On the morning of the 4th of June I was in the shop; the prisoner Wilkinson came in, took three half-quartern loaves, and ran out of the shop with them; the other two prisoners were standing outside - they all three tore them in pieces, divided them, and ran away; I did not see them tear them myself.

PETER KELLY
. I am a constable. On the morning in question I saw three men run round the corner of Circus-place, pursued by the call of Stop thief! I and another officer, ran and took the three prisoners with two loaves and a half - they had each a loaf divided in two, and were eating them very voraciously; I asked why they took so many loaves; they said they were very hungry - they made a deal of resistance; we found nothing on them but a small bag and a spoon.

ABRAHAM HAM
. I was in the Circus at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, and heard the cry; I pursued, and took the prisoners - they were eating some of the bread, and had the rest under their arms.
WILKINSON'S Defence. I told him not to take the bread from me - I was starving with hunger.

WILKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

PERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
The prisoners have all been previously convicted of felony.

1275.
JOHN ROBERT SPENCER
and
JAMES COSTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 1 1/2 bushels of coals, value 18d. , the goods of
John Thomas Pocock
and another.

MARK FULTON
. I am clerk to Messrs. Pocock and Son, coal-merchants , of St. Bride's-wharf, Whitefriars
. On the 9th of June, about twelve o'clock, I saw the prisoners taking coals out of the Joseph barge, which laid on the shore - they reached them out of the barge, and put them into a bag on the side; neither of them were in the barge; they must have pushed one another up to have reached them - there was about a bushel and a half in the two sacks: I have seen them there frequently before - the coals could not have tumbled overboard, for they had not been in the mud, and there was a vacancy in the barge where they were taken; I had seen the coals safe the night before - I saw them both take coals out of the barge; I saw Spencer taking them out of the barge - he reached them by standing on his toes; there were five in all - Spencer was the biggest; I apprehended them directly; I have warned them at least fifty times.
JAMES YATES. I am a beadle. I was sent for, and found the prisoners by the side of the barge; they took up their bag, moved on the puddle-dock, and I secured them.
SPENCER'S Defence. I came along the shore all the way from the Temple, and picked the coals up at several places.
COSTON'S Defence. I say the same.

SPENCER -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

COSTON -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined One Month , and
Whipped .

1276.
GEORGE SPINKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 8 smelling-bottles, with silver tops, value 3l. 16s. , the goods of
Apsley Pellatt
, his master.

JOHN ALSUP
. I am in the service of Mr. Apsley Pellatt, a glass-manufacturer , in St. Paul's church-yard
. The prisoner has been two years and a half there as porter ; in consequence of suspicion, on the 7th of May, I secreted myself in a corner of the shop, at eight o'clock in the evening; he had received my orders to lock up the front door, but before he did that I went and hid myself - he locked the door, and went into the glass room, and took these bottles; I went and let myself out at the front door unknown to him- I watched him out at the front, then returned to the shop to see what was gone, and left my fellow-servant to follow him; I followed, but he was out of sight, but in Aldersgate-street we found him in a public-house - I got an officer to take him - he was searched, and 8 smelling-bottles found on him, which are worth 3l. 16s. with the tops -I missed them from the room.
Prisoner. The firm is Pellatt and Green. Witness, Master has no partner now.

FREDERICK MOSS
. I am servant to Mr. Pellatt. I went out with Alsup, and found the prisoner at a public-house- the property was found on him.

JOHN
WILLIAM HARRISON
. I am an officer. I found the bottles on the prisoner, between his shirt and skin.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I entered the prosecutor's employ with a ten years character, and had I been a depraved character, I certainly could have robbed them to a considerable amount.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .

1277.
HENRY BOTT
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 6th of May , 1 glass, value 6d. , the goods of
George Hart
.

MARY GROOM
. I live with George Hart, a publican , of Aldersgate
. The prisoner came and had a glass of porter in a tumbler: I missed a glass the moment I took the porter to him: he went out - I followed, and charged him with stealing it; he gave it me from his pocket - he was not in the least drunk; several other glasses were found on him, or master would not have given him in charge - he had got about twelve yards from the house.
RICHARD LANGDON. I saw the glass produced from the prisoner's pocket, and found three or four more in his pockets and his hat.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it out to put it on the bar.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1278.
JOHN DAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 100 iron nails, value 10d., and 36 screws, value 2s. , the goods of
William Bush
, his master.

MARY BUSH
. I am the wife of
William Bush
: the prisoner was an odd man in our employ for five or six months. On the 26th of May, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I saw him take some nails and screws from the nail-house which adjoins the shop - he put them in brown paper, tied them up, and carried them down to the cellar, and in about two hours and a half, I went into the cellar, and found them concealed in some shavings in a basket; I brought them up, and kept them till the foreman came - we carried them back to where we had taken them from.

WILLIAM WARREN
. I am foreman to William Bush. Mistress gave me information; I went and put the property back to where it had been found - there was above three dozen screws and one hundred of tenpenny nails; the prisoner took them away afterwards.
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1279.
JANE SWAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 1 gown, value 1s. 6d.; 1 apron, value 1s.; and 1 cap, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Catherine Swan
, the elder; and 1 gown, value 5s.; 1 cloak, value 5s.; 1 shawl, value 2s., and 1 bonnet, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Catherine Swan
the younger.

CATHERINE SWAN
. I am a laundress , and live at No. 2, Aldersgate-street
. The prisoner is my daughter - she was living at home on the 5th of May, and for about a month, she worked at my business while she was at home- she left without informing me; this property was below stairs where she slept; it was wearing-apparel - mine and my daughters; I saw it there at night when she went to bed - she left between seven and eight o'clock in the morning; I did not see her leave myself - she came home on the Saturday following; she is seventeen years old -I do not allow my things taken without leave; she brought some of them with her again - she had no permission to pawn any thing; she had no clothes of her own at home - she came home distressed for clothes, and her sister lent her these to appear respectable in; she had been living with me a month - I lent her my clothes, but not having sufficient, her sister lent her her's as well; it is very painful to bring a child here - I merely do it for a warning to her.
NOT GUILTY .

1280
ROBERT GREENAWAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of April , 1 bed, value 1l. 18s., and 1 blanket, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Lucas Chance
.

JAMES THOMPSON
. Mr.
Robert Lucas Chance
has a warehouse in St. Paul's wharf
, and is a glass-merchant . This bed and blanket were at the wharf in a warehouse; I saw it safe on the 22d of April - the prisoner had been employed as watchman to our lighters, and had access to the premises - I missed the property on the 23d of April, and charged him with it; he denied it - I found a duplicate in a pocket-book which was found by one of the clerks lying on a counter, and I found the same pocketbook on the prisoner's person, when he was searched - I had taken the duplicate out before that.

GEORGE CANNON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found the pocket-book on him, containing a duplicate, but not of this property.

FRANCIS WHITLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 29th of April, I took in a bed and blanket - to the best of my belief the prisoner is the man, but I cannot swear to him.
NOT GUILTY .

1281.
ANN WILSON
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
John Frodsham
, on the 21st of April , at St. Bennet, Gracechurch-street, and stealing therein 2 watches, value 10l. 10s. , his property.

JOHN FRODSHAM
. I am a chronometer, watch, and clock-maker . My house is in the parish of St. Bennet, Gracechurch-street
. On the 21st of April, about eleven o'clock in the day, I was standing in the shop and heard a window break - I looked round, and it might be half a minute before I put my eyes on the pane which was broken; the prisoner then had her hand through the pane, helping herself to watches; I hallooed to her - she immediately left the quantity she had collected, and walked away with two in her hand; I opened the door, went out after her, and took her with the two watches in her hand - I am certain the window was safe before she broke it; it is my dwelling-house - the watches are worth ten guineas; here they are - I know them.
THOMAS KELLY. I only apprehended her.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 18.

1282.
GEORGE MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 224 lbs., of sugar, value 5l. 18s. , the goods of
John Edwards
.

JOHN EDWARDS
. I am a grocer , and live in Fleet-market. On the 1st of May the prisoner came to my shop with two samples of sugar, and asked what price I should charge him; I showed him four samples - he fixed on two; 2 cwt. was packed up, with 6lbs. of tea, and another parcel of sugar - he asked if I would send somebody with it to Mr. Green's, Saffron-hill; I sent my apprentice with him with the property in a truck - he distinctly stated that the goods were to be paid for on delivery, and I told my apprentice he would have the money on delivery; I never knew the prisoner before.

EDWARD HOPKINS
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Edwards.I had the sugar in the truck to go with the prisoner to Green's, Saffron-hill, and was to receive the money on delivery - master told me so in the prisoner's presence; but when we arrived at Green's the prisoner told me his name was Green, and the receipt was not meant for Green, of Saffron-hill - I handed the parcels out to the prisoner, who carried them into Green's; he told me to stand outside and watch the truck, as it was a bad neighbourhood; in a short time he came out of the shop, and said he had received the money from Green, and he would pay me the whole when he got to West-street, where he was to deliver the other two parcels of tea and sugar - he took me to the Coopers' Arms public-house, West-street; I went in with him - he said he would go and get a pen and ink to make out the bill, and I never saw him afterwards till he was at Guildhall.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He tells me he gave you a 5l. note and a sovereign, and you gave him 2s. change? A. He did not I am certain; he gave me no money, the bill of parcels was for 6lbs. of sugar - he said that was to be delivered in West-street, the others, being small parcels, I had no bills for them; I went to Green's before I went back to master, then went home directly, and told master; I had a stamped receipt in my pocket, which I brought home.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT, Sixth Day.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1283.
ANN ELLERY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 1 coat, value 12s.; 10 yards of cotton, value 8s., and 1 shawl, value 3s. , the goods of
John Kirk
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

1284.
WILLIAM JACOBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February , 1 coat, value 2l., the goods of
Robert Henry Makepeace
; and 1 coat, value 30s., and 2 shirts, value 3s. , the goods of
John Mullett
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined One Month .

1285.
WILLIAM STILES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 16th of April , 1 ring, value 10l., the goods of
Charles Frederick de Terrade
, Esq. , which had lately before been stolen by some evil disposed person. he well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM VERNON. I work for the prisoner - he is a shopkeeper , and sells clocks, watches, jewellery, and miscellaneous articles. On one Saturday in April he shewed me a ring with seven stones in it, which he desired me to clean; he asked me the value of it - I said, as near as I could guess it was worth 7l.; he seemed to agree with me - I took it home and cleaned it, and took it back on the Monday; it was very dirty - he did not say how he came by it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long have you known him? A. Seven or eight years; I do not know a more respectable man - I considered he was in doubt as to whether it was of value, or not; I do not think he is a judge of such things; it was in a very dirty state - I do not think any one, who was not conversant with diamonds, would have known them to be diamonds; they would have passed for paste with many shopkeepers - he has not much to do with such things; he is a clockmaker.

KITTY HURST. I live with Mr. Hind, in Torrington-square - Mr. Terrade was lodging in the house. I went to clean his room, and saw a ring with seven clear white stones in it, lying on a table; I took it, put it into my bosom, and went away with it - in the afternoon I was sent out on an errand, and at the corner of the square I met a girl called Kitty Barrett; she asked if I had any thing for her - I gave her the ring; she went up Store-street with me - she told me to go to a shop, and ask 4s. for it; I went to a shop, and saw Mr. Stiles - he looked at it a few minutes, and asked what I wanted for it; I said 4s. - he said it was not gold, and he would make it 3s. 6d. for me; I left the ring, and came away with the money - he did not ask my name, nor where I lived, nor how I came by it; I think it was on a Tuesday or a Thursday - I went before the Magistrate as a witness on Easter Monday; I think it might be a week before that, I do not know.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You stole this ring, did you not? A. Yes - I knew it was not right; upon my solemn oath the man did not ask me where I lived - I did not hear him ask that question; there was a little boy in the shop - I had not dropped the ring in the mud; there was no mud on it, nor streaks of mud - I did not offer it to a cheesemonger, who refused to buy it, nor to this gentleman, Mr. Franks; I never saw him before in my life - Mr. Stiles did not ask me where I lived; I did not tell him that I lived at Mr. Stevenson's, a linendraper, at the corner of Bowyer's-court, in Oxford-street, nor that I lived at any linen-draper's - mistress missed the ring, and asked me to tell her God's truth, and I told her; I never went to sell any thing before in my life - I lived at Mr. Ayers', No. 165, Regent-street; I left them because they were going to let the house as ready furnished lodgings - I did not state at the office that I was turned away from Mr. Ayers for having committed a robbery; that same girl wanted me to take a prayer-book from there, but I would not - that girl is not here, she was let off at Marlborough-street; I never was in any place of confinement till I was brought here - I did not mention before the Magistrate that there were seven stones in the ring; the reason I mentioned seven stones to-day was because there are seven - I counted them.
COURT. Q.Was it clean or dirty when you sold it? A.Clean.

WILLIAM BENNS
. I am keeper of Torrington-square. On Sunday morning, the 22d or 23d, I was sent for to Mr. Hind's; there was some conversation about Hurst and a ring - she was turned out for stealing 15s. from the cook; I took her to Mr. Stiles on the Monday morning, about eight o'clock - she said he was the person who bought the ring, and pointed to the boy and said he was present; I asked the prisoner if he knew the girl - he stood for a moment, and said Yes; I then asked if he recollected buying a ring - he said Yes; he went tothe window and got it; it was exposed for sale - any one might have seen it; it had seven diamonds in it - I asked what he gave for it - he said 3s. 6d., and said to the girl,"Did I not ask where you lived, and you said you lived at Mr. Stevenson's?" she said he did not ask any such question; he said it was all dirt, and she said she found it - that induced him to think she had found it; he said she told him she lived at Mr. Stevenson's, and he had sent to inquire there, but found no such person lived there.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.All this took place in a very few minutes? A. Yes, not five minutes - I remember your taking the ring in your hand at the office, and you asked a person, who is not here now, how many stones there were in it, and he said five; the prisoner was there at the time - it did turn out that the ring had seven stones in it; I took the prisoner's word for his appearance he - came voluntarily to the office.

COURT. Q. Did Mr. de Terrade claim the ring at any time? A. Yes; he lives at that house in Torrington-square - his name is
Charles Frederick
de Terrade; he is not here - this is the ring.

Prisoner's Defence. When the girl came to me the ring was all over mud; I have no knowledge of diamonds, and I thought it was only paste - she said she found it a little higher up; I thought it was not gold; she said she lived at the bottom of Bowyer's-court - I said, "I hope you have not taken it from any where;" she said, "If I did such things as that, how could I keep my places?" I said,"Where do you live?" she said, "At the bottom, at the draper's;" and then I incautiously purchased it; I am always active in stopping any thing I have suspicion of, and bringing people forward - one case particularly which Lord Winford knew of.

RICHARD FRANKS
. I live at No. 29, Tottenham-court-road, and am a cheesemonger. On the 16th of April a girl came in and offered me a ring for sale; I thought it was one of those common rings, it was all over dirt like the street dirt - she asked me if it was worth 6d. - I could not exactly recollect her person - it was a little girl; it was a ring of this appearance, and had seven stones in it - I thought it was glass; there was no stamp on it that I could see - I have known Mr. Stiles these three months.

JOHN VINCENT
. I live with Mr. Stiles, in Tottenham-court-road. I remember the girl coming to my master's shop - I did not hear all that passed, but I heard her say' she picked it up a little higher in the road - I saw the ring, it was very dirty indeed; she said she lived at the end of Bowyer's-court, at a linen-draper's; I do not recollect that she mentioned the name - I was sent there, and returned to my master.
COURT. Q. How far had you to go to the linen-draper's? A.Thirty or forty doors I should think; the girl was gone then; there is but one linen-draper at the corner.

WILLIAM JAMES STEVENSON
. I am a linen-draper, and live at the corner of Bowyer's-court, Oxford-street; Vincent came to inquire if such a girl lived with us; I said No; I think it was about eleven o'clock in the day.

WILLIAM BENNS
re-examined. Q. When you were at the shop, did the prisoner say any thing about having shown the ring to Vernon? A. No; he said at the Policeoffice that he had shown it him, and given it him to clean.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1286.
ADELAIDE DE THORAZA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 6 sheets, value 15s. , the goods of
Martha Davis
.

MARTHA DAVIS
. I live at No. 15, Finsbury-street, Finsbury-square
. I am single , and am a dress-maker - the prisoner was a servant at my house for fifteen months and a fortnight; she was there I believe at the time the sheets were stolen - she was the only female servant in the house; it was her business to mind the bedding and the bed-room; a butcher came to me to ask for a sum of money which I did not owe - I then went and searched the prisoner's box; I found a sheet and a night-gown belonging to me - I knew the sheet was mine, it had been worn a little, but was not dirty - it was a sheet from her own bed, but it was mine; I examined her bed soon after, and both the sheets were gone - this was on the 28th of April; I never saw the corresponding sheet; the officer produced some duplicates, by which we found six sheets; I knew them to be mine, as I had assisted to spin them, and made them up myself.

SUSANNAH PERRY. I live at No. 7, Camden-court, Grub-street, Chiswell-street. I had known the prisoner for about a fortnight before she went into this service; she brought me a pair of sheets and a bolster one evening, some months before she was taken up - she said she was tired, that the bailiffs had come into her mistress' house, and she had got a bed out and pawned it - she had a pair of sheets and a bolster in her apron; she asked me to go and pawn them on her mistress account - I pawned them in my own name, at Mr. Upsall's, in Barbican; Christopher Deer advanced me 8s. - I gave the 8s. to her.

CHRISTOPHER DEER
. I am in the service of Mr. Upsall, of Barbican. I know Perry by visiting the shop; I cannot speak positively to her pawning these sheets, though I have reason to suppose she did, by her name and address being on them; I gave this duplicate - they were afterwards claimed by Davis.

MARTHA DAVIS
. These are my sheets, they are marked with my name; the prisoner had no authority to pawn them - I never authorised her to pawn a bed; I had an excellent character with her.

THOMAS BROOKS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have four sheets pawned at two different times, one pair on the 19th of February, in the name of
Eliza Wilson
, No. 8, Camdencourt, a lodger, for 3s.; I did not take them in - this duplicate was given; I do not know who pawned them - the other pair was pawned on the 2d of March, in the name of Winson; I suppose the person who took them in did not rightly understand the name; I do not think Davis swore to these because they are not marked.

JOHN BEE
. I am an officer. I was sent for to take charge of the prisoner - she was not at first accused of stealing sheets, but was afterwards; I found two duplicates of Mr. Brooks', Whitecross-street, and one other duplicate on her.

COURT to
MARTHA DAVIS
. Q. Look at these four sheets, and tell me what reason you have to claim them as yours? A. I made up part of them - some of them were kept in a cupboard and some in a box, they are both kept locked; I never sent the prisoner to take the sheets out; I always do that myself.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

1287.
JOHN AUSTIN
and
HENRY JOHNSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the property of
Jeremiah Henry Joyce
.

JEREMIAH HENRY JOYCE
. I live in Crescent-street, Euston-square
. On the 5th of June this handkerchief hung up in my shop on a clothes-horse; a person could not reach it going by - they must have got on the step to reach; I saw it safe between eleven and twelve o'clock when I went out - the prisoners were taken at the time.(Property produced and sworn to)

SAMUEL JONES
. I am a shoemaker, and live opposite to the prosecutor. On the 5th of June I saw the prisoners near his door, about five o'clock, standing on the step; I came out of my shop, and went in at a private door - I came out again, and missed the handkerchief; I went, and told Mr. Joyce's people of it - the prisoners had only got about twelve doors down the street; I did not see them taken.

JEREMIAH CONNELLY
. I am a servant to Mr. Pearse, a neighbour of Mr. Joyce's. I saw the two prisoners running, and Austin putting this handkerchief into his trousers behind him - I ran after them, and they were taken in the middle of Euston-square, about a hundred yards from the prosecutor's; I saw the handkerchief found on Austin at the watch-house - it was claimed by Mr. Joyce.
Prisoner JOHNSON. Q. Who stopped us? A. Mr. Joyce's lad, and another person took up the handkerchief.

THOMAS SEABORN
. I am a constable. I received the prisoners at the watch-house, and found this yellow handkerchief in Johnson's hat; I searched, and found nothing else - I then ordered him to pull off his boots, and found one handkerchief in each of his boots; I found Mr. Joyce's handkerchief in Austin's trousers - it had this shop ticket on it; this waistcoat, which they said belonged to Austin, was put on the table at the watch-house.
JOHNSON'S Defence. I passed the shop door, and looked at some of the things; when I got about six doors further, the man took me.
AUSTIN'S Defence. I saw this at the door, picked it up, and the man came after us.

AUSTIN -
GUILTY . Aged 28.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1288.
WILLIAM BERNADEER
and
WILLIAM CLEASBY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 14lbs. weight of bacon, value 6s. , the goods of
Benjamin Barber
; and that the said
William Bernadeer
had been previously convicted of felony.

LUCY BARBER. I am the wife of
Benjamin Barber
: we live in Windsor-street, Islington
- we keep a shop, and sell bacon . On Wednesday, the 20th of May, we lost some bacon from our shop - I had seen it about an hour before on the counter opposite the door, not within the reach of any one going by; I missed it about ten o'clock in the morning - I had not seen the prisoners that day; I had seen Bernadeer about before - I saw the bacon at Worship-street; I can swear it was my husband's, though it was dirtier than it had been.

ELIZABETH BARHAM. I keep a chandler's shop, about one hundred yards form Mr. Barber's, in Windsor-street. I know Bernadeer; he carries hearth-stones about for sale- I had seen him that morning in my shop, and bought some stones of him; there was a person shorter than him sitting at my door - I cannot say whether it was Cleasby.

RICHARD SKILLERN
. I am a Bow-street officer. On the 20th of May, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners in Virginia-row, Bethnal-green; Bernadeer had this bag on his shoulder - I had some suspicion, and stopped him; Cleasby was with him, but he walked away - Bernadeer said it was bacon in the bag; I asked where he got it - he said he had been bird's-nesting in the morning, and picked it up in the field; I took him to the watch-house; he made no resistance.

WILLIAM KINGHAM
. I was with Skillern; I saw him stop Bernadeer - Cleasby walked away, and I took him; he said he was with Bernadeer, in Hackney-fields, when they found the bacon - he said there was another piece all over mud, and if I liked to go and take it, I might.
RHODA JOHNSON. I lodge at Mr. Barber's. I saw a person standing at the post of the door, about ten o'clock; I believe it was Bernadeer, but I cannot be certain - I saw no one near him.

GEORGE HENFREE
. I am an assistant-beadle of Mileend Old-town. I have known Bernadeer two months; I have a certificate of his conviction, which I got from Mr. Shelton's office - I know it relates to Bernadeer; I saw him then in Court, and heard him plead guilty (read)
BERNADEER'S Defence. When the bacon was produced at Worship-street - the officer said there was a mark on it, and then the lady swore to it.
CLEASBY'S Defence. I saw this young man jump into a ditch, and pick up this bacon.

BERNADEER -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

CLEASBY -
NOT GUILTY .

1289.
JOHN VIGO
and
CHARLES HOLLAND
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , 1 brass cock, value 2s., and 3lbs. weight of leaden pipe, value 4d., the goods of
John Foster
, and fixed to a certain building of his ; against the Statute.

MARY ANN
FOSTER. I am the wife of
John Foster
: he keeps the gate at the distillery in Whitechapel. I know this cock - it hung over a tub, and came from a neighbour's house to mine; it was fixed to the wall of my own private house - my husband rents the house; I had seen it safe on the night of the 14th of April, when we went to bed - this pipe came from my neighbour's wash-house, and branched into my yard; when I got up in the morning, it had been cut off, and a small part of the pipe from the wash-house of the next house, which was empty; the persons who got into the next house could have taken it away without coming into my yard - I have seen them in the officer's possession, and know them: the prisoner was taken in the course of that day.

WILLIAM LEVITT
. I live in George-street, Stepney, and am a labourer, in the employ of Mr. Nott, of Jamaica-street. My father was getting up on the 15th of April, and saw the two prisoners - I went down into the yard, and missed the water-pipe from our premises; we had no cock- my father sent me after the prisoner; I found them in company, about a quarter of a mile off - I ran and called Stop thief! Vigo dropped a bag from under his coat; Ihad known Holland before; he had lived in the empty house which they had been in; Holland put down a white wash-hand bason near the kennel; I ran and took up the bag, and gave it to my mother - there was some pipe in it, and about seven brass cocks; the prisoners got away then, but they were taken the same day; I am quite certain they were the persons.
Prisoner VIGO. Q. Where did you first see me? A. In Redman's-row, a quarter of a mile from the prosecutors; it was between five and six o'clock in the morning.

CHARLES BONWICK
. I am a watchman. On the 15th of April, I was going off duty at twenty minutes before six o'clock, I met Levett running after two men - I told him no one had passed my beat but the two prisoners; I saw Vigo drop a blue bag - I just opened the mouth of it, and saw some cocks and leaden pipe in it; they got away then, but were taken the same day; I saw them before the Magistrate, and knew them.

WILLIAM DICKINSON. I am an officer. I took the two prisoners together, between eleven and twelve o'clock, at a house at the corner of Dog-row; I told them it was for cutting off some cocks; I got this bag from Levitt's mother - there are nine brass cocks in it, and a number of pieces of leaden pipe.

MARY ANN FOSTER
. This one is our's, and the piece of lead pipe which is fastened to it - our house is No. 3, George-street, Stepney.
The prisoners received a good character.

HOLLAND -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

VIGO -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Twelve Months , and
Twice Whipped .

1290.
JOHN MURPHY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Waer
, on the 28th of May , with intent feloniously to steal his goods and monies : against the Statute.
SECOND COUNT, with intent to rob: against the Statute.

JOHN WAER
. I live at Windsor. On the 28th of May, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was about three quarters of a mile from Hounslow, down the backroad - I was alone; I sell things about the country , but had nothing to sell at that time - I was not at all intoxicated: the prisoner, whom I had not known before, came up to me, and asked charity - that was just going into Brentford from London; he told me he had not broken his fast that day; I took him to a public-house, gave him some roll and cheese, and part of two pints of beer - when we left, he said he would bear me company on to Windsor; we went on about three-quarters of a mile from Hounslow
, when he said, "Come in this field, and lie down till morning;" I said I would keep on my journey - he then said, "Give me what money you have;" I said, "I have no money, my lad;" he did not speak in a begging tone, but demanded it - he then knocked me down with his fist; I had no money; I had a handkerchief - I cannot say whether he got that or not; if the patrol had not come to my assistance, I think I should have been a dead man - I cried out; he jumped over the gate, got into the field, and got away - the next morning I saw him before the Magistrate - I am quite certain of his person.
Prisoner. Q.When I first saw you, you were in a public-house, three miles from London? A. No, you overtook me on the road - you struck me on the temple, and knocked me down; the blow stunned me.

CHARLES ALLEN
. I am one of the mounted patrol of Bow-street. I was within fifty yards of the Bell public-house, where two roads divide; one goes to Staines - the prosecutor said good night to me; there was a person with him whose dress corresponded with the prisoners, and I believe he is the man - I stopped about seven minutes to commnuicate with my partner, who calls there; I then went slowly back towards Windsor, and when I got about three-quarters of a mile from where I first saw them, I heard a scuffle on the road; I went up, and heard the prosecutor say, "You must be a villain to use an old man like me so, who am a cripple, and blind with one eye;" I went up, found him lying on his back, and his hat seven or eight yards from him - I asked what was the matter; he said, "The man you saw with me has demanded my money, and knocked me down;" I said, "Where is he gone?" he said, "Over in this field;" I challenged in the field, but no one answered - I got a description of him from the old man, went on, and gave the description down the road; I returned in a few minutes, but did not see the prisoner till the next morning - I believe him to be the person I saw with the prosecutor.

SAMUEL DUNNER
. I am one of the mounted patrol. I received a communication from Allen - I found the prisoner near the spot where I was told the offence was committed - I heard something move in the field, and called out, "What do you do there - who are you?" No answer was given; I called again, and said if they did not answer I would fire - the prisoner then said he had gone into the field to sleep; this was about ten minutes before one o'clock: I told him to come out, and took him - the prosecutor saw him between nine and ten the next morning, and said he was the man - Allen said he was the person he saw with the prosecutor; the prisoner had nothing on him.

Prisoner's Defence. The first time I saw him it was about eleven o'clock in the day; we went into a public-house, and had a slice of bread and cheese; he said, "You look very bad;" I said, "I am out of work;" he said,"So am I, come along with me:" we went begging together, and drank all we got on the road - I should not have gone that road but for him; he pretended to be blind, and a cripple, and got money where I could not.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Life .

1291.
WILLIAM HEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of May , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
John Aaron
.

THOMAS CAPPS. I am in the service of John Aaron, a pawnbroker , of Whitechapel-road
- he has no partner. There was a pair of shoes hanging outside his door, twisted on a nail; I did not see them taken, but the officer brought back the prisoner with them, and I knew them.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am a Police-officer. I was on duty, and saw the prisoner with another boy; I watched them -I saw the other boy go and take these shoes; they went away - I went through a court, and met them; I saw the other give the shoes to the prisoner - I called the prisonerby name; he came to me; the other ran away - I took the prisoner to the shop, and they claimed the shoes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Whitechapel, and a lad asked if I would buy a pair of shoes; I gave him half-a-crown to go to a shop for change, and the officer took me.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined Two Months , and
Whipped .

1292.
WILLIAM INGRAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 1 pair of stockings, value 4d.; 1 shirt, value 6d., and 1 razor-strop, value 6d. , the goods of
Richard French
.

RICHARD FRENCH. I live in Brick-lane, Spitalfields
. These things were in my bed-room - the prisoner lodged in the same room. On the 14th of April I got up at six o'clock in the morning, and went out, leaving him in bed; another person slept in the same room, who got up, and went out when I did - I returned about twelve o'clock, and the landlady mentioned to me about a new sheet being taken off the bed; I went up, and missed these articles - I met the prisoner on the 18th of May, and asked him if he knew me - he said he did not, and I gave him in charge.
JOHN BOURNE. I am a pawnbroker. On the 13th of April, this razor and strop were pawned in the name of Wright, for 9d.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went to my lodging: the landlady told me the prosecutor wanted me at a public-house- I went there, and asked what he wanted; he said, "D-n you, it is all right, drink a glass of ale;" I did, and then he said, "Have you any objection to a young man sleeping with us?" I said if they had no objection I had not - he said, "D-n me, that is all right," and he gave me another glass of ale: at half-past eleven o'clock the landlord came to clear the house; the prosecutor said he would have some more, and he had some rum - he said to the other man,"You must stay till they are gone to bed;" he then came up, and we went to bed; I heard them talking in the night - when I awoke they were gone.

RICHARD FRENCH
re-examined. Q. Who was that young man? A. A butcher, named Lawson, who lived just by; I am certain he left the room with me; the prisoner was searched at the watch-house, but we could not find the duplicate - I asked where it was: he took me to two places, but the things were not there - he then took me to the right place.
NOT GUILTY .

1293.
SARAH SPALDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 1 cloak, value 15s.; 1 veil, value 12s.; 1 bonnet, value 12s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s., the goods of
Mary Ann Bird
; and 1 shift, value 3s.; 1 scarf, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, value 2s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. , the goods of
Harriet Bird
.

MARY
ANN BIRD
. I live at No. 3, Winchester-street, Pentonville
, and am a milliner and dress-maker . The prisoner came to me, and said she had been turned out of a situation for being out an hour too late; I took her in, and gave her a lodging from Friday till Monday, the 30th of March, when she said she should get a situation; she said on Monday that she was afraid she should not get a situation till the Saturday - I said she might stay, but she left me that day without notice; I missed this property from my bed-room up one pair of stairs - I had seen them about an hour before they were taken; I saw them again on the 16th of April, when the prisoner was before the Magistrate - my sister's things were found on her person.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you lend me this property to go to my sister's, to borrow a sovereign to pay your rent? A. No; you said you had no sister in town; you did not lend me 5s. on the Saturday night before; I was not taken to the watch-house.

HARRIET BIRD
. I am the prosecutrix's sister. The prisoner occupied part of a room; I lost a shift, a scarf, a petticoat, and a pair of shoes, on the 30th of March - they had been safe in my room an hour before; the prisoner gave me no notice of going: I did not see her again till I was before the Magistrate - she had my petticoat on; my shift and scarf were found at her lodging by the officer - my shoes have not been found.

COURT. Q. What are you? A. An upholdstress; I had known the prisoner at Ipswich; she was a servant - she was not an unfortunate woman, to the best of my knowledge; I met her in the street at Pentonville - she said she had lost her situation, and she came to tea; the next day, she said she was an hour too late, and lost her situation; I did not lend her these things; there was nothing particular happened at Clerkenwell the other day.
Prisoner. Q.Did not you lend me the body linen and the shoes, to go out walking with you? A. No, I never did.

SAMUEL MOUNT STEPHENS
. I am a constable of Clerkenwell. I was in this box on the 15th of April last, and the prisoner came into this Court; I took her into custody on the charge of robbing Mary Ann Bird - she had this veil on her bonnet; this cloak I found at No. 20, Speldhurst-street, where she told me she lived - the stockings she had on the prosecutrix claimed, but they were not taken off; this shift was on her - this scarf was at Speldhurst-street; the bonnet I found at Bell-street, Paddington, where she had exchanged it for another.

Prisoner. Q. Are you not in the habit of visiting these young woman? A. No; I have seen them repeatedly - I did call there once while you were there, to inquire for a person who was charged with taking a watch; I did not stop five minutes - I saw you there, and from that I knew you; you told me you came here to give yourself up to me.

Q. Did not
Harriet Bird
go for a quartern of gin, and you drink it with them? A. No; I never drank with them- I did not drink tea there; there were two brokers in the house, West and Evans, who I believe had sold her a bedstead - I do not recollect Mary Ann Bird saying if she were ruled by the officer, she would send you out of the country for life.
JOSEPH OADBY. I am a constable. I was with the witness Stephens when the prisoner was taken; she was very candid in telling where the things were - we took her the next morning to the place.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I say they lent me the property as soon as I saw you? A. Yes, but the prosecutrix contradicted it.

Prisoner's Defence. It was my misfortune to be seduced at an early age, by a gentleman, by whom I became pregnant; the offspring of my indiscretion did not survive its birth, but I was left before that event to earn a subsistence as I could; I did apply to my parents for forgiveness, but without success: at length I obtained some employ in the hat business, but unfortunately continued an acquaintance with the prosecutrix, which I had commenced before, and on the Sunday evening, from which I date my present misfortune, I called on her - she invited me to take a walk with her; she lent me some articles of body linen, as security for which I left some of my own with her: a quarrel afterwards took place between the prosecutrix and a lodger; the prosecutrix was conveyed to the watch-house, to release her from there - I lent her 5s. to give the watchman: on the following day she said she was distressed for a sovereign to pay her rent, and asked my assistance - I said I had a sister in service, but my dress was not suitable for me to call on her, and the prosecutrix lent me her bonnet, cloak, and veil to go to her; on my way I met the gentleman who first drew me aside from the path of rectitude - every other idea was then forgotten, and I spent a week or two with him, previous to his going to Liverpool, to which place I certainly should have accompanied him, but for these very articles; having disappointed the prosecutrix, I was ashamed to carry the things home myself - I met her lodger, and asked her to take them, but she refused; I then came to this Court, to see the officer, who I was aware knew her, to offer him the articles, to deliver to the prosecutrix, when I was taken into custody for an offence of which I solemnly protest my innocence. Since I have been in prison I have heard the heart-reading intelligence of the death of my mother; let all these circumstances be considered, and let my youth and the miseries I have experienced in my short career, plead in my behalf, and I trust you will not consign me to further disgrace on the accusation of one more experienced in crime than myself.
NOT GUILTY .

1294.
ROBERT WATTE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 child's cart, value 8s. , the goods of
David Field
.

DAVID FIELD. I am a labourer . I bought a little cart to draw my children out - I saw it about six o'clock in the evening in my kitchen; it was missed next morning at seven o'clock - it is a lodging-house, and we cannot keep the door shut - the prisoner is a stranger.
Prisoner. Q. Was it in use on the Sunday? A. No; it was sometimes in the yard.

WILLIAM JAMES
. I am a labourer - I live in Meard'scourt; the prosecutor lives at No. 1 Kemp's-court. On Monday the 25th of May, I saw two young men with this cart, in Berwick-street - I cannot say whether the prisoner was one - I went to Kemp's-court, saw Mrs. Smith standing at the door, and she asked me if I thought David had lent his chaise to any body - I went into the brewhouse, and saw the prosecutor's brother, John, who told me it was not lent; and I then went in pursuit of it - I did not come up with it till I got to Panton-street, Haymarket, Where I saw the prisoner drawing it; two other persons were behind him - I asked what he was going to do with it; he said he was a spring-maker, and he was going to repair one of the springs - I saw it had no springs - I told him if he came by it honestly, he would have no objection to go to the person it belonged to - he turned, and drew it as far as Rupert-street; the other two walked behind; one of them called out,"Bob, what a fool you are to draw it;" he made no answer, but walked on till he got to the corner of Archer-street. when he dropped the handle and ran off - I cried, Stop thief! a person got in the middle of the road, he turned back towards me, and I collared him.

Prisoner. Q. Look at me, and say whether I was one of the persons you first saw with it? A. I did not take notice - you did not ask a young man if he did not give it you - there were three of you; one had an iron footman in his hand.

Q. Was not there a person you had a communication with yesterday, and you said you were very sorry you had any thing to do with this business? A. I said it was a great deal of trouble - I was very sorry, as I was very near losing my situation - I suspect it was a person who had followed the cart - I do not think I told him to cut his stick, and say he was one of them.
THOMAS GOOK. I am a constable. I came up about seven o'clock, and James had hold of the chaise in one hand, and the prisoner in the other; I took the prisoner.

ELIZABETH SMITH
. I live in the parlour of the same house as the prosecutor - I saw the cart in the kitchen on Sunday, about eight o'clock; on the Monday, about seven o'clock, I saw two men taking it through the passage and out at the street-door - I looked out and saw James coming up the court - I told him to ask Mr. Field if he had lent the chaise; I did not notice the persons - I saw it again about eleven o'clock before the Magistrate.

Prisoner's Defence. I was turning Coventry-street, and saw two young men drawing the cart - I knew one of them, and told them where I had been; we walked down the Haymarket, and one of them who had a white handkerchief and a snuff-coloured coat, asked me to take hold of the cart, while he gave his parcels to the other men- I had not had it two minutes when Mr. James came up - I turned back, and asked the young man whether he did not give it me - I might have run away; but knowing I received it innocently, I scorned to run till I saw the other two running, and then I did run a little way.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined One Month .

1295.
JOHN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 2 china jugs, value 4s. the goods of
William Butler
.

WILLIAM BUTLER
. I keep an earthenware-shop , in Silver-place, New Road
. On the 10th of April I saw my jugs safe at half-past eight o'clock in the evening, and was showing them to a person - in a quarter of an hour I missed them, but did not see them taken - in about half an hour the watchman brought them - he asked if I had lost any thing - I told him I had lost two jugs; he then pulled them from under his coat.

THOMAS FORD. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner passing my beat at five minutes past nine o'clock, itis about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's - he had two jugs under his coat, and that induced me to stop him, as I had seen him before; he said he bought them, but could not say where, and was going to take them to his master - I thought it was not right, and took him to the watch-house - I went to the prosecutor who claimed them.
Prisoner. I hope you will have mercy on me. I have no friends.
GUILTY. Aged 12.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.

Judgment Respited
.

1296.
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 1 waistcoat, value 3s.: 1 shawl, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; and 1 purse, value 1s. , the goods of
John Prigmore
.

JOHN PRIGMORE. I am a tailor . The prisoner was my apprentice ; he had been twelve months with me; he absconded during the absence of myself and wife, on the 1st of May, between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning - I saw him, at half-past six next morning, playing at pitch and toss, in Elizabeth-street, Whitechapel - I had missed these articles, and a good many others; when I took him, he said he had sold the waistcoat and shawl -I found on him a purse, containing 4s. 5d. and two knives - he said nothing.

JOHN NORRIS
. I am an officer. The prosecutor gave the prisoner to me; his friends live near me, and his master thought he would come home; he found him playing with some sweeps - this purse and two new knives were found on him.
JOHN PRIGMORE. This is my purse.

Prisoner. Forgive me this time; I will never do the like again.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1297.
JAMES WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , 1 live tame fowl, price 7s. , the property of
Robert Tyler
.

ROBERT TYLER. I am a labourer , and live at Stanley Cottage, King's-road. I put my fowl in possession of Mr. Williams two months ago - it was a game cock; I heard it was stolen on the night of the 23d of May, and saw it at Queen-square; I know it by its feathers, and there are two or three feathers cut off at the front of the wing.

JOHN WILLIAMS. I had the fowl to take care of six weeks or two months before it was stolen - it was safe on Saturday, the 23d of May, and I missed it the next morning; the prisoner is a butcher - I do not know exactly where he lives; this is the fowl.
GEORGE UPWARD. I am an officer. I took this fowl from the prisoner on the 24th of May, between four and five o'clock in the morning; he said it was his own - I was not satisfied, and took him.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to Chelsea on the Saturday before, and saw a man with this fowl; I gave him 4s. for it - I was going to my employer's, Mr. Chorley, of Putney, when I was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Two Months .

1298.
ALFRED WILKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of a certain man whose name is unknown, from his person .

HENRY YATES
. I am a porter. I was in Nassau-street
on the 25th of May, about one o'clock; I saw the prisoner and another person go up to a gentleman - the prisoner took this handkerchief from his pocket; I had my knot on my shoulder; I ran and knocked him down - he got up and ran again, I pursued and took him; I had fifty or sixty people round me - this is the handkerchief.
Prisoner. Q. Were not you a Police-officer? A. Yes, for ten years; I lost my situation through not sending for a surveyor to inspect some goods at the London Docks.
Prisoner's Defence. I was walking down the street, and a young man dropped this handkerchief at my feet and ran away.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Two Months .

1299.
ANN WOODS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 chain, value 1s.; 2 seals, value 3s.; 1 key, value 2d.; 1 guinea, 1 halfguinea, 7 sovereigns, ten shillings, four sixpences, and and two promissory notes, for payment of and value of 5l. each, the goods and monies of
Henry Selwood
, from his person .

HENRY SELWOOD. I went home with this woman to her house in Westminster
; I had two 5l. notes, seven sovereigns, one guinea, and one half-guinea, besides some silver, a watch, seals and key; I was not drunk, but very tired and sleepy - she asked if I was going to give her something to drink; I gave her two half-crowns - she fetched some gin, and I had a little glass of it; when she came in with the gin she locked the door, I said "Don't lock the door as I must be off;" I fell asleep in the chair, and when I awoke she was gone, the door was open, my watch and my money were gone; I am sure she is the person - she stopped me in the road, and enticed me with her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you swear you were not tipsy? A. I was not; I had been out two nights looking after my master's barges, and met her in Tothill-street - she was the only woman who caught hold of me; I had been talking with another woman, but not stopping with any other; the other woman asked me if I was going to give her any thing to drink - she walked about the street with me, but I took up with this woman; I suppose I should have gone to sleep by myself if this woman had not caught hold of me - it was Duck-lane we went to; I cannot say what number; the officer told me the name - I did not tell the Magistrate I was intoxicated - I said I had been working two days, and up two nights, and I had had a glass or two; the last publichouse I was in was the Crown; it is in Westminster - we had a quartern of gin and a pint of beer between another man and myself - I left there before ten o'clock; that was all I drank besides the glass of gin the prisoner gave me - I had been on board the Fame, where I am employed; I left about nine o'clock - I had been in a public-house in the morning; we had a pot of beer there between three or four of us; I drank no gin or spiritsthere - I had no dinner, and drank nothing in the night but some coffee; the prisoner was taken the next day -I lost a watch, two 5l. notes of the Devizes bank, seven sovereigns, a guinea, and a half-guinea, besides some silver; I cannot say how long I was with her - I sat down and fell asleep: while I was asleep she robbed me; when I awoke the door was open, and she was gone -I cannot say what she was to get; one half-crown would not have got much; I only went to get something to drink - I awoke that night between eleven and twelve o'clock, but I did not see any watchman; I staid there till morning, then made an alarm, and sent for an officer; there was no one that I could see in the house - as soon as made the alarm they threatened to kick me out of the house.

EDWARD ALLEN. I am a Bow-street patrol. I saw the prosecutor on the afternoon of the 25th of April, in Orchard-street, Westminster; he stated what had happened - I went to No. 8, Almonry; he said he had lost two 5l. notes, seven sovereigns, one guinea, a half-guinea and his watch; he said the half-guinea was under weight, and rather bent; I found the prisoner at the house - he had described her; I said I wanted her for robbing a countryman of his money - she said she knew nothing about it; I took her, and as we went along I thought she wanted to put her hand in her pocket - I took hold of her hand, and found on her two sovereigns, this bent half-guinea, 11s. 6d. in silver, some copper, a handkerchief, and a pair of stockings, which were new; they were under her arm - I had before asked what money she had got, and she said only a few halfpence; when I found this money she said a gentleman gave it her the night before - she afterwards said she had saved it, as she wanted to go into the country to see her friends.

Cross-examined. Q. Are not these old coins very often under weight? A. I do not know; it was between five and six o'clock in the evening when I took her - I think it was half-past four when I saw the prosecutor; I do not know whether I was the first person he went to.
HENRY SELWOOD re-examined. Q.Who did you go to? A. I went to an officer's house between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, but he was not at home.

Cross-examined. Q.What time did you leave the house? A. I suppose between six and seven o'clock - I did not see any watchmen about; I called the people at the next door, and they talked of kicking me out of the place - I had only been in London two days.

Prisoner's Defence. I got the money from a gentleman I formerly resided with - he gave it me to redeem my clothes; the prosecutor and another female parted with me, and went home together - he never mentioned any mark on the half-guinea till it was shown at the office.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Life .

1300.
JOHN BARRY
and
HENRY KEYS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

THOMAS ROBERTS. I saw the two prisoners on the morning of the 23d of May, in Oxford-road; they followed a gentleman up Bond-street, and then they followed the gentleman whose handkerchief they took - I saw Keys take it from his pocket in Cavendish-square
, and give it to Barry; Murray was with me - he seized Barry, and I took Keys; Barry threw the handkerchief down an area- I went and got it; the gentleman said he lived at No. 21, Pitt-street - I have been there, but cannot find him.
Prisoner BARRY. Q. Where did you see me first? A. There were three of you sitting on a stool near Argyle-street.

BENJAMIN MURRAY. I was with Roberts, and saw the prisoners in Oxford-street; I knew Barry, and watched them - I saw Keys take the handkerchief, and give it to Barry; I took Barry, but he got away - I took him again, and he got away again; I pursued him to Cavendish-square, and secured him - he threw the handkerchief over some rails; the gentleman came and said it was his, and that he lived in Pitt-street - they both acknowledged in the office that one took it, and the other received it; I am a fancy steel-worker - I do not make a practice of taking people in the street, but if I see a felony committed I take the persons; I was a constable twelve months ago, and have been with Roberts before.
BARRY'S Defence. I was going along, and this man called out, "I will have you two boys," he came and took us - I do not know what he meant.
NOT GUILTY .

1301.
THOMAS BURDETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of May , 8 wooden ornaments, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Bowller
.

THOMAS BOWLLER. I am a tallow-chandler , and live in Carter-street, Bethnal-green
. On the 3d of May. between two and three o'clock in the morning, I lost several wooden ornaments, which were fixed to the front of my house; my dog alarmed me - I got up, and saw two men, one on the shoulders of the other, getting on the front of the house; I called, and said unless they got away I would shoot them - they got down; I saw them go down the street, and into a house at the bottom - I dressed, then went and listened; I heard the prisoner and another consulting whether they should go back - one said, "You heard what he said, that he would shoot us;" I got a watchman, who went down with me - the prisoner was coming out of the house, but the watchman would not take him; I know the prisoner was the man who was on the shoulders of the other - I knew his person well; I had seen the ornaments safe when I went to bed.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me with any thing in my hand? A. Yes, when you ran down the street; I cannot say what it was - I did not see him again till the 9th of May, when he came down the street with two others, and pointed up to my front; he went into the same house -I saw him again on the Monday; he was alone - I went and took him - I said I wanted him for a felony; I got him to my door - he knocked me down, cut my eye, and got away; I heard he was in the neighbourhood, and went to Worship-street - Garton sent three officers to take him.

GEORGE SIMMONDS. I am a dyer. I live in the house to which the prisoner went, and was alarmed by hearing some persons at the door; I got up, and went to get a light - I heard some persons walking in the yard, in the direction of the privy, and they were talking whether itwould be better to throw them down; I could not say what they alluded to - when they came into the room again, they said now the property was done away with, they did not care a d-n who came in; I know the prisoner was there at that time in the lower room, where two people live.

THOMAS FRANCIS MARMOCK
. I am a silk manufacturer.
