No, I do not; I do not expect to be prosecuted - I have not been promised that I shall not; I expect I shall not - I have seen my sister on the subject, and Mr. Butler, the solicitor; it is not in consequence of the evidence I have given that I do not expect to be prosecuted - I have been induced to give it at the entreaty of my parents, and because the prisoners have offered (I have reason to believe) to give evidence against me, that is my only reason.

Q. You said before your only reason was the pure love of justice - which of the two reasons do you stand to? A. The one I have just given, the first must have been a lie; I do not recollect swearing that that was as true as the rest of my evidence; love of justice had something to do with it - I consider I am doing justice by giving evidence, that is one reason; I wrote to Salmon, I think on the 11th of May - Martelly was in custody at that time, and I had heard the officers were after me - I had heard it about a week before; I surrendered three or four days after I wrote the letter - I had not seen the officer; I never absconded - I was not residing at any place at the time; I was compelled to get a living where I could - I was not hiding at the time I wrote the letter; I have lived on my parents since I have been out of employ - I lived very near them, at a place they appointed for me, nearly all the time.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Is this the letter you wrote to Salmon? (producing it). A. It is; and I wrote him this one - I put the first into the post, and sent the other by a little boy; I was clerk to Mr. Busby five years and a half - the fees I mention are clerks' fees, which come with barristers' briefs; the fees I embezzled belonged to Mr. Busby - Mr. Busby has since received mine, and is not out of pocket; he never made a charge against me before a Magistrate.

HARRIET PEARCE
. I live at No. 9, Surrey-row, Blackfriars-road, and did so in the beginning of May - I saw Coombs there in May, and a young man with him, who, he said, was named Conway; he said so in the presence of that person - I stated at Bow-street I was not positive of that being the prisoner.
Q. What is your belief? A. Why, on the previous evening a person called, and said his name was Conway, and I doubted it - I cannot say positively; the prisoner is the man I saw at Bow-street.

Q.Now, on the oath you have taken, do you or do you not believe that person to be the same young man you saw at your lodging in company with Coombs? A. I cannot swear to him; if I judge from what I have heard, I must believe it was him.

Q. From your recollection of the person at the time, what is your belief? A. I do not believe it is him, because he is very much altered if it is him; the lad that came with Coombs was fresh-coloured, and, as far as my recollection goes, was dressed in a surtout coat - I really have a doubt of the prisoner being the person, and should not like to take a solemn oath about it - I believe Coombs to be the person, but do not recollect Conway to be the person - I am half-sister to Martelly; I was by the same father - Coombs wrote a note in my presence; Martelly was in custody at the time - it was on Tuesday, the 4th or 5th of May - I believe this to be the note I saw Coombs write - the young man who was with him signed it; I saw him sign in a slanting direction, but I did not read the name he signed; I knew what the letter was about; I knew the first sentence, but I did not read the whole; I was not desired to have the conversation with them, at the request of my brother - it was of my own accord - I heard my brother was committed to Newgate for trial; I called on him, and asked if he was innocent; he said he was, and if I could find the young man, he could inform me he was; and if I enquired of the mother of the young man named Conway, I should find Coombs' address.

SAMUEL HERCULES TAUNTON. I am a Bow-street officer. I apprehended Conway in Great Suffolk-street, Borough, No. 96; he lodged in the front room first floor; in consequence of information I searched the privy in the yard, and found thirty-eight cheques and this paper with them; I received this note (looking at it) from Sir R. Birnie, on the 11th of May - I found this letter on Conway.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Conway lodged there: then it was a lodging-house? A. Yes; I did not inquire how many persons lodged there; there might be several for what I know - the privy is common to the whole house; I had a chimney-sweeper with me, and a person to pull up the seat - I took the cheques out myself- Conway was not present.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Did you see him after you found them? A. Yes: I took him before a Magistrate, then returned to examine the privy - I said nothing about the cheques in his presence, except before the Magistrate - I stated in my examination that I found them there; he made no answer to it.(The letters were here put in and read, as follows:)

DEAR GEORGE - I cannot go with you over the water, having work to do, which will detain me all the morning; go to the fakement and obtain the leaf, then it will be my ingenuity that will settle the slum and put the bustle in our clyes. I am, with every feeling of gratitude, your's faithfully, and truly for ever.
B. M. CAREW.
Have pluck; when done bring the leaf to my house - will be at home all the morning. Destroy this. B. W. HORNE.

To
George Coombs
, care of Miss Smith.
Friday, May 1, 1829.

SIR - The young man, Marlelli, who has lately been examined upon a charge of forgery on the Bank of Messrs. Coutts and Co., and who has been committed to take his trial, the writer of this feels it his duty to acquaint your Worship, is innoccut of the charge.
T. HAMERT.
SIR RICHARD BIRNIE, Police-office, Bow-street.
MR. HAMLETT. The signature to these blank cheques are not mine - there are thirty-eight all signed with my name; none of them are my writing; these cheques are not filled up with any sum.

ANDREW HINRICH. I am a solicitor. The prisoner Conway was with me about ten months as clerk; Mr. Hamlett, of Prince's-street, was at that time a client of mine, and communicated with me by letter; my clerk had opportunities of seeing the letters of my client's on business, but Mr. Hamlett signs his letters, deeds, and instruments different to what he signs his cheques; while Conway was in my service I had a cheque from Mr. Hamlett more than once, I dare say.

JONATHAN BUSBY. I keep a coffee-house in Pickett-place. I know Coombs and the prisoners by their frequenting my house for tea and coffee - they came separately, and I have seen them twice together, but not more, I think.(Cheque read.)
MARTELLY's Defence. I am perfectly innocent.
CONWAY's Defence. I am innocent.

MARTELLY -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 25.

CONWAY -
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury - before Mr. Recorder.

1317.
ROBERT ELEY
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

JOSEPH SCALES
. I am a butcher , and live in High-street, Aldgate. On the 23d of April the prisoner came to my shop, about eight o'clock in the morning, and asked for the carcase of a sheep for his master; I said, "Who is your master?" he said, "Mr. Lailey," and as he had come before on the same errand, I did not hesitate to let him have the sheep; he asked me the price - I told him 6d. per lb., it would come to 36s. 6d.; he took it away.

THOMAS LAILEY. I deal with Mr. Scales, and know the prisoner. On the 23d of April he was not in my service; I gave him no authority to apply to Mr. Scales for a sheep - he had left me three weeks all but a day; he never brought it to me.

JOHN GRHIMES. I am a constable of Leadenhall-market. On the 29th of April, about nine o'clock, the prisoner brought the sheep into the market, and exposed it for sale - I, suspecting him, went and asked the price; he said 3s. 6d. a stone, which is 5 1/2d. a lb.; I asked his master's name; he said, "Mr. Lailey, of Poplar;" I said, "Who authorised you to sell it?" he said his master would be there presently; I looked at the carcase, and said, "Why I think this belongs to Whitechapel," as I knew the score - he said, "Yes, it does; I got it from Mr. Scales, who killed it for master;" I then took him into custody, and he voluntarily said he had abseuted himself from Mr. Lailey for three weeks.
The prisoner put in a long written defence, complaining of illtreatment from his master, but nothing on the subject of the charge.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

1318.
WILLIAM TENSEY
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

JOHN SIMON ENGLEHEART
. I am a pork-butcher , and live in St. Martin's-le-Grand
. On the 25th of April, the prisoner came to me for a leg of pork, for Mr. Kingsford, of the Swan with Two Necks, Lad-lane, who deals with me - I never saw him before; I supplied him with it - it came to 6s. or 7s.; I asked him for the book which Mr. Kingsford generally sends - he said he had come away in a hurry, or something: on the 30th of April he came and asked for another leg of pork for Mr. Kingsford, which I gave him, and asked him for the book; he said he had forgotten it, and come away in a hurry; on the 1st of May he came again for a leg and a loin, for Mr. Kinsford; I let him have them - he came again in the afternoon for a loin; I had my suspicions then, but being busy I let him go away with it; and on the 7th of May he came again for a leg and loin - I gave it him, and sent my man to follow him; he stopped him - the value of all the meat is 26s. or 27s.

WILLIAM KINGSFORD
. I keep the Swan with Two Necks, Lad-lane. The prisoner was never in my service - I never saw him till he was apprehended.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Weeks .

1319.
THOMAS TADDELL
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

WILLIAM CLARK GOLLAND
. I live in Watling-street, and am a warehouseman . On Sunday, the 19th of April, a little after eight o'clock in the evening, I was coming from St. Bride's church, and nearly opposite St. Dunstan's church
, I felt somebody at my pocket; I turned round, and felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket - I collared him; I had a handkerchief in that pocket - he drew part of it out in endeavouring to extract his hand; I said,"You rascal, you are trying to pick my pocket:" he immediately said I was a rascal, and wanted to rob him - I held him; some persons collected, and wanted me to let him go, which I should have done, but somebody struck me behind - I turned round, and he struck me himself with all his might in my mouth, which bled profusely - he got from me, and ran up Bell-yard; he was secured in a minute - I have not the slightest doubt of him; he used the most abusive language a man could.

CHARLES READER. I am a law bookseller, and live in Bell-yard. I heard a cry of Stop thief! turned round, and secured the prisoner, who I had seen shortly before this happened - I had taken hold of him three minutes before for picking a gentleman's pocket, but the handkerchief was returned, and the gentleman declined prosecuting; I secured him, and a party kept soliciting me to let him go, as there was nobody to prosecute him; I let him go, and immediately found my own pocket had been picked - he did not get from me after Golland's robbery.
THOMAS LIGHTFOOT. I am a beadle. The prisoner was given into my custody - I saw nothing of the transaction.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Confined Two Years , and
Publicly Whipped .

1320.
HENRY TAYLOR
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT, Seventh Day.
First Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1321.
MATTHEW SKRUSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 table-cover, value 12s. , the goods of
James Grant
.

JAMES GRANT. I am a licensed hawker . On the 1st of June I was at the White Horse public-house, in Maiden-lane; I staid there - the prisoner came in soon after I got there, and sat at the next table; I went out between four and five o'clock - I went into a field near Kentish-town
; I put down my pack it being heavy - I was awoke by the rattling of the papers which my tablecovers were in, and saw the prisoner with my table-cover in his hands; I laid hold of it - he dropped it, and struck me; the officer took him.

WILLIAM LADWICK. I am an officer. On the first of June, between four and five o'clock, I was in the field; I saw the prosecutor, the prisoner, and three others - the prosecutor had hold of a table-cover, which he claimed, and said the prisoner had taken it; the prisoner said that he awoke the prosecutor up, or he would have been robbed by the others, and that he had been drinking in the same house with them, but the prosecutor denied it; the prosecutor said if he would go to the White Horse, and the landlord would deny that he had been there, he would forgive him; we went - the landlord said he had not been there, but the landlady said he had; I took the prisoner to the watch-house - he struck me in the face on the road, and was rescued at the Bellisle; I took him again at eight o'clock the next night.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you, on the first examination, swear to him as the man? A. Yes, and he was remanded, that I might find the parties who rescued him - I found a sixpence and some copper on him.

JAMES GRANT re-examined. The others were his comrades; I said to him, "Are not you the man who was drinking with me at the White Horse, a few minutes ago?" he said, "No - I am pot-boy at the King of Prussia public-house, and am gathering my pots;" he struck me a violent blow, and said he had saved me from being robbed by the others, but it was no such thing - he afterwards said he had been at the house.
Cross-examined. Q.Were you not asleep? A. I was nearly asleep; my eyes were shut; he had the cover in his hand when I awoke; I had not drank much - I was not tipsy.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Three Months .

1322.
CHARLES HOLLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of May , 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
Thomas Payne
.
THOMAS PAYNE. I am a publican , and live in Shoreditch. The prisoner was brought to my house on the 23d of May; I found my quart pot concealed in his basket.
HENRY STEBBING. I saw the prisoner take this pot from a butcher's steps; he put a cloth over it, and put it into his basket - I took him with it.
GEORGE SMITH. I am an officer, and took the prisoner - he has been one of the paupers of our parish.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it through distress.
GUILTY . Aged 51.
Transported for Seven Years .

1323.
THOMAS ROURKE
and
MARY ANN ROURKE
, were indicted for
stealing on the 3d of June , 1 bat, value 8s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 belt, value 6d.; 2 half-sovereigns, 7 shillings. 1 sixpence, and 5 1/2d., in copper monies, the property of
Thomas King
, from his person .

THOMAS KING
. I am a sawyer . On the 2d of June, about half-past ten o'clock at night, I was in the City-road- I was very much intoxicated, and fell in company with the female prisoner; I had at that time three half-sovereigns, a half-crown, two farthings, and some half-pence - I am not sure whether I had my hat on or not: I agreed to give her 4s. - I gave her half a crown, went to a room with her, and staid about a quarter of an hour; we then went to a public-house, and had something to drink- I there changed a half-sovereign, to pay for gin, and gave her 1s. 6d. more; she immediately ran down a court and I never saw her again till I was at the watch-house - I had had a silk handkerchief in my hat, and another round my neck; one of the farthings was of the old coin, and battered round the edge.

Prisoner
MARY ANN
ROURKE. He met me and another female - he asked us to have something to drink, and said he was ashamed to go into the house, as he had been drinking with his cousin, and had been lying down, and lost his hat; the watchman came up, and said, "Go on women" - we went, and the prosecutor followed us; he said he would give me half a crown, and when we got in, he gave me 2s. 5 1/2d., and said a farthing would make no difference.
Witness. I had been to see a young man in the City-road - I have no cousin in London; I was going home from the Macclesfield Arms.

SUSAN SIFORD
. I live in the same buildings with the prisoners. On the 3d of June, at twenty minutes before one o'clock in the morning, I was awoke by a noise - I got up, opened my sesh, and saw
Mary Ann
Rourke at her own door, which is just opposite mine; she looked up at me, and went in doors, leaving the door open; I heard her say to some person, "Eighteen-pence is my due," and a man's voice said, "Here are two shillings, give me 6d.;" she said, "I have not one, you look in your pocket and you will find one;" he then seemed to look and found one - he gave it her, and she said "I am quite satisfied;" she then said, "I am very hungry, I want some bread and cheese and porter;" he said, "It is too late, you can't have it" - she said, "I know a house where I can get it, if you will go with me, and then we will come home and go to ged;" she went out, and the prosecutor followed her without a hat - she ran away from him in less than a second; he stood in the middle of the court - in a few minutes the male prisoner came, went to the bottom of the court, and then returned to his own door, knocked, and said "Jane, are you at home?" he put his knee to the door, opened it, and went in - he staid a minute or two, then came out, and went to the top of the court, where the prosecutor was standing, as if to watch for the woman; he then went near the watch-box - the woman came and went up to the prosecutor, who had fallen on his side - she gave a signal to her husband, who went and put his hand into the prosecutor's right-hand pocket, and took some money out, then into his left hand, and in his waistcoat pockets - they went to their own house, and I heard the man lay down on the table 6s. 6d. and some copper, I think 5 1/2d. and a farthing - she said, "D-n your b-y eyes that is not all the money, I saw more money in his pockets;" the man then went to the prosecutor again, searched all his pockets, turned him over, then went back to his own house, and shut the door - I put on my clothes and went for a watchman, but I could not find one: I came back and got a candle, by that time the watchman had come to the prosecutor; he got him up - I said to the watchman "He has been robbed, and I will point out the person in the morning," and I gave the same statement.
Q. How do you know it was 6s. 6d.? A. I heard it counted on the table.

Prisoner
THOMAS ROURKE
. Q.What number is your house? A. No. 8; it is opposite, and I could hear what was done - I can see the door, but not into the house; I get my living by hard work, and selling old clothes - I go to fairs with my husband at Easter and Whitsuntide.

CHARLES CONSTABLE
. I was in the watch-house when the prosecutor was brought in intoxicated; another watchman brought in the woman who had seen him robbed - he told such a clear case, that I said "I must go, and apprehend these people;" I went with two watchmen - I knocked at the door; the man looked out of the window, and said,"What do you want?" I said, "I want you, Tom; come, and open the door" - he came down; I said, "It is upon a charge of felony;" I took him to the watch-house, and found this knife and 1s. 6d. on him - I then went back, and took the woman; she was not dressed - she took her pocket to put on, and I took out the money - there was 10s. 6d. in silver, 5d. in halfpence, and three farthings; at first she denied it, but afterwards said there had been a man with her who had lost his hat at Islington - on our way to the watch-house she said, "Constable, don't say any thing about my admitting that I had a man with me who had lost his hat; if you will not, I will give you half a crown."

RICHARD BLISSET. I am a watchman. I took the prosecutor to the watch-house, and told the officer what I had heard from Siford; we then took them into custody -Siford said she saw the man put his hand intoall his pockets, and then go and search the pockets a second time, and said she heard the woman make use of an oath, and say he had not got all the money.

Prisoner
THOMAS ROURKE
. Q. Did she tell you she had seen him robbed, till you caught her standing over the man? A. I was standing at the corner of Ebenezer-street, and saw you and the prosecutor together - there was a row; I went up to disperse it - I came back, and the clock struck one; I went round to the other part ofmy beat, came back, and saw the witness standing over the prosecutor - she then told me of it; her house is not on the same side of the way as yours; it is a very narrow place.

WILLIAM PATTON. I saw the female prisoner and the prosecutor together near the Britannia public-house door, about a quarter-past eleven o'clock - the prosecutor had no hat on; there was another woman named Jones with him.

THOMAS ROURKE
's Defence. I was at the White Bear public-house with all our men - I saw the prosecutor at the top of the court; I passed him, and knocked at my door -I came back, and went to look for my wife; I did not see her, and went back - she was in bed: the court is forty-seven yards long - this woman could not see to the end of it.

RICHARD BLISSET
. There is a large gas-light, which shows all down the court - the prisoner's and the witness's houses are so close, that you might shake hands out of the windows.
CHARLES CONSTABLE. One of the farthings is of the old coin - he said he had been tossing with it.
NOT GUILTY .

1324.
WILLIAM THORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 hat, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
John Hunt
, from his person .

JOHN HUNT
. I am a glass-cutter , and live in Golden-lane. On the morning of the 25th of May I was watching some buildings; I fell asleep, and at ten minutes after three o'clock the watchman came and awoke me - I saw a hat by my side; I got up, found my own new hat was gone, and an old one left in its place - I had only had mine one week, and gave 5s. for it; this is it.

WILLIAM FINCH. I am a watchman. I saw the witness asleep on the morning of the 25th of May, at a quarter before three o'clock; he had a good hat on his head - I went down the lane, came up again, and saw him asleep, with an old hat lying by his side; I told him of it - I took the prisoner the next day; he offered me 5s. not to take him, and said he had a wife and two children.

WILLIAM SMITH. On the 25th of May my brother-in-law came to me, and said he had lost his bat; I said,"This old hat belongs to Bill Bucker," which is a name the prisoner goes by - I have seen him with it frequently.
ROBERT LOCK. The prisoner was given to me the next day, at the office door; he said the hat he had on was his own, but we sent for the prosecutor, who claimed it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. That hat does not belong to him.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1325.
RICHARD THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 1 watch, value 30s., the goods of
James Maden
, from his person .

JAMES MADEN. On the 20th of May, as I was going down Angel-gardens
, with a woman, (I had been drinking) my watch was snatched from my fob; I did not see who took it, but I gave a description of it, and saw it at the office - this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. What time was this? A. Half-past ten o'clock at night; it was moon-light - I was not very drunk; I could keep up: I have known the woman three years, every time I came home from sea - I had been only two or three days on shore; I cannot say whether she was a woman of the town.

MARGARET BROWN. I was walking with Maden, and the prisoner took his watch from his fob; there were three others with the prisoner - I called out Watchman! and the watchman sprung his rattle; the prisoner was taken.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not see the prisoner taken? A. No; they all ran up Angel-gardens: we went out, about seven o'clock, to the London Docks for a walk; we had a pint of beer, and some gin - he had been drinking in the day: the prisoner and his companions shoved against us, and then took his watch; I was alarmed, but not confused - I saw the prisoner in custody, and knew him again.

CHARLES LOUGHTON. I am a watchman of St. George in the East. I was on duty. at half-past ten o'clock, and heard the rattle; I saw the prisoner come running towards me; I do not think he saw me - when he came up, he said,"There he goes, there he goes;" I said, "Never mind him, you are the man I want:" I went to take hold of him, but his coat was buttoned, and he got away - I pursued, and saw him throw something into a court: I could not see what - I took him, and my brother watchman found a watch in a court, where I thought he threw something.

Cross-examined. Q. You say he ran towards you? A. Yes, at first; I do not think he saw me, as I had a dark coat on, and my lantern was under the cape - there was no one running in the direction he pointed to; I was not more than five yards from him when he threw something from him - the court leads to several houses, but is no thoroughfare; the watch was about ten yards up the court - he made no resistance, but stood still, and seemed very much hurt at being charged with it.

WILLIAM INCH. I am a watchman. I heard the rattle, and came up; Loughton had the prisoner - I found the watch in the court next morning; the prisoner asked if it could be made up - I said I thought not.
Cross-examined. Q.What distance up the court was it? A. A good bit; the glass is not broken, but the case is gone - it is a brick court, and it was in the kennel.
JOHN HUNT. This is my watch - the case has not been found.
MARGARET BROWN. I bought this watch-ribbon for Maden that morning.
COURT. Q. How far is the court from where they had been walking? A. The watch was taken in Ratcliff-highway, and the court is in Blue-gate-fields, not a quarter of a mile.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been working at my father's; my brother came and asked me to carry a child down to his house, and then he asked me to have a bit of supper -I then said, "I will make haste home;" I sat off running, and just as I got to Blue-gate-fields I saw four or five persons running; I made a stop, and then thought I would not stay, as I am not used to be out late - I ran and met the watchman; I said, "There he goes;" as there were three or four persons running, I kept on gently running, and the watchman took me to the watch-house; in half an hour the other watchman brought in this watch, and said he found it in the court; next morning I said, "I never was guilty of any thing of the kind; I should not like to have my character spoiled, do you think it could be made up?" he said he thought it could: he asked if my friends were there; I said I believed my brother and sister were; and when he went before the Magistrate, he stated that I asked about its being made up.

MARTHA THOMAS. I am the prisoner's brother's wife. He carried my child home that night, and left directly; I suppose it was two or three minutes after ten o'clock - he said he should make haste home: our house is in High-street, Shadwell.
JOHN THOMAS. I am the prisoner's brother. He left work at nine o'clock that night, and went to carry the child home.
CHARLES LOUGHTON. It might be twenty minutes before eleven o'clock when I took him - I had finished crying half-past ten.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1326.
EDWARD GINN
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JAMEL OVENELL
. I live at Ponder's-end, and employed the prisoner on the 26th of May; I sent him to London with forty-four bundles of tares - I never saw him again till the 1st of June, when he was taken; he was to have brought me sixpence a bundle for them - what he got more was for himself; he was to settle as soon as he came home.

JOHN WILSON
. I am a constable of Enfield. I took the prisoner on the 1st of June - I told him the charge, he said he should not have done it but for Jessop, and that he had but 16s. 6d. of the money.
CHARLES JESSOP. I am in the prosecutor's service. The prisoner called, and took 6s. of Mr. Young, of Somers'-town, and several other persons.

Prisoner. Q.Where did I leave you? A. At Somers'-town; I had two bundles to sell, and four to go to the Bear and Ragged-staff public-house: you said you were going to the brewhouse to see how many tares they would want to-morrow.

Prisoner's Defence. Upon my soul and body, I came down with him to the tripe-shop, at Islington: we threw down seven dozen of bundles in the yard: he said, "Mind, and be sure you take care of your money," and give me 1s. of it - I had the money, and I said to him, "I shall overtake you - here is the shilling," there was a hole in my pocket, and the money slipped down; I ran back, and could not find it - I sent word to my master by two people that I would work the money out, and he said I should; I went to the field to work, and was taken.
JAMES OVENELL. He sent word if I did not choose to take him into my employ, he would lay a stick, which he had with a spike in it about my bl-y head, and he had that when he was taken.

JOHN WILSON
. He had a large stick with a nail in it.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined One Month and
Whipped .

1327.
MARY ANN IRELAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 1 necklace, value 50s. , the goods of
William Ferns
.

EMILY ANN FERNS
. I am the wife of William Ferns, and live at Pentonville
. The prisoner was employed by me; after she was gone I was going out, and missed my necklace from one of my drawers - I had left my keys there.
WILLIAM COOMBE. I am a pawnbroker. I have a necklace pawned with me on the 9th of June, by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSEPH CADBY
. I took the prisoner, and found the duplicate on her.
Prisoner. The prosecutrix promised if I would give up the duplicate she would forgive me.
MRS. FERNS. I did so, but my husband would not allow it.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined One Month .

1328.
WILLIAM MUNTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 purse, value 1d.; 1 sovereign, and 1 half-crown, the property of
Thomas Sedgwick
, from his person .

THOMAS SEDGWICK
. On the 14th of June, I was going out of Mile-end-road, down Dog-row
, between twelve and one o'clock - the prisoner and his companion overtook me; one came on my right side, and the prisoner on my left - the prisoner said, "Come, young man, we are two weavers from Twig-folly, we will see you safely home:" I said, "I know nothing of you - I would rather be without you" - I turned and called to a friend, and said, "Tom, come on;" he came up, and walked a little way before - I then felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket; I called out, "Tom, they are robbing me;" he said No - I said, "D-n their eyes, they are;" they then ran off - I missed my purse and money; I made a bit of a struggle after them, and got this stick from the prisoner - I struck him twice on the back of his head; that was the nearest I could get to him; he got away, but the watchman came up - he knew him; I gave him my address - the watchman had seen him, though he could not catch him; my purse contained a sovereign and a half-crown - I had it safe when I bought some water-cresses.

THOMAS JONES
. I was with the prosecutor - I stopped a short time, and when I came up, I saw the prisoner and his mate - the prosecutor said, "Come on, Tom, we are all going home together;" I looked at the prisoner and his companion, but did not know them - I walked on; the prosecutor said, "Tom, they are robbing me;" I said,"Nonsense, not they:" he then said, "D-n their eyes, they are;" I turned round, and saw the prisoner had got hold of the prosecutor's left arm, and then they ran off.

RICHARD BURTON. I am a watchman. I was coming out of the street from crying one o'clock - I saw the prosecutor, the prisoner and another man, in the middle of the road - the prisoner had hold of the prosecutor's left arm; I heard the prosecutor say they had robbed him - he called to Jones, and Jones called him stupid; he then said,"D-n their eyes, they are robbing me," and they ran off; I knew the prisoner before.
JOHN RADLEY. I received information from Burton,and found the prisoner - he asked what I took him for; I said he would find that hereafter - I found nothing on him.
Prisoner. You will see that at the Magistrate's - he said he took a wrong man.
The deposition being read, contained no such statement.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .

1329.
JOHN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 1 coat, value 20s. , the goods of
Timothy Roach
.

MARY ROACH
. I am the wife of Timothy Roach: we live in a passage in Berwick-street
. The prisoner lodged in the same room with us; last Monday week, I put my husband's coat into a box just before I went out, at twenty minutes after seven o'clock in the evening, and took out an apron - I left the prisoner sitting in a chair; he pretended to be asleep: I came home in a short time - he was there; my husband came in soon after, and the prisoner went into the privy - when he came in he had the coat wrapped up, but the skirt of it hung down; I was standing at the room door, and saw him go past - I called my husband, and said he had his coat; he would not believe it till he looked into the box, and missed it - he then pursued, but did not catch him; the coat has not been found.
TIMOTHY ROACH. My wife said the prisoner had taken my coat - I looked into the box, and it was gone; I pursued the prisoner, but lost sight of him.
Prisoner. Q. Is your name Roach? A. Yes; it is not Murphy.

SAMUEL LINDLEY. I am a constable. I took the prisoner, and said it was for stealing a coat from the prosecutor - he said he was no thief, and would not be taken by any body; he showed fight, but I struck him with my staff - he gave the prosecutor some wounds, and he has not been able to work since.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

1330.
JOHN WHEELER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 coat, value 5l. the goods of the
Marquis of Lansdown
.

JOHN GILPIN. I keep the Mitre and Dove public-house, in King-street, Westminster
. Lord Lansdown's carriage was at my door the day before yesterday, at a quarter-past ten at night - I saw a coat go off the box, and gave an alarm; the footman went round the carriage, and took the prisoner.
JOHN HARRIS. I am a constable. The prisoner was given to me with this coat.
JOSEPH MUSPRATT. I am footman to Lord Landsdown. I ran round the carriage, and saw the prisoner throw this coat on the wheel - I took him.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you not first see it on the wheel? A. No; he was not walking with his hands in his pockets; he had the coat - I saw him throw it on the nearest hind wheel - there were no other persons about; the landlord was talking to us; he said the coat was going - I ran round the carriage - on my oath I saw the coat thrown on the wheel.

Prisoner's Defence. I came out of the corner door - I went round the carriage; the coat was on the near wheel; I was on the off side with my hands in my pockets; the coachman caught hold of me, and said,"Where is my coat?" - the footman went and got it, and said, "Here it is;" and then he said, "There is no one here but this man, we will give charge of him, in fact, I will swear I saw him throw it."
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

1331.
JAMES WALLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 12 bushels of wheat, value 4l. , the goods of
Richard Booth Smith
.

RICHARD BOOTH SMITH. I live at Uxley Farm, Edmonton
. On the 12th of June, I detected the prisoner in my barn taking this wheat; he had taken it from a heap and put in another place - I had seen him before, but not employed him - I was called up by Hawtree, and saw a light in the barn - we went to put in a key to unlock the door, the light was then put out; we went in and found about three sacks of wheat, which were dressed, and laid separate from the heap which was not dressed.

WILLIAM HAWTREE
. On the Sunday night, at a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I went to get my horses to go to London - I saw a light in the barn, and called my master - we went, unlocked the barn, and found the prisoner there - we had waited outside watching him for half an hour; some corn had been made ready to put into sacks; it was thrown on the other heap at day-light.

JOHN CAMP
. I am a constable. I went about four o'clock in the morning to the prosecutor's kitchen, where I found the prisoner charged with having been in the barn; he said he was found there - I went to the barn, and near where they said he had stood, I found about half a candle, which had been lighted, and this stick which he had opened the door with.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

1332.
JOSEPH DUDLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 1 necklace, value 15s. the goods of
William Spicer
, from the person of
Emily Spicer
.

MARGARET EASTON. I know Mr. Spicer; he is the father of Emily Spicer - she is sixteen months old. On the 1st of May I took her out; she had a row of beads round her neck; we were at the corner of Gerrard-street
, and three boys came behind me, two of them stood at a little distance; I then saw the beads go from the child's neck - I turned and asked the prisoner for them - he said he had not got them, and ran away; I ran, and called Stop thief! but he got away - they have not been found - no one was near enough to take them but him.

ROBERT PRIDHAM. I was going along with a board of fish, and saw Easton running with the child - the prisoner ran down Porter-street, and looked to see if any body was running after him - he then turned down Newport-street towards St. Martin's-lane; I lost sight of him - I heard, when I came back, what had been lost.
PHILIP RILEY. I was sent for about four or five o'clock, and found the prisoner in custody, from the girl's description.
Prisoner's Defence. I was standing in St. Martin's-lane; the gentleman came and asked if I knew any thing of the beads - I said "No, I am innocent."
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1333.
ELIZABETH KEMBLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , 1 metal-cock, value 3s. , the goods of
John Farrant
.

JOHN FARRANT. On the 21st of April I lost a brewing-copper out of my barn; on the Thursday following I went round to inquire after it - on Saturday Mills brought me part of the cock: the prisoner lived about three hundred yards from me.

WILLIAM MILLS
. I bought this cock of the prisoner on the Monday, and when I heard of the loss I took it to Mr. Farrant.

THOMAS WHITTINGHAM. I went with a search-warrant on the 27th of April, to the house of George Kemble, to search for a copper; I found this part of the cock at Mills' - I asked the prisoner if she had sold it to Mills; she said No, she knew nothing of it - she afterwards said she had sold the cock, but she found it by the side of the road: her husband has absconded.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the cock by the the road.
NOT GUILTY .

1334.
ALEXANDER STEED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of May , 1 brass mould, value 20s. , the goods of
George Jackson
, his master.
GEORGE JACKSON. I am an ornament-maker . I had a brass mould brought to me on the 15th of May; I knew it to be mine - the prisoner had been in my employ for six or eight weeks.

PHOEBE CARNEY. I live near Tottenham-court-road, in the house kept by the prisoner's father. On the 15th of May I went into the wash-house, and saw this brass mould; I took it into my room, and showed it to my husband, who works for the prosecutor; he asked the prisoner if he knew any thing about it - he denied it at first, but afterwards owned it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not your husband tell him it would be better for him to tell the truth? A. No - the prisoner came in, and my husband said, "Do you know this?" he said, "Yes, I brought it from one of the men's benches, and I intend to put it back, but I brought it to show my father."

JAMES CARNEY
. My wife showed me this mould; I asked the prisoner where he got it - he denied it: I said,"Either you or I must have brought it here;" he then said he brought it to show his father, and he got it from under
Robert Henry
's bench.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not broken? A. One of the holes are; he said he meant to take it back.

GEORGE JACKSON
. This is my mould - it cost 30s. when new; it is very little the worse for wear.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1335.
JOSEPH WATTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of May , 1 load of hay, value 4l., and 1 load of straw, value 2l. , the goods of
Simon Trout
.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

SIMON TROUT
. I am a hay-salesman . The prisoner is foreman to Mr. Tackness, who was in my debt. On the 2d of May I was in the Haymarket - the prisoner came there in a gig, and said he wanted a load of hay and a load of straw; it came to 6l. 4s. - I said I could not let it go without the money, as I wanted to pay my men; he said,"I have a cheque in my pocket for 190l., and I am going to get it cashed at a banker's, and any time after I return you may send to my place; I will pay for them;" I sent between four and five o'clock, to Mill-hill-mews - my brother took the straw, and lowood the hay; I said,"The agreement is for ready money, mind, and bring the money back, but they returned without it.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How long have you known Tickness? A. Five or six years; I have taken perhaps 20l. of him; I have a bill of his returned for 18l. - he became a bankrupt on the 31st of May: I entered this hay and straw in a common day-book - I did not give credit to Tickness; I believed the prisoner ordered it on Tickness' account - I thought, as he was his servant, he had got his master's money to pay; I was not to allow him any commission - he asked for something to drink- I said I would give him a pint of beer or a glass of gin; he did not say he was going to Sir John Beresford's to receive money on his master's account - a man did call on me on the Tuesday, but I had taken a warrant out on the Monday, and on Wednesday Mr. Tickness' sister came, and said she came to settle it: half a dozen people came to me to try to settle it - there was a man called on the Tuesday; I said it was in the Magistrate's hands; some man did say if I would go up about four o'clock, but I did not hear him say I might take the receipt: he said the money would be ready - the Magistrate did not say I ought to take the money; he said it was a gross fraud: I have not offered to forego this prosecution if the bill was paid, and the money for the hay and straw; a man did call and say he came as a friend to ask me to settle it.

JAMES TROUT. I am the prosecutor's brother. I took the straw; I saw the prisoner and gave him the bill - he said, "You have 6l. 4s. to take back, I will go and fetch the money in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes and settle with you;" I had not unloaded the hay, but we did afterwards - he came on horseback in about twenty minutes, and said he had seen our master and settled - we came away without the money.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not tell you he was going to Sir
John Beresford
's to get the money? A. He did not; I never called there afterwards - he did not say when he had settled.
JOHN ISWOOD. I drove the cart with the hay - the prisoner said he had settled.

Prisoner's Defence. I said I wanted a load of hay and straw for Mr. Tickness; I said, "What time will you send it?" he said, "Between this and two o'clock;" when I got home there were six trusses of hay in the cart - I was called to speak to a gentleman, and went to a public-house to have something to drink - the man and boy came to the house and had a drop of beer, I saw neither of them afterwards; Mr. Trout afterwards came to the house and rang the bell, and said, "Have you got my money?" I said"No: I am going to Sir John Beresford's to get a cheque for 5l., and I will give it you, or you can have it on Monday."

WILLIAM TICKNESS. I am a stable-keeper, and live at Mill-hill-mews. I have known the prosecutor some years, and had dealings with him to the amount of 300l.; I have paid him myself 70l. - he never bought any thing of me;the prisoner has been in my service four years, and is so to this day - he is paid by the assignees of my estate; I sent him for this hay and straw on the 2d of June, and said his mistress would give him the money - he was to collect some money in the course of the day, and to go into the City for a cheque, but it was not paid; this hay and straw were delivered on my premises, and upon my solemn oath the prisoner derived no advantage from them - he receives his weekly guinea from my assignees.
MR. BODKIN. Q. When did you become a bankrupt? A. On the 30th of May; Mr. White, who lives in Kent, was the drawer of that cheque - I sent it back to him and got the property back.
NOT GUILTY .

1336.
HENRY WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 14 yards of ribbon, value 8s. , the goods of
George Simpson
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1337.
JANE GRAHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 2 caps, value 4s.; 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 2 yards of ribbon, value 2s., and 1 basket, value 6d. , the goods of
Charles Burrows
.

SARAH BURROWS. I am the wife of Charles Burrows - we live in Eden-court, Regent-street
; the prisoner slept at my house for ten nights. On Sunday night I went out nursing at Chelsea - on the Tuesday I returned and missed these articles.

JOHN VARLEY
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Lisson-grove. On the 9th of June the prisoner pawned this cap for 1s. 6d.

RICHARD BULL
. I took the prisoner. She said she did not care about going to the watch-house.

SARAH BURROWS
. This is my cap.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor's wife, she gave me something to drink, and then persuaded me to go and live with her; a broker came to seize the things - he gave me leave to take mine; she is no more than I am myself, and used to go out with me of an evening.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1338.
JOHN POWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Joseph Walker
, from his person .

JOSEPH WALKER
. On the 19th of April, as I was going down Holborn
, I wanted my handkerchief and missed it; I had not felt any thing done to me - I had it but a few minutes before; I saw the prisoner close behind me, and the watchman had the handkerchief.

GEORGE FORDYCE. I am a watchman. At ten minutes past eleven o'clock the prosecutor walked by me with a lady, the prisoner was close behind him - I followed, and saw him draw this handkerchief out of his pocket - the prosecutor seemed to feel some one pulling at his pocket; the prisoner threw it behind him, and it fell on my foot; the prosecutor turned, and said,
"He has got my handkerchief;" I said, "No; I have it."

Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking, and was going home - I passed this watchman, and saw him pick up the handkerchief; he laid hold of me, and said he saw me take it; I am a stranger in London, and am a native of Liverpool.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .
First London Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1339.
JANE HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 2 brooches, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
William Illman
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1340.
JOHN ALLFORD
and
WILLIAM MATTHEWS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 2 bookwriting-cases, value 20s.; 1 other writing-case, value 7s., and 1 work-box, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Benjamin Slee
, from the person of
William Pye
.

BENJAMIN SLEE
. I am a writing and dressing-casemaker . On the 12th of May I packed up a parcel of articles, and among them were three writing-cases and a small work-box, covered with tortoiseshell: I gave it to William Pye, to take to Mr. Lund's, in Cornhill - he came back without it; I know nothing of the prisoner.

WILLIAM PYE
. I received this parcel; I was going down Fleet-street, and saw a man taking some gold fish out of a bowl - Matthews stood looking at him; he asked if I knew of a place - I said No; he then asked how far I was going; I said "To Mr. Lund's, in Cornhill" - he asked if I had a place; I said "Yes, at Mr. Slee's, in Silver-street;" he went down a street, and I went on; when I got half way down Cheapside
. I saw Allford - he asked me if I did not come from Mr. Slee's; I said Yes - he said Mr. Lund, his master, had sent him to my master, and if he overtook me he was to take the parcel, and I was to go home, which I did.

DANIEL FORRESTER. I was going up Fleet-street on Thursday, and saw the two prisoners together; I took them to Mr. Slee's, and the lad identified them - he expressed no doubt about their being the persons; it was from his description that I took them.

ALLFORD's Defence. I was coming from over the water - I saw Matthews, and asked him if he knew of a place; the officer came and took us - the boy said at first, he knew me by my trousers, and then by the hat.
MATTHEWS' Defence. I never saw the boy.
JURY to PYE. Q. Was any one near enough to hear the conversation that took place? A. No; it was about a quarter of an hour afterwards that I saw Allford.

ALLFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

MATTHEWS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .

1341.
JOSEPH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April , 1 saddle, value 1l. 15s.; 2 stirrups and leather, value 2s. 6d.; 2 girths, value 2s., and 1 crupper, value 6d. , the goods of
John Champion
; and that he on the 10th of January, in the 8th year of His present Majesty's reign, was convicted of felony.

JOHN CHAMPION. I am a sugar-broker . I lost the articles, stated in the indictment, on the 16th of April, from Mr. Horner's yard, Upper Thames-street
- I had seen them safe a quarter of an hour before; I went to a sugar refiner's, and when I came back, the cloth was lying on the ground, the other articles were gone - I have seen the saddle since.

GEORGE KNAPP
. I am a pawnbroker; a woman came to my house, to pawn this saddle for 15s., on the 16th of April, about two o'clock - I stopped it; she said she would send her husband - the prisoner then came; I asked whoseit was - he said his master's, Mr. Arnold, of Torrington-square; I asked how he came to bring it here - he said he wanted a little money; I said, "You got it dishonestly"- he ran off; I pursued and took him.

GEORGE KNAPP, JUN. I came in at the time the woman was offering the saddle - she said it was Mr. Arnold's, of Torrington-square; the prisoner then came, and said, it was his master's - that he was a confidential servant, and had taken it to make a little money of; he ran off - I pursued, and took him; he did not say John Edwards brought it.
HENRY BIRGGS. I am an officer. I took the prisoner at the pawnbroker's - he said he got the saddle from some other man.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. On the 16th of April, business called me out; I returned at three o'clock in the afternoon - my wife told me John Edwards had brought a saddle, and wanted her to pawn it for 15s., but she said she could not go out then; I knew no more of it till I came home, when she said it was detained at the pawnbrokers' - I went there, and told them the same story.

WILLIAM DODD
. I produce a record of the prisoner's former conviction; I was present, and believe him to be the same person. (read)
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Life .

1342.
JOHN CARMAN
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Romeo Preen
, on the 3d of May , and stealing 1 gown, value 3s.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s. 6d.; 1 other handkerchief, value 2s.; 1 brooch, value 6d.; 4 sovereigns and 4 half-crowns , his property.

ROMEO PREEN
. I live in Somerset-street, Aldgate
. On the 3d of May, at ten minutes past six o'clock at night, I stood by while my wife locked the door - we went out, and returned home at twenty minutes before nine; the door had been unlocked, and was fastened inside - it was twilight; I broke it open, and found the prisoner there - he was a stranger; my wife had deposited four sovereigns and a half in a drawer, and they were gone - the shawl and other articles were removed from the bed-room, and were on the stairs loose: my family have the whole house - I do not know the value of the property.
Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. Was the prisoner sober? A. Yes; he made no resistance - he said he got in at the first floor window.

ANN PREEN
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I had seen the money safe at half-past eleven o'clock on the Saturday night; there were four sovereigns, four half-crowns, and a brooch.

JOHN DAVID
REED. I was returning home, and saw some persons at the door - I heard there was some one going up stairs; I went up the next house, and called to the people to watch at the bottom - no one came out at the top, and I went down; we broke the door open - I went up stairs, and found a flower-pot removed from the window, and several articles of wearing apparel on the stairs; I went down again, and found the prisoner in the cellar at the foot of the stairs - he said, "I am he: there is only me, don't be afraid" - I took him up.
JAMES ROBERTS. I am the officer. I took the prisoner and found nothing on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent of the money - I did not see it, nor remove the wearing apparel at all.

ANN PREEN
. These articles of dress were in my bedroom - I found them on the stairs; the prisoner said he was in distress, and this was the first crime he ever had committed.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1343.
MARGARET THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of May , 3 half-crowns, 1 shilling, 1 penny, and 2 halfpence, the monies of
James Holley
, from his person .

JAMES HOLLEY
. I am a chair-maker . On the 23d of May the prisoner came up to me in Little Moorfields
, between half-past eleven and twelve o'clock at night - I had a little talk with her, and then missed my money; she ran off to Short-street - two females there came up, and spoke to her; she threw down the two half-crowns - I am sure her hand had been in my pocket; I had three half-crowns, one shilling, and twopence.

JOSEPH SCARCE
. I am a watchman. I saw something I thought was not proper - I hid my light, and saw some money fall from the prisoner; I crossed over, and took her - the prosecutor picked up the money; he appeared sober.

JOHN PEACOCK. The prisoner was given into my charge. I received the two half-crowns and the penny; I found on the prisoner 1s. 6d. - she claimed 6d. of it, and it was returned; the shilling the prosecutor claimed - the prisoner then sat down in a chair; it was said there was no doubt she had another half-crown - I went to search her, when we heard a half-crown drop close to her chair.

Prisoner's Defence. He gave me 6d., and wanted to force me down the alley - I said I would spend it in drink, - he followed me, and wanted his money back; I would not give it - he then threw down his money in the road, and I was taken to the watch-house.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1344.
JAMES WATERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Palmer
, from his person ; and that, at the General Session of the Delivery of the Gaol of Newgate, on the 19th of February, he was convicted of felony.

HENRY PALMER
. I am a warehouseman . On the 28th of April I was passing Bank-buildings, Cornhill - I heard some person call behind me, I turned, and saw the prisoner in custody; I immediately missed my handkerchief.

JOHN HOLLAND. I am street-keeper of St. Andrews, Holborn. On the 28th of April I saw the prisoner and two others - I followed them, and just at the beginning of Cornhill
I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the witness' pocket; he gave it to one of his companions, who escaped; Perry has since identified one of the others, who is brought here on another charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I met a gentleman, who gave me a load to carry to the Bank; there was a waggon going by, and this gentleman said I had picked his pocket, but I had not.
SAMUEL HEINSON. I produce a record of the prisoner's former conviction; I was present at his trial - he is the same person (read).
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Transported for Life .

1345.
THOMAS KEAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 4 deal boards, value 3s., and 6 ends of joists, value 6s. , the goods of
Edward Holgate
.

WILLIAM STOTTARD
. I am foreman to Mr. Edward Holgate, builder , of Mitchell-street. The prisoner was in Mr. Wing's employ - he was working in Noble-street, where Mr. Holgate was employed; I got these boards out of the cellar of a public-house - I had seen them safe on the premises at half-past twelve o'clock that day.

GEORGE MIDDLESHIP
. I am a waiter at the Mail Coach public-house, Noble-street, Falcon-square. At ten minutes before one o'clock, on the 11th of June, the prisoner brought three baskets of wood for sale - we had bought some old wood of some of the men at the same buildings; I found this was new wood, and I shewed it to Stottard - my employer sent to Mr. Wing.

HOWELL GODDARD
. I went to the building to take the prisoner; he got down a ladder, and ran off, but I took him.
Prisoner. He told me to run away; if Mr. Wing was here he would know how it was - I never to my knowledge brought any of that wood; some of the working men were there all the time.

JURY to WILLIAM STOTTARD. Q. Are you sure it is your master's property? A. Yes - I found the fellow pieces on the premises; the men are not allowed to take any wood - they take chips; these are only part of what were gone.
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1346.
ANN McCORMACK
was indicted for
that she, on the 26th of February , feloniously did receive 6 yards of drill, value 12s., and 2 yards of jean, value 2s., the goods of
William Palmer
, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. RYLAND conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM PALMER
. I am a hosier , and live on Ludgate-hill. About two years ago I commenced the business of a tailor, and took the prisoner's brother into my service to measure, and cut out at the end of the shop - there was a partition between us; the prisoner was employed to make clothes - she used continually to come backwards and forwards to receive the clothes and make them up; in about two years I gave up that business, and dismissed her brother - in consequence of suspicion I went to Mr. Gray's, about a month ago, and there found some drill; I went to the prisoner's lodging with a search-warrant - he was searched in my presence; the officer has the duplicates found on her, and some others which were found in the room; I had not before that missed any articles, but I did afterwards - I have seen some articles which were found at the pawnbrokers, and compared them with some pieces of drill and jean which I have.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did the prisoner buy any thing, or merely come for work? A. For work - her brother employed her to work at the business, what he told her I cannot tell - my attention was directed to John Boston, who lived with the prisoner as a husband- I accused
Edward McCormack
and Boston, but one was acquitted, and the bill against the other was thrown out.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I am a Police-officer. I went to the prisoner's premises on the 9th of May; in a box, which was owned by Boston, I found five duplicates, and on her I found two duplicates, but they did not belong to any property which the prosecutor claims.

Cross-examined. Q. The box was claimed by Boston? A. Yes, but he said he knew nothing about any duplicates, and when Mrs. Boston came in she would tell me; when the prisoner came in I shewed them to her, but she made no observation.

JOSEPH AVANT. I am in the employ of Mr. Gray, a pawnbroker, of Fleet-street. I took in this drill from the prisoner, in the name of Mary Thompson, and gave her this duplicate; she had been there before.

JAMES TAGUS
SHORT. I am a servant to Mr. Brown, a pawnbroker, in Fetter-lane. I have a piece of jean, pawned on the 28th of February.

WILLIAM PALMER
. These three pieces of drill are mine; I have the pieces here to match them.
Cross-examined. Q.How do they match? A. In quality, colour, pattern and selvidge; it is impossible to see two of these things alike.

JURY. Q. Have these original pieces been cut since February? A. I have not sold one yard of them in my life; they were cut up for trousers - there have been a number of trousers cut off, but not since McCormack left me, which was in April.
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury. - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1347.
SUSAN JAMESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 3 half-crowns, the monies of
George Abbott
, from his person .

GEORGE ABBOTT
. I live in Moorfields, and am a porter . On the 28th of May, at twelve o'clock at night, I shut up my master's shop in Westmoreland-buildings, and was going home to my father's; the prisoner caught hold of me - I told her to let go, as I was going home; she wanted me to go into a house, but I would not - I gave her 2d. to get rid of her; I then missed three half-crowns from my breeches pocket, and told her she had them - she began swearing, and I said she should not go till the watchman came; he came up and took her - I did not go up any alley, or to any house with her; I cannot say what pocket I took the 2d. from - she had been behind me; three half-crowns were found on her.

EDWARD PAGE
. I am a watchman. I was on duty twenty minutes after twelve; the prosecutor cried Watch! I went up, and he said he had lost three half-crowns - I took the prisoner to the watch-house, and the officer found some halfpence on her; she then squatted down on the floor, and put the three half-crowns out of her mouth into her hand.

Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the three half-crowns and asked me to go and take a glass of liquor - he wantedme to go up a court, but I would not; he then took hold of me, and said he had lost three half-crowns.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Life .

1348.
HENRY SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a certain person unknown, from his person .

WILLIAM CRAIG
. I am a Bow-street officer. On the 20th of May, about eleven o'clock in the day, I was in Barbican - I saw the prisoner, and a person shorter than him, following a gentleman; I saw the prisoner go up to the gentleman several times, and make attempts at his pocket - they left that gentleman, went on to Finsbury-square, and then followed another gentleman up Chiswell-street into Beech-street
- I there saw the prisoner take a handkerchief from the gentleman's pocket; there was a cart going by, and I lost sight of the other, but I took the prisoner; I called to the gentleman - he said he had lost his handkerchief, but would have nothing further to do with it - I did not see it after it was taken from the pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. So you neither have the handkerchief, nor the gentleman? A. No; I have never prosecuted for stealing from persons unknown before - I did not think I was justified in taking him for an attempt.

CHARLES CLITHEROW. I am a City officer. I was crossing the street, and saw Craig with the prisoner; he spoke to a person who was with me, and asked if he was a City officer - he said No, and I took the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q.You saw no handkerchief? A. No; I searched the prisoner, but found nothing on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was searched, but nothing was found.

JURY to WILLIAM CRAIG. Q.Did you see the handkerchief? A. Yes; and he ran across the road - I did not see it afterwards.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined One Month , and
Whipped .

1349.
EDWARD CROW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of April , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Benjamin Soares Willis
, from his person .

BENJAMIN SOARES WILLIS. I am in the house of Smith, Payne, and Smith. I was on Ludgate-hill
, and lost my handkerchief from my coat pocket; I did not feel it, but was told of it - I had had it five minutes before; I turned round, and a friend pointed out the prisoner, who was about three yards from me, and had his hand in his right-side pocket - I ran up to him, pulled out his hand, and my handkerchief was in it.

GEORGE HUSSEY. I was walking with Mr. Willis; I saw the prisoner close behind him - I watched, and saw him draw his hand from Mr. Willis' pocket and put it into his own - I asked Willis if he had lost a handkerchief - he said he had, and took it from the prisoner's hand.

RICHARD AMBROSE
. I am an officer. I was standing by and took the prisoner; I found two other handkerchiefs on him, all of different patterns.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that his handkerchief was thrown at him, and as nobody owned it he put it into his pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1350.
MARY MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 5lbs. of beef, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Patrick Clare
.

JOHN VICKERS. I am servant to Patrick Clare, a butcher , of Fetter-lane
. On the 13th of June, about ten o'clock in the evening, I was serving in the shop, and saw the prisoner come across the street, take a piece of beef, and run off - I ran and brought her back with it.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she was intoxicated, and unconcious of having taken the meat.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1351.
MARGARET MADDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April , 33 yards of linen cloth, value 2l. 15s. , the goods of
James Dowling
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1352.
HENRY ROSETTA
and
JAMES GILMORE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a certain person unknown, from his person .

JOHN MURREY. I am a letter-cutter, and live at Westminster. On the 30th of May, at half-past ten o'clock at night, I was near Furnival's-inn, Holborn
; I saw the two prisoners together - Rosetta put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and took out a silk handkerchief; Rosetta, Gilmore, and another person crossed over, and I saw them all looking at it - I went to Simons, the watchman; he asked me to assist him in taking them - I look Gilmore, and he took Rosetta - I said, "The other has the handkerchief," but he got away; the watchman gave me the two prisoners, and went after the other, but could not find him - I went up Holborn after the gentleman; he was with a friend - they were both intoxicated; I wanted him to come back, but he said, "D-n the handkerchief, I will take no trouble about it."

CHARLES SIMONS
. I am a watchman. Murrey gave me information - I saw three persons together; I took Rosetta, and the third ran away - I gave Rosetta to the witness, and followed him up Union-court, into George-alley, but he got away; in the mean time, the prisoners were taken to the watch-house; I was beset by twenty bad characters in George-alley, and I believe if I had not made my escape, I should have been killed.
GILMORE'S Defence. I was coming home - I was taken hold of, and shoved into the watch-house; I was searched, but nothing found - I never saw this prisoner in my life.
Two witnesses gave Rosetta a good character.

ROSETTA -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

GILMORE -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1353.
WILLIAM CAPURN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2d., the goods of
William Thomas Nicholson
, from his person .

WILLIAM THOMAS NICHOLSON
. I work at Mr. Evans', the stove-makers. On Sunday evening, the 14th of June, between seven and eight o'clock, I was on Londonbridge
, looking at the boats; I did not feel my pocket picked - a gentleman told me of it; I then missed my handkerchief.

GEORGE THOMPSON
. I am a fisherman. I was passing, and saw a number of persons looking through the ballostrades - I saw the prisoner and another push in between the people, and they had the tail of a coat up between them - I saw a handkerchief pass from the coattail into the prisoner's trowsers; I seized him, and took the handkerchief from him - the other got away.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was looking through the rails, and a young man gave me the handkerchief.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1354.
JOHN DUCKWORTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Samuel Burton
, the younger, from his person .

SAMUEL BURTON
. I am a stationer . On the 11th of June, at a quarter past seven o'clock in the evening, I was on Ludgate-street
- I did not miss my pocket handkerchief, but received information, turned and followed the prisoner - he turned into a court, went into a passage, and the handkerchief was found in that passage, but I did not see him drop it.

JOSEPH BROADHURST. I saw the prosecutor on Ludgate-hill; the prisoner and another young man followed him - one of the two drew a handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket; I ran across the road, and informed him of it - the prisoner ran; I pursued him up Ave-Maria-lane - he went into a passage of a house; he came out- I stopped him; while I held him, a gentleman in the house brought out the handkerchief - I am sure one of them took it, but I cannot say which; they were close together, and the prisoner ran into the passage.

JAMES WILLMOTT
. I am an officer. I was coming down Paternoster-row; I saw the witness with the prisoner - I came up and took him; he said, "I did not steal the handkerchief."(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Greenwich-fair, and thought I would not go to work till the morning; several gentlemen were going down Warwick-lane - I went down a turning, and was caught hold of, but I am innocent.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1355.
JAMES NOWLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 12lbs. 7oz. weight of copper, value 8s. 4 1/2d. , the goods of
George Sex
, the elder.

TIMOTHY CONNER. I was working at Mr. George Sex's, Sen., Stonecutter-street, Fleet-market
, and moved some copper to the hay-loft, from a place twenty or thirty yards off.
WILLIAM FITZGERALD. I work for Mr. Sex. I was ordered by Mr. Pickrell to take some copper into the hayloft; I cannot tell how much there was - the prisoner worked there.

ROBERT PICKRELL
. I am a bricklayer. I employed these witnesses in repairs at Mr. Sex's: the copper was taken into the loft on the 4th or 5th of May: my scaffolding lay there - there were 60 or 70 lbs. of copper, and three pieces out of four were missing - they must have weighed near 60lbs.; I missed it on Saturday week - I have seen some like it since; the prisoner had access to the loft.

CHARLES JAMES LAWRENCE
. I am shopman to Mr. Stanley, of Shoe-lane. I have 28 1/2lbs. of copper; I bought half of it of the prisoner on the 6th of June; he said it was his own - he was alone.
ROBERT PICKRELL. I believe this to be some of the copper - there is no mark on it.
Prisoner's Defence. I had nothing to do with the copper.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

1356.
JOHN CRAWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 3lb. 4oz. weight of copper, value 2s. 2d. , the goods of
George Sex
the elder.

ROBERT PICKRELL. I am a bricklayer. The prisoner was employed by me at Mr. Sex's; I sent 60 or 70 lbs. of copper to his hay-loft, and saw it there; I was sent to look for it, and missed it - I believe this to be part of it.
Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. At the examination you said you could not swear to the copper? A. No; there is no mark on it.

CHARLES JAMES
LAWRENCE. I live with Mr. Stanley, a metal dealer. I bought about 11lbs. of this copper of the prisoner, on the 6th of June; he came alone, and said he came from No. 9, Field-lane, and his name was Curton.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not say at Guildhall that Crawley sold all but one piece? A. No; Nowland sold more than he did: I know nothing of the prisoner but by his selling copper at our shop.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .

1357.
JAMES LANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of April , 6 sovereigns, 1 half-guinea, 2 crowns, 32 shillings, and 1 crown , the monies of
John Patterick
.

JOHN PATTERICK
. I am a butcher , and live in Suncourt, Aldgate
; the prisoner lodged in the same room. I lost this property out of a drawer between the 19th and 22d of April: I have lodged there twenty-eight years - I am the last person out of the room in a morning, and take the key down stairs; I wanted this money to pay 9l., and it was gone; the prisoner was out when I missed it, but he could get the key of the room when he wanted it - I went down to the Sun public-house, and said I had been robbed; the young man said Jem had robbed me; I took the prisoner on the Thursday; he denied it.

SAMUEL PATRICK
. I am a street-keeper. I took the prisoner at Mr. Williams'; he acknowledged that he took the money.

JOHN WILLIAMS, JUN. I am a coppersmith; the prisoner was our porter. I heard this accusation, and asked him if he was guilty of the charge; he denied it at first, but after having proved every thing false which he asserted, as to getting a new hat, and some other articles which he pretended some person had lent him money to do, he said to the prosecutor, "If you will allow me, I will make it up."

SAMUEL PATRICK
re-examined. He took me in the cellar, and got on a chair; he put his hand in a hole, and gave me out two sovereigns and 14s.; he then got a crown from a dust-bin; the prosecutor said he could not swear to the two sovereigns and 14s., but the crown-piece he could.

Prisoner. I did not know any thing about the money but the foreign piece.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

1358.
HENRY SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 piece of tissue satin silk, containing 63 yards, value 12l. 15s., and 1 piece of tissue gros de Naples silk, containing 63 yards, value 12l. 15s. , the goods of
William Stewart
, the younger.

WILLIAM STEWART
, JUN. I am a commission-agent . I gave Reynolds a piece of tissue satin and some tissue gros de Naples, done up in a parcel, to take to No. 29, Fort-street, Spitalfields, about half-past twelve o'clock on the 1st of June - it was my own, and worth about 12l.; he was to deliver it to my sister - he was afraid to come home, and I did not see him till the next morning, when he told me a man had taken it from him: I afterwards saw an advertisement which led me to Mr. Attfield; I found the gros de Naples, and got it back.

SAMUEL REYNOLDS
. I am apprentice to Mr. Stewart. The prosecutor gave me these silks to take to No. 29, Fort-street - I met the prisoner in Moorfields, where there was a man joining a china jug, near the Catholic chapel; I did not know the prisoner before; he said to me it was a wonder how the man could do it - I said it was; he then walked on to the corner of Artillery-lane, when he asked me to go on an errand for him and he would give me 1s.; he said I might as well earn 1s. as any one else; I gave him my parcel, and went to the next door, the Ship public-house, and asked for some watch-cases and 10s. in money; as soon as he got my parcel he ran off - I ran after him, but could not find him; I walked about till one o'clock, and then slept in an alley in Whitecross-street; I am sure he is the man - I saw him again on the Saturday, and knew him directly.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I am an officer of Worship-street. I received information that a boy had been robbed of a parcel in the Artillery-ground; I went to the Green-gate public-house in Hackney-road, and saw the prisoner coming out of the parlour with this parcel; I pushed him back, and asked what he had got - he said he did not know, it was a parcel a woman gave him to carry - this was between four and five o'clock on Monday, the 1st of June; he was taken to the office, and the boy picked him out from among forty.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been out of work for two months; a person authorised me to carry it, and said he would give me 1s.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1359.
ELLEN LEONARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 4 yards of silk, value 14s.; 3 1/2 yards of other silk, value 14s; 3 1/2 yards of other silk, value 14s.; 1 1/2 yard of other silk, value 7s., and 10 yards of other silk, value 3l. , the goods of
William Jarrett
, her master.

WILLIAM JARRETT
. I live at No. 80, Wood-street, Cheapside
. I missed some property, and suspected the prisoner, as she had left my service without notice - she had been with me one month; I went with the officer and found a silk dress, a green silk bonnet, and this other property on the prisoner, which is mine.

HENRY TURNPENNY. I am a City officer. On the 8th of June the prosecutor applied to me, and I went with him to Flying Horse-yard - the prisoner was not there then; we went the next day, and while we were there she came in - this property was produced by the woman who kept the room she slept in; I asked her if there were any silks there, and she gave me these rolled up in this white petticoat, and said the prisoner brought them there; the prisoner said she bought them of her mistress for 13s. or 14s. - this gown and bonnet I took off the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1360.
PHILIP FITZE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

THOMAS PYE
. I am a projecting letter-manufacturer , and live in Long-lane - the prisoner was my apprentice . He has received money for me, and was to pay me when he saw me.

HENRY FAIERS
. I am a hair-dresser. On the 17th of of April I was in the prosecutor's shop ordering some letletters; I saw the prisoner serving a gentleman with some letters, and he paid him 3s. 6d. - a porter came in with a parcel, and the prisoner paid him 1s. 8d. for it: I left my address, and the next morning the prosecutor came and brought some letters - I said I was at your shop, and saw your lad take 3s. 6d. and pay 1s. 8d.

THOMAS PYE
. The prisoner only gave me 1d. - he did right in paying for the parcel, and if any thing else had come he should have paid for it - he did not leave me.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT.
EIGHTH DAY. FRIDAY, JUNE 19.
First Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1361.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , at St. Andrew, Holborn, 1 trunk, value 10s., and 84 pairs of shoes; value 17l. 10s., the goods of
William Bird
, in his dwelling-house .

WILLIAM BIRD
. I live at No. 3, Greville-street, Hatton-garden
; it is my dwelling-house, and in the parish of St. Andrew. Holborn, and County of Middlesex -I am a shoe-factor . On the 5th of May, about four o'clock, or a little after four in the afternoon, (I think it was on a Tuesday,) I put seven dozen pairs of shoes into a trunk; they were worth 17l. 10s.; the trunk was two feet six inches long - it was a common wooden trunk, covered with leather, such as goods are exported in, and at the bottom was printed W. A. P. and Co. No. 1, that was printed with a brush - I left that trunk in my passage about four o'clock; my outer door was open; I saw it safe after the clock struck five, missed it a few minutes before six, and a little after seven I went with the officers, Duke and Waddington, to the prisoner's house, in a place called the Hole-in-the-Wall, which is a passage near Brooke's-market, Baldwin's-gardens - he was not at home; we found there fifteen pairs of shoes, which were mine, and part of the shoes which I had lost, and which had been in that trunk.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Of course youhave a private mark on them? A. I have - I did not see the prisoner at home.
