Q. When you did see him, did he not tell you they had been left by a person named Burgess, for him to sell? A. He said he did not know any thing about it; that he was not there - I have no partner.

JOSEPH BURGESS. I am a bookbinder, and work at present with Mr. List, No. 4, Prujean-square. On Tuesday evening, the 5th of May, I saw the prisoner - I knew him before; I was sitting in the house of call, the Swan and Sugar Loaf public-house, Fetter-lane - a person came in and asked me whether I would carry a box; that person went by the name of Rushlight Tom, but I have since found his name is Thomas Gall; he asked me at first if I would earn a shilling, and said it was to carry a box for a gentleman - I immediately went out with him down to the bottom of Bartlett's-buildings, and saw Jones standing with the box; it was the best part of a quarter of a mile from Greville-street - the box was as Bird has described it; his is an accurate description, according to the best of my memory, both as to the size, appearance, and every thing: I asked Tom if that was the box, and the prisoner said Yes; I asked Jones whether it was all right, he said Yes. and told me to take it into Chancery-lane; he preceded me - I went into Cursitor-street; he was a few paces before, and went up White's-alley; I took the box to a house in Kingsbury-place, White's-alley - it was Tom's house: I suppose Tom had been walking behind me, as I did not see him till I got to the house: I took the box to the foot of the stairs, and was helped up by one of them up to the second floor - they were both there; when I got up to the second floor, the prisoner Jones paid me 5d., and stated that he would send me the remainder, which was sent; I ought to have had 7d., but 6d. came down in the course of the evening.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you observe the box particularly? A. I was not many minutes with it, so that I did not particularly notice it; I do not know what has become of Tom - I knew him by his frequenting a house I was obliged to wait at while out of employ, as it is a house of call; I did not know his house, but I saw him go into it, and heard afterwards that it it was his - I did not know it before; I cannot say he had not placed the trunk in the prisoner's care while he fetched me.

MARY ANN DAVIE
. I live at No. 7, Hole-in-the-Wallpassage; the prisoner Jones lived at No. 1 - he occupied the house. On the Tuesday evening in question, about a quarter before seven o'clock, I saw the prisoner coming through the court as I was waiting at my door - he passed close to me, and had a bundle in his arm on his hip; it was a large bundle tied up very tight, but I could see the soles of shoes through the cloth, it being tied so tight - I am in the habit of binding shoes; at seven o'clock I heard of the robbery, and gave information to Mr. Bird - I have seen Rushlight Tom at Jones' frequently; they were well acquainted - I saw Rushlight Tom at Mrs. Jones' house next morning, but the prisoner was then in custody; they were conversing together - I saw them at the window, but did not overhear any thing then; Sophia Hawkins was there: I have since seen her, and Jones' wife together.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you quarrelled with Mrs. Jones? A. She brought a parcel of low game to kill me nearly - the day after the robbery; I did not strike her - I went and fetched an officer; I did not swear at the first examination that I could not form an opinion what was in the bundle.

SARAH IVES
. I live at No. 8, Bream's-buildings, Kingsbury-place, and am the wife of William Ives. I know Rushlight Tom; he and Hawkins came to lodge with us a little before last Christmas - I saw a trunk brought there on the 5th of May, between six and seven o'clock in the evening; it was brought to my house - I did not see it go up stairs; it was taken out of my house by two men the same evening - one was a very tall man, and the other a short man; it was between six and seven o'clock - it was a dark coloured trunk, with nails in it; I took very little notice of it, and do not know whether it was covered with leather.

MARY MORANT
. I live in the same house as Ives. I remember a trunk coming in; it was carried out about five minutes after it was brought in - Rushlight Tom has absconded.

ROBERT DOWNES
. I deal in shoes, and live at No. 4, Portpool-lane; the prisoner came to my shop between six and seven o'clock on the 5th of May, with two pairs of shoes, and asked me to purchase them; I took them out of his hand, and told him they would not suit me - he said he would sell them cheap; I said No, they would not suit me - he said could I tell him where he could sell them, for he could put them in at a good bargain, them and a hundred pairs more - I said I had no money to buy them.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you not very deaf? A. I am, and was deaf that day, but he made me hear what he said - when a man speaks in my ear I can hear better than when he is at a distance, and sometimes I hear better than at others; he did not say he wanted to know the price as a person had offered to sell him some; I have made no mistake - he asked me to buy them; my wife stood outside the door - whether she heard him I do not know; she asked me what he came about when he was gone; my shop is about ten feet wide.

MARIA BROWN
. My husband deals in marine-stores -I manage the business, as he is a drayman; I know Jones. On the 5th of May he came in, my boy called me into the shop; Jones asked if my brother-in-law was there - I said No; he said he had some shoes which he thought would suit him as he is a shoemaker - I said he was not within; he said, "Well, will you purchase them;" I said No; I saw some in his hand, they appeared like men's shoes.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am a constable. I apprehended Jones on the 5th of May, between eight and nine o'clock at night; I found him in the public-house in Brookes-market; I had seen the thirteen pairs of shoes found at his house, and I found two pairs more there; when I apprehended him I called him into a parlour - he asked what I wanted; I told him I had come about the shoes we had found at his house - he asked, "What shoes?" I told him he knew very well what shoes - he said he did not, for he had not been at home since four o'clock that afternoon, and if I had found any, somebody else must have left them there, for he knew nothing about them.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner's lodgings on the evening of the 5th of May,and found some shoes tied up in this apron in a corner of the bedstead; I asked Jones at the office where his apron was, and he said that was his apron that the shoes were tied up in.
Cross-examined. Q. He owned it without hesitation? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BIRD
. I can swear to the shoes by several marks; I had packed them up myself for exportation - I did not make them.

Cross-examined. Q.Did you put these figures on them? A. No; here is 2222 - they are the private marks I speak of; I can swear to the hand-writing of the person who made them; I have lost seven dozen pairs altogether.

Prisoner's Defence. I never saw any thing of any box at all; these fifteen pairs were brought to me by Burgess and another man who I do not know; I was in a publichouse when Burgess called me out; I saw a man at a short distance with the shoes in his hand - he said he expected a seizure in his house every day, and wished to make some money; I said I did not understand him, but if he would allow me two pairs I would take them to Downes' to ask the value - Burgess said he would be answerable for the whole bundle; I took two pairs and went to Downes' - he said he had no money - I said I merely wanted to know what they were worth - he did not know; I then went to this woman to ask for her brother - he was out; I went home, carried the shoes down, and they are the two pairs found by themselves.
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 44.
Before Mr. Recorder.

1362.
CHARLES RICHARDS
was indicted for a
rape .

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 56.

1363.
JOHN JAMES
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Hester Roberts
, on the 27th of January , and stealing 15lbs. of pork, value 10s. her property.

HESTER ROBERTS
. I am single , and rent a house in Enfield
parish. On the 26th of January, I went to bed between eight and nine o'clock, and fastened the house; about four in the morning I heard a noise - I struck a light, looked at my watch, and it was four o'clock; I opened my bed-room window, and hallooed, Halloo! thinking if there were any thieves, it would send them away - the noise was at the back part of the house, which is only one story high - I then got into bed again, not hearing any more, and left my light burning - I got up at six o'clock; I found my doors open, and about 16lbs. of pork was gone from a pickling pan in the washhouse, the door of which had been locked the night before - I found all the back doors open, and the windows - the lock wrenched off the middle door between the kitchen and wash-house; the catch of the lock had been forced out - it must have been done with an instrument - I came to look about, and missed a basket and a few trifling things; I saw the pork again the same day; it was cut into pieces, and one bit where the leg was cut out there is a hook - I know my own cut well.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Was not the prisoner taken up, and set at liberty? A. That was about a hat; he was taken within half a mile of my house - I had seen him about once after the robbery, two or three months before he was taken, but I was not certain about him.

SARAH LAWRENCE
. I live at Enfield-highway - I have known the prisoner almost all my life; he came on the Saturday night before the robbery into the room of the house I lived in then; John Dearman was in the room - Dearman lived at the house; he called John Dearman out; it was between seven and eight o'clock on Saturday night, and he went out; and on the Monday night I saw him - he came and called
John Dearman
out again - he called him out twice on the Monday night - the last time was between twelve and one o'clock; I was in bed then - I was sleeping in the same room; he said he knew where the old woman's watch and her money lay - he did not say what old woman - Dearman went out with him, and a little before five o'clock they both came in together, and I brought the pork with them, which Mrs. Roberts afterwards claimed: it was tied up in a blue handkerchief - I have seen the prisoner about afterwards, but not so much as before the pork was put away; Mrs. Roberts saw some of it in a box in the room in which I sleep, the day after it was brought in, and said it was the pork she had lost - I did not at that time tell her what I knew about it; I was examined before the Magistrate on the Wednesday after, and there I gave an account of it - James at that time lodged about a quarter of a mile off; he and Dearman told me, if any thing happened, to take the pork out - I did not take it all out - I took out part of it, and buried it under ground.

Cross-examined. Q. You have told us all you know about it? A. No; while James was in prison he wished to see me - I went, and he said he would write to his sister, and I should have a sovereign if I would say he only came in to inquire about Tom Bedford, and that I only knew him by his dress; I was tried here myself for this offence- I did not at first know the pork was stolen; I told several people about it before I was taken up - I saw the prisoner two or three times after of an evening, but I did not know where he was to be found.

Q. Is not your motive for coming forward now, because the prisoner would not come, and swear falsely for you and Dearman? A. No; I was never in custody before; Dearman sent the prisoner a letter to come and see him, but I never asked him to come forward - I saw him once at the Cock public-house at Hounslow, and at the King's Arms public-house, about three o'clock in the afternoon - I never saw him at any other place, except of an evening; there was no officer to give him in charge - if they had come for me, when Dearman was here, I should have come and spoken the truth; I know nothing of his having been asked to come forward to swear an alibi.

JOHN WILSON
. I am a constable of Enfield. On Tuesday, the 27th of January, I went to this woman's house; Dearman lived there too - I found about 15 lbs. or 16 lbs. of pork: Lawrence was at home - the pork was in a chest among some clothes in a pan, and about two o'clock I heard Roberts had been robbed of pork; she went there with me, and there were only three pieces left - the pan was gone; she identified one piece in particular - when I first saw the pork it was in three or four pieces; I apprehended Dearman; and through the information of Lawrence I found one small piece of pork buried in the garden - I never could see the prisoner till six weeks or two months afterwards; we took him before the Magistrate about a hat, and then Lawrence was not to be found - he was taken upon this charge on the 12th of May; I found him in the house of a Mrs. Roberts, where he lived.

Cross-examined. Q. Perhaps you were not very active in looking for him? A. I knew he had been to several public-houses in our parish - I have been sent for, but he got away before I came - Lawrence cohabited with Dearman, who has been convicted; I never knew of her being with any body else.

GEORGE CASTLE
. I killed a pig for Mrs. Roberts. I saw the pork before the Justice, and believe it to be hers.
EDWARD SANDERS. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner on the 12th of May; he denied the charge.
NOT GUILTY .

1364
JAMES DALEY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William Sapsworth
, the younger, on the 2d of June , at St. Matthew Bethnal-green, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 cap, value 2s. , the goods of
William Sapsworth
the elder.

WILLIAM SAPSWORTH
, JUN. I am between seven and eight years old, and live with my father, William Sapsworth, at No. 22, Coalharbour-street. On the 2d of June, I was in Birdcage-fields, near Bethnal-green
, and had this cap on my head about eight o'clock in the evening - it was just by my father's house; the prisoner came up to me - he knocked me and my little brother down; it hurt me very much - he did it with his hand; my cap was on my head - I looked about when I got up, and could not find it; he went across the fields - I did not see him again till the second day after; he was then before the Justice at Worship-street - I am quite certain of him; my cap has never been found - it was seal-skin; I have seen him in the fields before, and knew his features - I cannot be mistaken in him.

WILLIAM SAPSWORTH, SEN. My son left my house between six and seven o'clock in the evening, and went to play in the fields with his brother, who is about two years old - he goes to church and to school; he had a dark sealskin cap on when he left home - I was informed his cap was taken; I went into the fields, and he was there crying- the cap has not been found; I am a labourer in the East-India Company's service.

ROBERT YOUNG. I am thirteen years old, and live with my father, who is in the Customs. I go to Finsburychapel; I can say the commandments and catechism - God will punish people who tell lies; I was in Birdcage-fields, on the 2d of June, and saw the prisoner: I had seen him before in the fields with other boys; I was sitting by the side of Sapsworth, and saw the prisoner take hold of him, and swing him round - he fell to the ground, and he took the cap off his head, and ran off with it; I ran after him, but he got out of my sight - I gave information to the constable, and he was taken on the 4th of June, near some fields; a sailor boy was with him - he said, "Good by, Tom;" I said, "That is the boy who stole the cap;" I ran and called the prosecutor and the constable, and they took him.

JOSEPH ROGERS. I am thirteen years old, and live with my parents. If I take an oath, I am bound to tell the truth; I was in the fields, and saw Sapsworth and his brother sitting down - the prisoner knocked him down, took his cap off, and ran across the hill with it.

THOMAS BRIDGES
. I am a constable, and live close to these fields; I received information, and went to Birdcage-fields, and saw the prisoner running away from Mr. Sapsworth - I ran round and caught him; I told him the charge; he said, "I am not the one;" I found a pair of scissors on him - he told the Magistrate he was not the boy who took the cap, but knew the boy who did.
Prisoner's Defence. The scissors are mine; I am in the silk line; I was not in the field at the time - I was at home at eight o'clock on Tuesday evening.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 14.
Recommended to mercy, on account of his youth.
NEW COURT, Eighth Day.
Second London Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1365.
HENRY LIGHTFORD
and
THOMAS WILSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of May , 1 diamond pin, value 30s., the goods of
Thomas Wick
, from his person .

THOMAS WICK
. I am an auctioneer , and live in West Smithfield. On the 18th of May, between twelve and one o'clock in the night, I was on Snow-hill
, with a lady - a female was behind me; I saw several persons, and the two prisoners were among them; the prisoners were together, and were at first behind me - they then came in front of me; Lightford shoved up against me - I asked what he did it for: he made no remark, but took the pin out of my breast with his thumb and finger; he went a little way back - I said to him, "You have got my pin - give it me, and go along about your business:" he said, "I have not got your pin;" in the mean time Wilson struck my female servant, who was behind - she called out Watch! and I held Lightford till the watchman came and took him: I do not know what became of the pin - it has not been found- the other persons were further up the bill; after I gave Lightford in charge, Wilson came up and struck me - I think he was two or three yards off when Lightford took the pin.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you mean that you gave Wilson in charge? A.Certainly I did, for striking me, and he struck
Catherine Conner
, who was with her husband, behind me; there were four of us together -
Sophia Aaron
was with me: a minute or two elapsed after I lost the pin, before Conner complained at Wilson striking her; we had no thought of taking him till he came and struck me - I saw them together, and three others with them.
COURT. Q. Do you think Wilson saw Lightford take the pin? A. His back was towards him, he might not possibly.

SOPHIA AARON. I was with Mr. Wick on Snow-hill. I saw Lightford take the pin from his breast - Wilson was about a yard from him at the time; I do not know whether he saw what Lightford did: Conner gave an alarm when Wilson struck her.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see what he did? A. He passed us to strike her - I turned round.

CATHERINE CONNER
. I was behind the witnesses - I did not see the pin taken; I saw Lightford near the prosecutor - Wilson then came and struck me, and I called Watch!

EDWARD BARTRUM
. I am a tin-plate-worker. On the morning of the 19th of May I was on Snow-hill - I saw Lightford and several others in company; he went up and assaulted the prosecutor - I heard him say, "I have lost my pin;" Lightford said, "I have not got it;" Wick said,"Give it me, and go along about your business;" he collared him, and called the watch - Wilson was by his side, rather behind him; I do not suppose he could see what Lightford did.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen Wilson with him before? A. Yes - they were sober, to my knowledge.

JOSEPH RICE
. I am a watchman. I took Lightford; in the way to the watch-house Wilson and two or three others attacked the prosecutor - I sprung my rattle; another watchman came and took Wilson - I will not swear that Wilson was sober.

MR. PRENDERGAST to
CATHERINE CONNER
. Q. Were not you struck first? A. Yes - there were five or six of them together; the watchman came to Mr. Wick before he came to me - the pin was taken before I was struck at all.

JOHN DELL
. I received the prisoners at the watch-house; Wilson was the most sober - Lightford had been drinking.

LIGHTFORD'S Defence. I was walking down Snow-hill, and happened to run against one of the women - the prosecutor and I had some words; I was a little inebriated, and challenged him to fight - I certainly did hit him in the breast, and he called the watchman, and gave charge of me for stealing the pin.
WILSON'S Defence. I was going home from my trademeeting that night - I saw a mob, and went up; I was tipsy, and do not know whether I struck any body or not; I went voluntarily to the watch-house.
JURY to MR. WICK. Q. Was it near a lamp you lost your pin? A. Yes - I saw it very plainly in his hand, between his thumb and finger.

LIGHTFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Life .

WILSON -
NOT GUILTY .

1366.
CHARLES WALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 2 crape handkerchiefs, value 1l. 14s. , the goods of
John Burbidge
and another.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

WILLAM WRAY. I am warehouseman to Mr. John Burbidge and another, of Bread-street
, Scotch and Manchester warehousemen . On the 8th of April, the prisoner, whom I knew, came to our warehouse between five and six o'clock, and asked for Mr. Burbidge; I said he was gone home - there were ten shawls lying in the warehouse they had been marked by me for a particular purpose - he staid about a quarter of an hour, and when he was gone, I missed two; I sent our apprentice after the prisoner - he came back; I asked him to walk in the counting-house, and taxed him with having the two shawls - he denied it; I told him I could not think of his leaving the place till he convinced me he had not got them - he told me had not; I wished him to take off his hat - he asked me the reason of that; I told him from a circumstance which had occurred some time before - he took off his hat, and gave me the two shawls out of it; he promised that he would return the next morning to see one of my employers, and I let him go, but he did not return - I did not see him again till Friday, when he was in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was be taken at his own house? A. Yes; by Mr. Burbidge - I believe Mr. Burbidge has known him ten or twelve years; I believe some of the female members of their families are related; I was not present at any interview between him and Mr. Burbidge - I know he came there with Mr. Burbidge; I was at the warehouse at the time; he was in the counting-house with Mr. Puzey, perhaps twenty minutes or half an hour - he was then given into custody; I am sure he did not say, "I have not stolen the shawls."
JURY. Q. Is the prisoner in the habit of dealing there? A. No; he came backwards and forwards as one of the family.

THOMAS PUZEY
. I am in partnership with
John Richard Burbidge
. I never knew his name was Richard till within the last ten days.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A.About three years and a half; he was in the counting-house perhaps two hours before he was given into custody - Mr. Wray had told me of the robbery.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is Mr. Burbidge unwilling to prosecute him? A.He would never give me an answer when I asked him.

HENRY TURNPENNY
. I am an officer. I received the prisoner at the prosecutor's house - these shawls were delivered to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner, in a long address to the Court, stated that this prosecution arose from vindictive feelings on the part of Mr. Puzey; that Mr. Burbidge had signed an instrument, declaring the prosecution was carried on entirely against his will, and had ordered Wray not to appear; that he (the prisoner,) had the use of the prosecutor's counting-house for his business at all times; and having an order for shawls, took these, not thinking it necessary to name it to Wray, as he was on such friendly terms with them; he then stated that Mr. Puzey had told a Mr. White, that he would not proceed, if he received 40l.; and that he, the prisoner, was in good circumstances, and could have no motive to commit such an offence.

MR. BARRY to MR. PUZEY. Q.Have you had any conversation with any person? A. Yes, Mr. White and another gentleman; I never said if I could have the 40l. I would not prosecute - I said I believed my partner put Wray out of the way; I am satisfied he was very desirous of getting him off - he brought him, and said, "Here is Wall, do what you will with him;" I believe he has lent the prisoner 500l. at a time - he had a good opinion of him.
Prisoner. Q. Had you a young man named Hobbs? A. Yes; he robbed us.
JURY. Q. Had the prisoner any dealings at your house? A. I believe not; I could not swear it; he might have bought a few things.

Prisoner to
WILLIAM WRAY
. Q. Did you not say"Mr. Wall, I am very sorry to ask you the question; have you not some shawls?" A. I did not - you denied having them; you gave them to me afterwards - I believeyou were not in needy circumstances; you had a good situation.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

1367.
ROBERT CANNON
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

WILLIAM DEVAS
. I am a Manchester warehouseman , and live in Watling-street. I know nothing of the prisoner, but on the 23d of April, I received a letter by a ticket-porter, ordering Irish linens and other articles; my son gave me the letter - in consequence of what is in the letter, I sent two pieces of Irish linen, and two pieces of calico to the Spread Eagle inn in Gracechurch-street.
WILLIAM DEVAS, JUN. I received this letter by a ticket-porter.

PHILIP SCOTT
. I took a letter to Mr. Devas, which I received from the prisoner at the coffee-room at the Spread Eagle, Gracechurch-street. (read)
To Mr. W. Devas, 70, Watling-street.
Stanstead Mount-fitchet, April 22, 1829.
SIR, - Please to forward per my son, on Thursday the 23d, to the Spread Eagle, Gracechurch-street, without fail, as below, will oblige your's respectfully, S.T. DAY.
Two pieces 4-4ths Irish, finest quality; two peices 7-8ths do. do,; two pieces French cambrics, very fine; six pieces silk bandannas, stout and good patterns.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Is it not possible you may make a mistake in the person? A. I may, but I believe him to be the person - I may make a mistake, but I am not making any mistake.
COURT. Q.Have you any doubt about him? A. No, not at all - I saw him, before the Magistrate the next day.

EDWARD BEDFORD
. I am waiter at the Spread-Eagle. On the morning of the 23d of April, the prisoner came into the coffee-room, took breakfast, and desired me to get him a ticket-porter to take a note - I got Scott, and he took it; I did not observe where it was directed; when the prisoner went out, he said there would be a parcel or two come in the course of the day, and requested me to take care of them; two parcels came - one I took in, the other the porter would not leave without seeing the gentleman; I gave the parcel I took in to the prisoner: I did not see it opened.

JOSEPH MARTIN. I am a constable. I went to the Spread-Eagle on the 23d of April, about half-past four o'clock, by desire of Mr. Devas, with his porter, and was desired to take any person in custody who might apply for the parcel; the porter left the parcel, and I waited till about a quarter before eight o'clock in the evening, when the prisoner came and asked the waiter if any parcels had been brought for him: he said Yes - one was left, and the other was taken away; the prisoner said, "Get me my tea," but in a minute, he said, "Give me the parcel, and I will take it somewhere;" I did not hear where - I permitted him to take it, and go into the street; I then went to him, asked him if his name was Day - he said Yes, but then recollecting himself, he said, "Not exactly Day; my name is Cannon - I married Mr. Dasy daughter;" I said I had authority to take him into custody- in going to the Mansion-house, he made an attempt to get away - he got a few yards, fell down, and was secured.

GEORGE LEWIS. I took this parcel to the Spread Eagle; I took it off Mr. Devas' counter in Watling-street, in Mr. Devas' presence - I saw it packed up by a gentleman named Hainson, in Mr. Devas' presence.

MR. DEVAS. These are the articles I sent packed up in the parcel; I know Mr. Day; he lives at Stansted Mountfitchet, and is a customer of mine. I sent the parcel, with orders that the person should be taken up, because the wafer of the letter was rather wet, which struck me as singular; and it was dated the 22d of March, which was the day before - I did not place any confidence in the letter.

SAMUEL TAYSPILL DAY. I live at Stansted Mountfitchet, about thirty miles from London; the prisoner is not my son-in-law, but he lived servant with me two or three years. I did not write this letter, nor give any body authority to do it.
GUILTY.

Judgment Respited
.

1368.
ANN LEARY
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
ANN FEELEY
. I am the wife of
Michael Feeley
; he keeps the French Horn public-house, in Barbican . On the 11th of June, at half-past nine o'clock, the prisoner came to my house, and called for a glass of stout; the girl served her, and she handed a coloured 6d., and said, "Give me change for this half-sovereign, and take for the halfpint of stout;" I stopped the 6d., and sent to my husband, who sent for an officer; I asked her if she had any more money about her; she said No; she was searched, and 1l. 0s. 6 1/2d. in good money was found upon her.

Prisoner. Q. Did I offer you that to give change? A. Yes, and I asked where she got it; she said in change for a sovereign at a house in Grub-street; I went there, and she had not received change there - we went to the Coach and Horses public-house, and saw the brother-in-law of the landlord; he said the prisoner had change for a sovereign there, but she had offered him a bad half-sovereign first, and he had given her one pound's worth of good silver; the prisoner then said she took the half-sovereign at the Seven Stars public-house, Whitechapel.

ROBERT HOWARD
. I am a constable, and took the prisoner. I found on her 19s. 6d. in good silver, and 1s. 3 1/2d. in copper - she was in liquor; I did not go to the Seven Stars.

- HENSHAW. The landlord of the Coach and Horses public-house, in Bunhill-row, is my brother-in-law. The prisoner was there that day, between half-past six and seven o'clock in the morning; she tendered a gilt 6d., which I would not take; a person followed her in, and said she knew it was bad, and she had offered it at a house opposite: I asked the prisoner why she tendered that when she had money in her pocket; she said, because she owed that person some money - I would not serve her; she said she took it at the Seven Stars.

Prisoner. Q. What money did I give you? A. You pulled out a sovereign, and some girl at the bar went out and got change for it, though it was against my wish; I counted it out before this woman, and told her to sound it before she took it away - she was partially intoxicated.

Prisoner's Defence. I changed it when I was inliquor. Since the time my husband was killed I cannot recollect any thing: I received two sovereigns from my brother; I knew no more what I was doing than the dead- I was going to look for the place where I took the change, but could not make it out; I thought I took it of this young man.
ANN FEELEY. She owned to me that she knew it was bad - this is the sixpence.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Six Months .

1369.
JOHN KING
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .

1370.
WILLIAM LONG
and
JOSEPH GOODMAN
were indicted for a
misdemeanor .

WILLIAM QUIN. I am a coal-dealer, and keep a shop in the general line, in Short's-gardens, Drury-lane - I keep a horse and cart. Goodman came to me on Wednesday, the 3d of June, about ten o'clock; he asked if I had a horse and van; I said, "No, I had a horse and two carts;" he asked what I charged an hour; I said 1s. 6d.; he said one of my carts was too small; I said, "I have another, come in and see it;" he said, "That is too large, it is for two sheets of lead, which weigh about 11cwt.;" but he said,
"Come along, never mind, I am in a hurry;" he got into my cart, and we went on to the bottom of Fleet-street; he then said,

"We have a job in the City; you go on, and deliver this to Walker and Parker, at Bull-wharf, Thames-street, in Mr. Briggs' name," giving me a letter, sealed up; I could not tell what was inside it: I took it there, and they delivered two sheets of lead into my cart- it weighed 13cwt. 3lbs.; I know nothing of Long.

SAMUEL BRIGGS
. I am a plumber, in partnership with my son,
Samuel Minton
Briggs - we live at No. 25, Dean-street, Frith-street. The prisoner Long was in my service; I know the firm of Walker and Parker, at the Red Bull-wharf - we do business with them; this order is signed, "S. M. Briggs and Son" - it is not my writing, nor my son's, nor of any one in my service - nor is it the name of our firm, as it should be S. Briggs and Son: we never sign in this way at all.

GEORGE ANSELL
CRIPPER. I am a clerk to Messrs. Walker, Parker and Co. I gave directions for the delivery of this lead, in consequence of the receipt of this order, which I believed to be from Messrs. Briggs; it was delivered to me while I was in the office - I do not recollect by whom, but to the best of my knowledge, it was our assistant-warehouseman; it was on Wednesday, the 3d of June, I delivered it to Quin, who gave me his card.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are you quite sure this is the very identical paper? A. Yes - it has not been in my possession ever since; I made no mark on it, but I feel satisfied it is the same.

JOHN SLOUGH
. I am a painter, and live in Chichester-place, St. Pancras. I know Goodman very well - I saw him and Long coming up Liverpool-street, St. Pancras, with a truck, about half-past two o'clock on Wednesday, the 3d of June - there was one sheet of lead in it; they drew it up to the side of the street, to a house not built, and shot the lead out - Goodman asked me to mind it while they got another; he said they were going to take it to John-street - he pulled off his hat, and wiped his face; I said I would look to it while I was there - they went away together; the constable came in about threequarters of an hour and took the same lead.
Cross-examined. Q.Had you known Long before? A. No, but I am sure it was him.

WILLIAM NICHOLLS. I am a constable. On the 3d of June I went to Liverpool-street, and saw a sheet of lead - this is a piece of it; I saw Slough there - I shewed the lead to a gentleman who is not here, and to Mount Stephens.
Cross-examined. Q.What did you do with it? A. Locked it up in a coach-house; I then took it to Hatton-garden Office.
SAMUEL BRIGGS. Long was in our employ - I believe this note to be his writing; it was not written by my authority.
Cross-examined. Q.Have you seen him write? A. I have seen his writing on a slate - I could not swear I have seen it elsewhere.
COURT. Q. Do you feel confident that it is his writing? A. Yes.

JOHN BLAKE. I am a constable. I took the prisoners in the Northumberland Arms public-house, Bagnigge-wells-road, about half-past five o'clock that day; I said I had suspicion that they were wanted for some lead, I must take them in, and wait for a person who would identify them - they said they had not done any thing, but if I had waited a little longer, perhaps they might have done something; they said they were both out of employ, and had a right to get the best living they could- I do not recollect their saying any thing more; I said if they said they were not guilty, and knew those who were, I would go and take them - Long said he knew nothing of it, and the other said he did not choose to answer the question; I asked where the lead was, and they both said they knew nothing about it - there were two trunks at the door of the Northumberland Arms, which I took on the Friday to Hatton-garden; I asked the prisoners whose they were, and Goodman, I think it was, said he did not choose to tell me.
Prisoner GOODMAN. Q. Did I not say if you would wait you might see the person who employed us? A. No, you said you might have done something.

SAMUEL MOUNT
STEPHENS. I am a constable. I went to the Northumberland Arms, and assisted in securing the prisoners - there were two trunks in front of the house, which we put in a cow-yard opposite: the name of Elliott, Little Sutton-street, was on one of them - I went to Brick-lane, Old-street, on the Sunday, and found a sheet of lead on Mr. Compton's premises; I took possession of it, and have a piece of it here - there is No. 4184 on it; the reason we took it was, because there was another sheet wanting, and from the marks given at the office we thought this was the sheet described by Mr. Walker's foreman.
Cross-examined. Q.Where are the marks? A.These are them - they are not so plain as when I first saw them; here are other marks on it - here is 25 1/2, 7020 and 20.

FRANCIS ELLIOTT. I am a Wheelwright, and live at No. 8, Little Sutton-street, Clerkenwell. On Wednesday, the 3d of June, Long came to me, between twelveand one o'clock, to hire a truck; I asked him what it was for - he said to take some lend from near St. Pancras church to John-street, or John's-lane, I do not knew which; he said he was recommended by Mr. Thomas, and, as I knew him, I lent Long the truck - he never returned it, but I saw it at the Green-yard on the Monday following; the officer told me he had it locked up - my name was on it.

THOMAS PARSONS
. I am a labourer, in the service of Messrs. Walker and Parker. I know these pieces of lead are theirs - I delivered two pieces of lead to Quin, and by the weight and the number I know these to be the same.

Cross-examined. Q.Where did you get these numbers? A.From the books; I did not put down the number at the time - it was put down by one of the clerks; I did not see it put down - I called out the number, and can recollect them for a day or two.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you see the number on the lead, before you put it into the cart? A. Yes; these are the numbers I called out that day, and I am able to say these are the numbers I saw on the lead.
COURT. Q. How soon after that day, did you look in the book? A. I got this account from the book the day before yesterday.

WILLIAM JADDINE. I knew Goodman by his living at a public-house, as servant; I have seen him score his beer, but I do not know whether he can write - I received this letter, but do not know who wrote it.
JOSEPH NEALE. I know Goodman's writing; this is his writing - I found this lead, and gave information to Mount Stephens, and he got it.
Prisoner GOODMAN. Q. I cannot write at all; where did you ever see me write? A. At Mr. Sims'.
Prisoner GOODMAN. I never lived there a day in my life. Witness. Yes you did, you have been there several days together, reading and writing, to keep yourself employed.

WILLIAM QUIN
re-examined. Q. Who went with you? A.Goodman, to the bottom of Fleet-street; he then said,

"I have to go in the City to see some more of our men: you deliver this note to Walker and Parker;" the note was sealed up, but I saw the direction on it - he said, "If I don't overtake you, take it to No.25. Dean-street, Soho;" but he came to me about the same spot where we parted, and said,

"I have a further order to take this to the Small Pox-hospital, where we have to gutter some little cottages" - I took it there, and Goodman took it from my cart; I came home, and thought it my duty to let Mr. Briggs know it.(The note was here read.)
To Messrs. Walker, Parker and Co., Red Bull-wharf, Upper Thames-street.
SIR, - Please to let bearer have 1 sheet of 4lb. milled lead, and 1 sheet of 5lb. ditto ditto. S.M. BRIGGS & SON,
June 3, 1829. 25, Dean-street, Soho.

GOODMAN's Defence. I was at Mr. Parr's office; two men came, and asked if I wanted work - I said Yes; they gave me a letter to Drury-lane, and told me to get a horse and caravan - I could not get that, but I got that the horse and cart.

GOODMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

LONG -
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury.

1371.
MARY STEPHENS
was indicted for
feloniously counselling and procuring Edward Turner and
Thomas Crowther
, to commit a robbery on
Thomas Davis
.
The same evidence was given as in the former case, see p. 574.
NOT GUILTY .

1372.
JAMES WATERS
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Leah Gooding
, and that she with a certain knife did strike, stab, and cut her, with intent to kill and murder her .
SECOND COUNT, stating his intent to be to disable or do her some bodily harm.

LEAH GOODING. I am not in any business. I came to London six years and a half ago, and met with John Perry- we were out-asked in Lambeth church, but we were never married: he is a watchman, and I have been in the habit of going to meet him of a morning when he came off duty, as the doctor said a little morning air would he the best thing I could have for my health. On Sunday morning last I met Perry with the prisoner, whom I had not seen for some time, in the Hampstead-road; it was about half-past five o'clock - I said to Perry, "How is it you keep Waters' company, when I desired you not?" the prisoner gave me a blow on the bonnet, which tore one or two rows off, and gave me a kick on the left hip - I cannot say whether it was with his knee or his shoe; Perry then interfered, and said he could not think how he could behave so when we had acted so kind to him, and he had been as a brother to us - they went wrangling on to the watch-house, and I went in with them; they still wrangled, but I desired Perry to give over and come out, as it was Sabbath morning - he came out with me; when we got to the top of the Mews I saw the prisoner again - I said, "Here is Jem Waters;" we just passed by him, and I said, "Come on," but Perry turned and so did I - words again occurred between us, and I dare say I aggravated him, as I said I should be ashamed of myself to behave in this way, after we had been so good to him - he knocked Perry down; I turned to get him off, and recollect I pulled his hair - he then pulled off his shirt, and said he would fight both of us.

Prisoner. You tore it off me. Witness. No: he tore off his shirt, and he fought right and left with both hands, and gave Perry such a blow as filled his mouth with blood; I turned again and made two or three attempts to strike him; he got quiet, and we passed along Little George-street on to Great George-street - Perry then said to me, "My girl, I have forgotten my key, we cannot get in" - I said, "If you go to the watch-house for it, you and Waters will begin quarrelling again;" and he was afraid he would quarrel with me, so we went back together - as we went down the mews, the prisoner was standing on the right side; I turned and said, "Jem, where are you going?" - he said "To the watch-house;" I said, "We are not going to the watch-house to say anything about you;" he then turned back, and went to some men and two women whom he had been talking to - Perry then went on to the watch-house, and I sat down on the curb - my cough came on, which I am subject to, and I heard Waters say.

"D-n my eyes and limbs, I will end my own life;" I turned, and saw him coming towardsme - I said "Is it me he means to stub?" I looked at him, and thought he did not look natural - he pulled something out of his jacket pocket, and I saw it come to my heart; he said, "D-n your eyes and limbs, I will be hanged for you;" I was no more sensible - I thought I was going into eternity - I was stabbed.
COURT. Q. How long was it from your leaving him to go for the key, and his striking you? A. Nine or ten minutes.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.You are very ill, I believe? A.Yes Sir; Perry is not my husband; I have known the prisoner about two years and a half; I do not know whether he has been much given to drink - I had not seen him for some weeks - he had been drinking; he looked not natural; when he came to me he appeared a good deal affected - there had not been a great deal of quarrelling with us; I do not know what length of time had passed - not an hour; it was about six o'clock when this happened - I cannot say how many times I struck him; I did not pull the clothes off his back - I do not know what this blow was indicted with; I thought my time was come and I was thinking more about another world - I had not made use of any foul language, and not a foul word came out of my mouth; I had not called his mother a wh-re; he had before that morning said I was like his old mother; we have had some bickerings together - I summoned him for 10s. which he owned me - I had called him a bastard that morning, perhaps ten minutes before I was struck; I wanted him to tell the Jury that - I did not strike him, nor raise my hand to him when I received the blow; I could not have thought he was going to do it - I had made two or three attempts to strike him because he first struck me - but that was before I sat on the stone; I have had a fright since, which has weakened me a good deal - I suffered more from the fright than I did from the cut; I have been ill three years - I have not been to a surgeon for this cut; I have not been using any unkind expression as to what I would do to the prisoner; I forgive him with all my heart -God is my witness; we were in a public-house on Monday, before we went to the Grand Jury, but I did not speak unkindly of him; I said if the law would forgive him I would - I did not say any thing about hanging - I hope he will not be hung; Mrs. Stephens and another person were at the public-house; I said as my life was preserved, I hoped the Lord would preserve his - I said nothing about his not having means to procure a professional adviser.

COURT. Q. I think I understand, that when you sat on the curb there were no words between you? A. No; There had been no words for five minutes between us -Perry had left us to go to the watch-house, and Waters went up the mews to speak to his company; he had spoken to them - I heard him say, "D-n my eyes and limbs I will go and end my own life;" it was before Perry and he fought - I had called him a bastard.

JOHN PERRY. I was with the witness; we met the prisoner coming off duty, about half-past five o'clock or a quarter to six; something occurred between us and he struck me - Godding asked me why I kept his company, when it was not agreeable to her; she said something to him and he made her an answer, but I did not hear what it was - in going to the watch-house she spoke to him about his ill treatment of us, and he struck her; I stood in my own defence, and he struck me - I said I did not think he would behave so to us - we went down the mews and had some angry words about his striking her; when we got to the watch-house he struck his hand on the table and wished to fight me, but I would not - we came out, he struck me, and I struck him; he knocked me down in the road, and I said "I am ashamed of your striking us, as we have behaved so well to you;" we parted, and I went on to Great James-street - I said to Godding "I have forgotten the key of the street door, I must go back to the watch-house or we cannot get in;" she said "Let me go with you;" the prisoner was at some distance - we were going back, passed him, and left him at the top of the mews; as we were going down, Godding said "I will stop here," and she sat down on the curbstone - while I was in the watch-house she was brought in in a young man's arms.

Cross-examined. Q.How long have you known the prisoner? A.Near five years; we are both watchmen, and our beats join each other - we had passed the previous evening together and then been on duty; in the morning he and I had a pot of beer together at five o'clock, when we left duty - I had had a small glass of rum, and we had a quartern of gin between us - it was at the New inn - I had the glass of rum before I joined with the prisoner; we went into the New inn together, but I drank my rum at the bar and he was at the door - he must have known I had it; I then had the beer with him - we had the gin at the King's Head public-house at the corner of New-road; I had a pint or porter before I went on duty, at the
Mortimer Arms
public-house, Tottenham-court-road, but he was not there - he was fresh in liquor that morning, and I was pretty fair; I had not had many bickerings with him - I did not strike him above once or twice; he knocked me down, and then Godding came up to him - I did not call him any ill-name, nor did she in my presence; I had not been absent from her till parted at the mews.
COURT. Q.Did you not hear her call him a bastard? A. Not at all.

ROBERT MEARS. I am a hackney-coach master. I was present when the prisoner and the witnesses were together in Hampstead-road, at a quarter before six o'clock; I heard them quarrel - I saw the prisoner strike Perry; they then walked away, and Perry went back to the mews, with Godding - I saw the prisoner come round the corner from the Hampstead-road, with his hands in his jacket pockets; when Godding saw him coming, she rose from the curb-stone, and leaned against the house - when Perry came nearly opposite her, he pulled his right hand from his pocket, and forced it against her left breast, drew back his hand, and threw a knife down; I ran and caught hold of his right arm - he said, "I know my doom- I shall be hanged at Newgate; I resign myself up to you."
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. Six months; I never quarrelled with him, nor joined in any prosecution for which a man was transported.

JOHN OWEN
. I am a coachman. I was in Hampstead-road last Sunday morning; Godding and the prisoner had some words - I was not near enough to hear any words; I saw the prisoner go down the yard, and strike the woman on the left breast - that was, perhaps, ten minutes after the first quarrel; they seemed to part after thequarrelling - I then saw him strike her, but I do no know with what; I did not see the knife till I was at the office.
Cross-examined. Q.Was not the prisoner's back to you? A. Yes - I was a good bit off; it seemed to me that she aggravated him very much - she seemed like a woman in a rage.

TIMOTHY BYRCUMORE
. I produce this knife, which was given me by Mears; the prisoner came into the watch-house without a shirt, and looked like a madman.

WILLIAM JAMESON. I went to the watch-house, and found the prisoner in one of the cells: he began by stating that Perrys' wife had called him a rogue, and a rascal, said his mother was a wh-e, and he was a bastard - I said "You had better compose yourself; where is your shirt?" he said they tore it off: I went and consulted about searching him - when I went back to him, he said he had done it, and he should be hanged next Monday week; in going from the watch-house he met Perry, and said to him."Jack, I have killed your wife; I shall be hanged tomorrow week;" he sent me word afterwards that he had a present to make me, if I would come and see him hanged - he afterwards begged me to go for a shirt for him; I went to his sister-in-law - she said she could not get out, as her two children were had with the measles, and I took it him in the evening; he stated that Mrs. Perry was the cause of his not marrying a girl he had kept company with some time.
Cross-examined. Q.What took you to the watch-house? A. I go there for letters and orders for the Commissioners; I am street-keeper - I did not think any harm of speaking to the prisoner.
LEAH GOODING re-examined. I was stabbed in my left breast, and a little on my arm; he did keep company with a young woman - I know they were asked in church, and I persuaded her to marry him.

EDWARD PARKER. I am a porter, and live in Tottenham-court-road. I have known the prisoner six years - he bears a humane character; he got a hurt, and has not been well since - for the last three months he has been drinking more like a madman than any thing else, and when he drinks he is overcome by it; he has, complained of his head and side.

JOHN CAMPBELL. I am a watchman, and have known the prisoner five years. I and my fellow servant got to the watch-house just before him, and the prosecutrix - I heard her say Perry was with that d-d villain Waters - she ran to him, and struck him repeatedly; he thrust her away with his hand and foot.

EDWARD TALBOT. I am a watchman. I was going to the watch-house, and saw the prosecutrix strike the prisoner several times; and as she passed me she struck Perry, and said, "You are not a man, for not taking my part."
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1373.
GEORGE YOUNG
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Mary Grant
, on the 11th of April , putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 1 sovereign, 4 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 3 sixpences , the property of
Alexander Grant
.

MARY GRANT
. I am the wife of
Alexander Grant
; the prisoner lodged above me; Mr. King holds the house, and I lodged there - the prisoner had lodged there a quarter of a year, and is a painter . On the 11th of April, about five o'clock, or a little after, I returned home with a pocketbook and 1/2lb. of tea, tied in a white handkerchief - there was a sovereign, seven half-crowns, some shillings, and 6d. in halfpence, in the pocket-book; the prisoner was at the door, and he began in his foolish way, as he does when he is tipsy - I said, "Let me in;" he played tricks and molested me in the passage, and on the stairs he began violence; it continued till he got up to the landing-place: he then said, "I will have none of your b-y soup; I will have what you have got here;" he began to beat me, and snatched it by violence from me - he had not beaten me before that, only pulled me about; the handkerchief came untied, but I held it, and received more violence than I should have; the door opened, and I threw them on the bed - he got the pocket-book, but the tea went on the bed- I then swooned away: I said nothing more that night. but next morning I went to his room, about five o'clock - he did not appear sober then; I asked him to give me the pocket-book and papers; he said, "I don't recollect, she is not at home; but if you want a few shillings, I can lend them to you;" he cohabited with a woman of the name of Parker - I never got my book or money: he followed me down, and gave me three blows on the back of my neck, he said, "Where is your b-y pocket-book now?" and mentioned such words as I cannot repeat.
NOT GUILTY .

1374.
MARY MOODY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Henrickson
, on the 25th of May , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 3 sovereigns , his monies.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1375.
JOSEPH BYRON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , at St. Anne, 2 pins, value 4s.; 1 brooch, value 4s.; 3 coats, value 6l.; 4 pairs of trousers, value 2l.; 1 handkerchief, value 4s.; 1 box, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 12s.; 1 shirt, value 5s.; 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 5 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the property of
William Hunt
, in his dwelling-house .

JANE HUNT. I am the wife of William Hunt - he lives at No. 22, Phoebe-street, Limehouse, in the parish of St. Anne
. The prisoner lodged at my house, with two other young men - he came on the 13th of May; he was there two or three nights; the then said he was going to Yorkshire; some of this property was in drawers, and some in a trunk - he slept there on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday nights. On the Friday evening I put my pocketbook into the trunk, in the room in which he slept, and on the Saturday morning I missed it, when I went to get the money - he had left that morning, and said he was going to Yorkshire, by the steamer, on the Monday morning; he had paid me, but I thought he was coming again on the Saturday night and Sunday, but he did not return: I have only seen the coat since, which had been in the trunk - I lost two pins, a brooch, three coats, four pairs of trousers, and various other articles, and five sovereigns; the value of the whole was 10l. - I have only seen one coat. On Saturday, the 6th of June, I met the prisoner in the Commercial-road; I took him by the arm, and said, "You are the thief that robbed me!" he never spoke to me.
Prisoner. Q. Did you observe any alteration in my dress? A. No; when he left he put the sixpence on the table, and walked out; I do not know that he spoke to me, nor I to him.
Q. Are you sure that this coat and the other articles were in the room I slept in? A. I cannot swear that; they were my lodger's clothes.
JOSEPH JOSLIN. I am shopman to Mr. Williams, a pawnbroker, of Brick-lane. I have a coat, pawned by the prisoner, on the 26th of May, for 25s., in the name of Joseph Byron - I knew him before.

JANE HUNT
. This is my husband's coat.

WILLIAM HAWKINS
. This is Mr. Hunt's coat - I made it for him some time before Christmas.

Prisoner's Defence. If you will send to Mr. Ward, the pawnbroker, he will prove that I bought a duplicate, gave 1s. 6d. for it, and paid 2s. for the interest; I had a green coat which I wore, but this coat was too large for me, and I pawned it for 25s. - I never ran away.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.
